comments.text: @ Matt Cohen:  This is a very strong retail concept and the storefront excellent.  I'd love to see some of photos of your interiors and I hope your store is doing well.  I was wondering if you offer any fresh/semi pre-made meals in your store or if you had a take out counter/deli.  I'm also curious to know where your frozen meals are prepared.  In the store?

@ Matt Cohen:  This is a very strong retail concept and the storefront excellent.  I'd love to see some of photos of your interiors and I hope your store is doing well.  I was wondering if you offer any fresh/semi pre-made meals in your store or if you had a take out counter/deli.  I'm also curious to know where your frozen meals are prepared.  In the store?
Hey Giacomo, sounds cool, but ... If they need a top chef and a nutritionist, it isn't easy. If it isn't easy, they won't do it.

I myself would rather celebrate the veggies than hide them.  If they are cooked correctly they can be fantastic.  But, otherwise, I like the concept of Kidfresh.  Jamie Oliver did a similar thing on his Food Revolution series.  A place where kids can come to connect with good food, learn about it and eat it.  School classes could come for a cooking lesson, kids could have birthday parties there, etc.  A place where learning about good food is a group experience (can be remembered and talked about later with friends that were there) and designed to be fun.  I'll have to go check out Kidfresh.  Thanks for the idea!
Ha, very clever hiding of the veggies =). Actually, my mother used to do this to me for any foods I didn't like, hoping that I'd acquire a taste for them over time.

kidfresh.title: KIdfresh

Unfortunately, sugary cereals do a great job of enhancing the sugar high with toys and games. Healthy snacks can have the same power to educate and amuse.

my_fork_says_2018_yes_2019_.description: The idea is to create spoons, forks and knives that react to food ingredients and changes color and show signs. During everyday meal time, while food is cut and poked, these cutleries react to touching ingredients and will show messages such as ‘O’(for healthy food) & ‘X’(for unhealthy food). Depth of color will also indicate how healthy or unhealthy the food is. By using these fun cutleries during at the table, children can find immediate information on what they are eating in a very intuitive and simple way.
my_fork_says_2018_yes_2019_.creator: f0d9f706a1807e2169313526f1a3714d

comments.text: Using utensils as tools is helpful because we can get them as they're about to go for it, whether they're about to eat foods that's bad or good for their health. It's a very playful concept.
@Ruben Not nitpicking at all. Almost, again I asy, almost all foods are okay in moderation. The counter, of course, is that a diet of oranges would not be caught by this system, nor exactly healthy.

Cool concept!  And I agree with Patrick that immediate visual engagement with the user is very valuable.My concern, though, would be that this idea might be better applied at another spot along the experiential pathway of preparation and consuming of food.  If a person's fork starts showing 'X's would that make them stop eating?  And if they stop will that half eaten food in front of them get thrown away and wasted?  I think it would be a bummer if we wasted more food than we already do.Also something to think about are the foods that don't require a utensil such as burgers and fries.  But I guess then the fork could be used more as a probe.What if your concept was applied to utensils used during the preparation stage?  Such as in a mixing spoon.  Or what if your pots and pans had handles that showed 'X's and 'O's on them depending on the ingredients that were being prepared in them?  If my pan handle started flashing with a red 'X' it might prompt me to make sure there is a higher proportion of vegetables to oil in the pan as I am making the dish.  So the pan would help me keep my preparations on track for achieving the optimal balance between taste and health.Sorry to go off on a tangent.  But thanks for the concept.  I like it!
I appreciate that it is visual and tactile. The more senses the better.

Cool idea, but it seems hard to realise. Can it be done? 'Lab on a chip' integrated in your fork? Well, why not in future.
Also: some fats are good for you. It would be a pity if the fork told you not te eat the mackerel. But this is nitpicking.

my_fork_says_2018_yes_2019_.title: My Fork Says, ‘YES’

oliver_s_radishes.description: My Dad (an organic farmer) has been teaching my nephew, Oliver, to grow a vegetable patch. His radishes have been really successful so Dad's been helping Oliver sell them to some of Dad's existing customers. Now Oliver's turned this into a school project, even including a bit of maths to work out how many bunches end up making.
oliver_s_radishes.creator: 49d75f861bdf99e6736c5f3f85e41b62

comments.text: oooh it's beautifull ! but I think not everybody has the chance or the resources to affort this ... any way it is cool XD

An expert dad and a single-item vegetable sale are one thing... but I think the main idea is a great one.  Using the growth of a vegetable garden as an opportunity to not only learn about cultivation of good food specifically, but also to expand it into a multi-disciplinary project to teach (and intertwine) subjects such as math, business, chemistry, climatology, mineral science, etc., etc.  One garden could be a school semester's worth of learning material (and inspiration) for kids.  Great inspiration for the project!
This is a great idea.. unfortunately, I only hope every dad is a farmer!!

oliver_s_radishes.title: Oliver's radishes

30_of_you_don_t_care_so_why_should_they.description:
If you're reading this in Alabama, there's a 30% chance that you are obese.
http://dc.streetsblog.org/2010/08/09/our-waistlines-are-expanding-in-sync-with-our-car-dependence/
30_of_you_don_t_care_so_why_should_they.creator: ed73f6b46391b95e1d03c6818a73b8b9

comments.text:
http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/02/080207163807.htm
This article is just one reference but I have heard of this conclusion on numerous occasions; lower income families have higher rates of obesity. I think this is an important factor to consider, especially when coming up with solutions to this problem. Whatever solutions we suggest should be extremely cost effective otherwise people simply won't be able to try them out.

Yes, I agree with this too.  Kids will pick up patterns and habits from parents.  I know that I did - luckily they weren't such bad habits :-)  We need to look at raising awareness with children and also with parents.  Or even better, for children to raise awareness with their parents on the bad choices they're making!   Also, if parents are larger, then this sets the expectation of what's 'normal'.  This is such a tricky subject, but raising awareness of what is healthy and normal is so important - I'm all for embracing diversity, but we need to tackle the issue of an increasing waistline, especially if it's a parent's waistline influencing children's healthy upbringing.

I completely agree - adults and parents need to take the lead in making healthy choices and leading healthier lives.  If a parent is obese they are probably feeding their kids the same fattening stuff they are eating.  And they are probably not encouraging their kids to stay physically active if they are not doing so themselves.  It is obvious that kids look up to older role models for guidance in how to lead their lives.  And a kid's parents are their first and most important role model.  Adults, as well as kids, need to be targeted in the effort for us as a society to learn how to make healthier eating choices.  Good point!

30_of_you_don_t_care_so_why_should_they.title: 30% of You Don't Care So Why Should They?

cooking_club_web_service_and_community_e.description: Since parents are key influencers w.r.t. kids' eating habits, and many parents don't believe they have the time, money, or skill to prepare anything but microwave pizza, harness the power of the community and the Internet to show them how.
cooking_club_web_service_and_community_e.creator: 24f6e3dc1bbc5a5dfb1e5c6481b94eb7

comments.text: Very simple, fun,and convenient. I recommend using meetup.com to find interested members, to form these "Cooking Clubs", and to get the word out. I already know there are different types of foodie groups,so  these cooking clubs would be a nice addition in the cooking/food category, but it also stands out because of the web service.

Building on Dani's comment about time: After getting to know & trust one another, cooking club members could also have the option to participate in self-formed meal sharing groups that take turns cooking for one another (saving everyone time). Perhaps there could be a web/mobile/social media app to help form & run groups, and remind and hold accountable whoever's cooking each day.

LOVE this idea. I'd have a couple of additional questions, though:
1. How would we differentiate this from the myriad of other cooking instruction and recipe sites on the internet?2. Given that one of our arguments is that parents don't think they have time, how can we get them to take the time to go to a website and interact online? What channels would we use to promote the site?

cooking_club_web_service_and_community_e.title: Cooking Club - Web-service and community event for parents

taste_to_try.description: Get social influence inside the house with 'Taste and rate'. Every time you taste new (healthy) food as a child you can add it at your 'taste collection' and indicate if you liked it. The more you collect and the more you like, the more points you get. With a certain amount of points they can get a free mysterious product at the supermarket. The height of ranking and amount of free mysterious products, will be compared with friends and stimulate to eat more varied, healthy and to taste more.
taste_to_try.creator: ac7a4b650ac4fdef4304037f269682ae

comments.text: I like how this is tackling the "my kids wont try new foods" problem, and I like the game/competition/reward elements.

I Love this idea!  I think it has real potential especially if proper game mechanics are applied this could be very successful.  Friendly competition is always good - everyone is winning.
In my childhood, we had recycling competitions or food drive competitions for homerooms.  Same thing can be applied here.  My big concerns is:- is this infringing enormous cost on the parents- what if the kids have allergies or have a family with religious beliefs. 
Just shooting off some general "game" ideas:
Give kids an online "passport" where only faculty and parents can sign off on there "tried" list. -  online means we save paper as well-  engages the parent as well-  kids lose things all the time-  there maybe some fun data between classes or schools or region that the          kids might want to know.- might have good strategic data to change the learning curriculum to upsell more liked foods the next time around.
Kids can engage in Daily quizzes about healthy foods for extra points.  Maybe of fridays they can wager a certain amount( like jeopardy's daily double)- doesn't matter if they copied the answers from a kid.  The information still  passes through their brain. 
Friendly competition in "seasons".  The Macro game loop is to beat other classes, the micro is to beat their classmates.- Any competition drawn out for too long are no long fun to play.- Every week, stats come out to see how each classroom is performing.  Kidsget to visually see how they compare, whether good or bad. - program needs to be tweaked to play keep players excited, and hoping for the  next "season" to start.
Just some random thought.  Again, great idea!

Exactly, I  think that food rating shouldn't be done afterwards. It should be established before. Eating healthy should give tyhe user a good score. Eating junk shouldn't. And I think that all participants here agree that eating vegetables and drinking milk should be well rewarded in points. A happy meal should generate a poor score. This wil help everyone, but especialy children to avoid nocive items. It's like the tobacco tax.

I think it'll be important with this idea to make sure that the system doesn't accidentally backfire and make kids avoid the foods that other kids didn't like, and also that the supermarkets don't just end up using it as market research to decide which products to get rid of.I like the reward system, though, and the incentive to try something new.
What I also love about this idea is that it delivers knowledge in the real world (as opposed to other posts that try to deliver knowledge through virtual applications)Again, it's a really great idea.

Very good idea, I love it!I think it should be pushed more towards the gaming side, meaning that collected points will allow each child to a privilege (treat, access more options, purchase an ugrade etc...) This way, the child would be motivated to eat more healthy, (since his cup of milk could be worth 100 points but the candy could only give him 5 points...)

Great idea! Combining what kids like (surprises, presents, friendly competition) with their 'fear' of healthy food. Repetition also very important. Did you think about how physical activities increases how kids value the taste of food? When your body demands nutrition, food always tastes better! It might help kids to succeed better at winning points.But kids also like to cheat at games. How now to make it such that it doesn't become too complicated with rules. The ideal would be if the first incentive to participate is the mysterious prize, but then the game takes over and keeps kids captivated and eager to try more interesting food types. Good luck with this cool idea!
I like it, the supermarkets will be join this campaign, they impulse garbage products, if they change the route would be very helpull.

Going further along the lines of having kids rate the new foods, we should break it down into taste and texture. For example, I do not mind the taste of lima beans, but hate the texture, unless they are ground into pea soup.  Having the chance to rate why they like or do not like something should appeal to just about everyone and thus extend the appeal to more than just smaller kids.
Now if the entire school had their "mystery food of the week" program, all the kids could compare notes. When the majority like the taste of UMMPA's they will request more of them.

Like the idea, but broccoli is broccoli. It does not even sound good!  We might call the new food treats by different names to let kids go in open-minded to see if they like the "Mystery food for the week" before deciding that they hate it.
I really like that it encouraged kids to taste and receive positive input through higher ratings, etc.

taste_to_try.title: Taste and rate

comments.text:
Using "game points" could have the same effect on motivation as economic incentive....i.e you keep score getting more points for being healthy, and less for eating junk food. Eating healthy could be something to brag about as you get a higher score, at the moment it is very hard to compare how healthy you are, or even self-assess if I am truly healthy. comments.text: This concept is an oversimplification and does not fix the "lack of knowledge" problem. It only offers a quick fix and does not teach children WHY certain foods are better than others. This method can also mislead children; the healthiest foods, whole fruits and vegetable and fresh meats, don't even come with labels on them.
Naked Juice does this on their packaging, so you get a sense of what fruits are in your bottled smoothie.  it would be interesting to see this applied to other types of food.
My 7 year old loves to count/measure -- we set a target that he shouldn't drink anything bottled with more than x grams of sugar. He loves to read the labels!

Gra idea, al buscar el cambio en la percepcion  que los nios pueden tener sobre los alimentos sanos. Solo le agregaria una guia de ejecucion divertida para igualarlo a su principal competidor, la comida chatarra. Aburrido vs Divertido.

This idea reminds me of a killer sushi restaurant in Vegas that had business cards for their sake -- on the front was a picture of the sake, with stats on the back (how it was made, where it comes from) -- what about cards for healthy foods?
Nice idea. Very direct to the goal. I think once a month will already work great.

sharing_grandmas_secret_recipe_get_the_e.description:
Grandma's secret recipe will always be a favourite. Can we get the elderly involved by sharing their personal secret recipes with the wider community. It could be a great opportunity to also create links with the elderly community.

I am sure that they will be willing to share their secrets.
sharing_grandmas_secret_recipe_get_the_e.creator: bac1161f308485387a307b2bfce571eb

comments.text: Great idea.  Our grandparents are a great resource of untapped knowledge and wisdom.  And traditional recipes handed down are great.  As well as an appreciation for the value of food and the process of preparing it.  But I think one of the only ways to make an old recipe compelling is to tell a story about it.  I will build on this in a moment...

I agree that older people always seem to have the best recipes and the more great tasting fresh food children are exposed to the better, but I think you're dancing around a more powerful factor. I love the food my grandparents make because it tastes good and because I love them.  When I cook a recipe I learned from one of them I am transported via good memories to a familiar kitchen and a warm smile. 

What if we  encourage families, grandparents included, to create family traditions around healthy fresh food?  What are your thoughts Ching?

sharing_grandmas_secret_recipe_get_the_e.title: Sharing grandmas secret recipe, Get the elderly involved

_kyu_shoku_do_it_yourself_school_lunch.description: Japanese elementary school lunch system allows the kids to be close to what they eat.  Every day, the kids serve themselves with the lunch that the veteran nutritionist has designed.  Serving each other makes them think about menus, how to divide evenly to all classmates, how to use the cooking tools, think about the food itself, etc which enhances the interest toward food.  Who can be NOT interested in a good smelling big pot of healthy food when they're in touch every day??
_kyu_shoku_do_it_yourself_school_lunch.creator: ab4500f587c332736ace741d8c674832

comments.text:
My sister-in-law, whose little family just moved to Ketchikan, Alaska, posted this in her blog today: "The school is also starting its own organic garden where the kids get to grow the food and then eat it at snack and lunch time."  (http://daysatthehayes.blogspot.com/2010/09/first-day-of-school-pics.html)
This could involve the younger age kids too.  Maybe combine elements, younger kids help grow the food, older kids help prepare the food?
What a great idea - this is hands-on and a big responsibility for the children - and an amazing learning experience for all involved.

Brilliant! We have to make more opportunities for our children to change their lives and habits themselves. When a child "pulls" knowledge and especially through experiential interaction, it "sticks" for their lifetime. Plus taste and smells help aid mental and memory retention.

The idea it's great, for grown kids over 13 years old or beyond, because smaller kids are very active, they don't think about consecuences of his acts and thats worries me a lot, accidents occur so fast if you don't have control of the situation and little boys can imagine that they are grown up to cook home alone. This is a hurdle that I don't see in all of the inspirations (home safety cooking), Teaching a boy how to cook implicates the use of boiling water or oil, sharp knives... It's our responsability think about it, that before school teaching cook

I've lived in California all my life, and I've only experienced the American educational school system. I only recall getting served food by adults during lunch (at lease in elementary school). This concept gets kids involved at all levels. I think it's a great possibility!

Interesting post, really like the idea of getting kids involved in part of the process that is 'getting food', could we take this further and have schools grow some of their own food as well?
Not ever having lived in the USA, i'd be interested to hear what people think about the cultural differences between Japanese and American kids and whether an idea like this might not sit too comfortably across the board? Or are kids just kids where ever you are in the world? :-)

Wow, very nice example, especially considering that Japan has such a high overall life expectancy (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy). I searched "Kyu-Shoku" online and found many sources of good info about this. Thanks for sharing!

_kyu_shoku_do_it_yourself_school_lunch.title: "Kyu-Shoku" Do-It-Yourself school lunch

take_some_cues_from_the_enemy_aisle_.description: How might we make fresh food as exciting to kids as the candy aisle!
take_some_cues_from_the_enemy_aisle_.creator: c4b6b8771b65eb2b1f342d622d7ea6ff

comments.text: An interesting question... But... the unfortunate issue is that regardless of glossy fixturing, the vitamins and fiber in broccoli don't have the same affect on a kid's body, or taste buds, as the bright colors and simple sugars of a piece of candy do.  So it is a visceral urge that compels the kid to seek the quick fix of sugar.  But your point is understood.  Maybe there is something to be learned from the candy aisle that can be implemented into the bland (to kid's eyes) vegetable section of the grocery store.
Great point, Brendan!

This inspiration has alot of potential. I'm sure everyone knows how forbidden food (or fast food) taste so much better than 'healthy' food. What about taking away the 'healthy label' from healthy food?

Very good point! I believe that another enviable characteristic of the "enemy" side is that they are always ready and easy to consume. The same does not always apply to fruit, vegetables and other healthy food that needs a minimum preparation before consumption (cleaning, cutting etc).

Good one. Color, texture, lighting, interactivity, line of sight from child's eye height...these are all qualities that seem to work in the store. Then there's the conditioned response to crinkly paper that signifies sweets/candies. How might we strengthen the positive response to audible/olfactory cues of fresh foodslike a crunchy apple snap or fresh-picked tomato smell? Mmm!

take_some_cues_from_the_enemy_aisle_.title: Take some cues from the "enemy" aisle

kinestatic_learning.description:
a majority of kids are kinestatic learners, they learn by doing. 80% of the world's population is involved in agriculture or some form of primary industry. 100% of the world depends agriculture and primary industries. Kids love to discover new textures, smells, colours and taste. There are extremely sucessful correctional programs in America that give juvenile deliquents opportunities to gain agriculture skills. We all have a natural love for exploration, it just needs to be guided. 

getting kids to love food (IMO) is all about getting them involved. I'm support the concept already established of engagement. We learn the different holidays around the year, why can't we teach our kids the different vegetables in each season? Even Obama is recommending 'active participation' for parents for their child's educational benefit. Engage the parents! Give them a skill they can be proud of and their children will follow. As they say, 'lead the strong and the weak will follow'.
kinestatic_learning.creator: 11b6ee1d02177113fb64a568eb21ecf9

comments.text: I think an interesting angle to this is considering children's ability to get around. We would want children to be able to have all these experiences even without a parent who would take them to markets or help them build a garden.  So I think we need to think about how kids would access these learning opportunities.  How can we make sure that little people, who can't drive, can participate in food related activities?  Should farmers' markets be located with cycling infrastrucure and public transport options?  Should community gardens be child friendly and child accessible?  Could gardens and markets and other food initiatives have child input?  There are some interesting bits of work around children's independent mobility, and developing Child Friendly Cities.  I think this bigger picture stuff could really help the practical application of this kinestatic learning concept

I think an interesting angle to this is considering children's ability to get around. We would want children to be able to have all these experiences even without a parent who would take them to markets or help them build a garden.  So I think we need to think about how kids would access these learning opportunities.  How can we make sure that little people, who can't drive, can participate in food related activities? Could gardens and markets and other food initiatives have child input?  There are some interesting bits of work around children's independent mobility, and developing Child Friendly Cities.  I think this bigger picture stuff could really help the practical application of this kinestatic learning concept

kinestatic_learning.title: kinestatic learning

comments.text: GREAT question, Jane! I think that the spirit of the DIY culture can definitely be captured in a unique and powerful way in an effort to increase their awareness of fresh food. Imagine a DIY culture being instilled in a school as students engage in learning more about sustainable, fresh foods...they could build and ideate on different garden layouts, container types, self sustaining business models to support their workd, etc. Tremendous potential in merging DIY culture with Jamie's charge!

question_who_s_the_real_target_here.description: It's the parents who make the food choices in the households, not the kids.
question_who_s_the_real_target_here.creator: 654952541b27012218ead56c7fdfadf6

comments.text:
In my opinion it's the speed and ease of fast food that makes parents buy more of it.  Working, stressed, parents, who don't have time and energy to be concerned about making healthy cooking a part of their lives (compared to the concerns of money which is much more immediate) - because they simply don't have time or mind space for it. 
When I've had a bad day, which seems to be most days - I want to come home and pass out of the sofa - the first thing I think of is wine, take-out and mind numbing TV. It's easy. It's less stress. It's relatively cheap (I can't make a single meal for the same price they would charge for a burger -  economy of scale and bulk).  It's win win win on face value - and when I'm tired and beaten, face value is really all that matters.
Coupled with that - more than a century of advertising, engineered flavors, fun - youth targeted experiences and a place you can take attention starved kids to simply get rid of them and have them play in a safe environment = short sighted but immediate solution.  The spiral continues.
To me, the problem goes a lot wider than food.  It's fighting 50 years of culture. It's about parents not being able to cope with the strain of kids - and this might be due to kids not being active, playing outside [it's not safe anymore and we are all paranoid of movie-like horrible things waiting out there in the world, so McD's, video games and TV sounds safer). It's fighting parents' modern lifestyles - of which economy and perception plays a part.It's like fighting the tobacco industry - because no corporation is going to sit back and see they're fast-food profits disappear without a fight.  It's most likely the culmination of at least 3 generations of slow paradigm shifting towards faster, easier, societal value systems (like health vs wealth) etc.  
If I was a philosopher, I would have said that it will take large scale visible degradation, actual children dying daily and 50 years of seeing the results of our ways before minds start to change.  not just the enlightened few who watch TED. Look at HIV AIDS - what it took for people to notice - and to what extent the greater society actually cares about it (as long as it doesn't happen to me).  Education is always the better option - and it's been first on the list to solve almost any wrong in the world... but I'm starting to think it's overrated - simply because it's too slow and resource intensive.  Luckily I'm a designer and not a philosopher - so I'm eager to challenge something else.  I'm eager to learn behavior, and not counter it - but manipulate it.  I don't want to think "fight" it - I want to think "join" and "steer". If that makes sense.
Exactly, Leo. It's the kind of thing that if you can find ways to help get parents involved in the long-term THEN you have a great solution.
A friend picked up sewing when helping out his 9 year old son with a school project. With a smart approach, I think the learning can extend from school to home.
Uhhh. Okay.

Viorel, I'm not entirely sure if you're posting a rebuttal or agreeing (or both?), but there are many many people out there who are not ready to become parents, but are anyway. And yes, quite a few do need educating. That's sort of my point.

We can find something bad into everything, the only thing is to make it good from it. I think with will and wish all things are possible, like carying is sharing, share the good you have there and use it to make a diference, use it for the future of our world. For us!

Is not about what they prepare at home or not, yes changes many things, but trust me that if a kid knows, he can easily chose from what he knows. Even if that means to bypass his parents. A student should bypass his master at any meanings, even if the master in our case the parents are not always as they want to be. But lets not go deeper into it. While afecting todays consumption of food and beverages, also it is influenced by the budget. And if parents does not know what is good for their kid, they are not ready to become parents. Or there should be first educated maybe more.

Great point. And disturbing photo, Jeff. I completely agree with your premise...it is clear that if this is to be successful it will need to bring all stakeholders into the conversation, including parents, kids, school officials, community members, etc. I find that kids can be incredibly persuasive when they come home from grade school with new knowledge that they want to apply at home--many families have been persuaded to become more diligent at recycling or to start composting kitchen scraps due to what their children learned at school. But this often doesn't start until grade school...so many unhealthy eating habits are instilled in our kids at such an early age (heck, have you seen the ingredients on baby food...yikes!!!!). Perhaps it even starts with educating people about the benefits of making their own baby food out of whole, natural ingredients. Anyway, good thinking here!

question_who_s_the_real_target_here.title: Question: Who's the real target here?

comments.text: Jorge, Thanks for the comment!  Yes, I think there is such great opportunity here for brands to extend their presence into the fruit and vegetable category.  'Owning' their key product's foundational fresh ingredients could really make great strides toward building kid's awareness of and interest in fruits and vegetables.  I am not sure why it hasn't already been done!  Thanks again!

I think it is a viable concept. Because they can educate children about healthy eating. Obviously, the products must be honest in their ingredients and their design should be fun. Should be a profitable alternative for brands and educational for children. Good idea.
Thanks Francesca!
I love this!

Emir, Thanks for your comment! I agree that there is a danger in tarnishing the 'fresh food experience' with brand names.  But, I think that in actuality the branding game has been underway within the world of fruits and vegetables for hundreds of years now.  As an example, carrots were traditionally grown in multiple colors.  But in the 17th century Dutch farmers started cultivating only orange carrots as a tribute to William of Orange, the leader of the struggle for Dutch independence.  Who knew a brightly colored root vegetable could be the 'branded' symbol of political freedom?  As with carrots there is most probably a story behind every fruit and vegetable name and variety that we otherwise take for granted.  All that I am proposing is that brands utilize that tradition to further their brand identity exposure.  And attract the attention of kids to the fruit and vegetable aisle.  But you are correct in that there is quite a mythology of nature to be considered if this concept were to be developed.  Thanks again!

the whole idea about fruits and food being named is that they are inherently embedded with the history of how they came to fruition (mind the pun), thus, branding food in this way would dilute, homogenise and weaken the power and mythology of nature.

Arjan, Thanks for the comment!  Yeah... after staring at all the piles of different apples at the grocery store it hit me - why are none of these apple names branded?  Fuji, Gala, Granny Smith, even Macintosh, no one really 'owns' these names.  So why wouldn't a brand develop a new variety of apple and give it their own name?  Heck, even Apple (the company) could have some fun and do their own apple.  How about the 'Steve' apple?  Apple's brand recognition would then stretch into the grocery store and be certain that everyone thought of them when they were picking out fruit.  There could even be Apple Store tie-ins with 'Steve' pie baking contests at the Genius Bar.  Ha ha, now I am off on a tangent.  But, yes, there are lots of opportunities, I think, for brands to point their brand identity in the direction of their root ingredients.  And get kids to take notice in the process.  Thanks again!
Nice out-of-the-box thinking. If a brand that has a good rapport with kids comes up with something like this, it's bound to be a succes.

hybrid_produce_brings_advertising_dollar.title: Hybrid Produce Brings Advertising Dollars!

create_a_palate_sneak_it_in_early.description: If we create a palate for fruits and vegetables, even while a baby is in the womb, then nature will take its course and a growing child will have a desire for these foods. We may underestimate the power of food to create a demand for more of itself and by introducing a wide variety of fruits and vegetables from early pregnancy through infancy we develop a palate for healthy food in a child. If we start with mothers-to-be and create a selection of "cocktails" made from a wide variety of fruits and vegetables we will be creating a natural desire in children. Obesity starts early and the battle may be lost by the time a child is a toddler. We have to start before they are born and continue to "feed the beast" as wide a variety of fresh fruits and vegetables as possible. Eating bad food is NOT natural. It is a learned behavior that once started is difficult to change.
create_a_palate_sneak_it_in_early.creator: 047f0c01907eb2365cbc731fd25c3bf7

comments.text: I spoke to a woman from India the other day at a blender demonstration and she was blending all kinds of spices like cumin as well as ginger, garlic and peppers. She told Indian children are born with a palate for spices because it is part of their culture and she believes it is because of the mothers diet and the child develops a desire for these spices as they are nursing. I live close to Salinas where we have so many vegetables that go to waste before the can make it to the marketplace. I know we can find a way to turn these vegetables into a fresh juice for both pregnant women and to mix in baby food. I loved V8 juice as a kid and it was pretty much the only vegetables I had. It took a long time and a French wife who is a chef to train my palate. Earlier is better.

I spoke to a woman from India the other day at a blender demonstration and she was blending all kinds of spices like cumin as well as ginger, garlic and peppers. She told Indian children are born with a palate for spices because it is part of their culture and she believes it is because of the mothers diet and the child develops a desire for these spices as they are nursing. I live close to Salinas where we have so many vegetables that go to waste before the can make it to the marketplace. I know we can find a way to turn these vegetables into a fresh juice for both pregnant women and to mix in baby food. I loved V8 juice as a kid and it was pretty much the only vegetables I had. It took a long time and a French wife who is a chef to train my palate. Earlier is better.

Developing food palettes have a lot to do with the culture you grow up in. I don't know how it happened, but I absolutely love trying new foods and I'll try anything at least once. I am all for exotic foods, foods from every culture. I'll ask my parents how they did it...
Really interesting. Never thought you could begin getting kids accustomed to healthy food variety before they are even born!

I think the French food culture is a great model for us here. They teach their kids not just what to eat, but to also appreciate, respect, and demand quality food. Things may be changing there nowadays, but it used to be you did not eat on the run, in your car, or on the subway. You did not eat in front of the TV, or at your desk. You always carved out time to sit and have a proper meal.

create_a_palate_sneak_it_in_early.title: Create a Palate - Sneak it in early

produce._the_possibilities_how_to_make_f.description: Eating plenty of fruits and vegetables can lower the risk of heart disease and stroke, decrease blood pressure, and may even protect against cancers. Unfortunately, most Americans do not eat enough fruits and vegetables to receive those health benefits. It’s no coincidence that the leading causes of death in the U.S. are heart disease, cancer, and stroke. Grocery shoppers in the produce section often wonder: What is this? What do I do with it? It doesn’t look very good -- is it worth the time to prepare it?

mommy_and_mine.description: Children are most influenced by their parents. Let's create fresh fruits and vegetables in "Mommy" and "child" size labels. This helps the entire family eat healthier. This concept focuses on the inherent nature of children to what to be involved, do well, and do as others. We can start with small fruit labels, but this idea of letting children 'own' their health even at a young age is powerful. It starts with labels, but can move to sections in supermarkets, refrogerators designed with "kid friend;y" spaces, and more.

vegetable_circus_stage_shows.description:
A Vegetable Circus stage show uses movement arts and circus skills to teach children about healthy eating and living.  The performers are cool role models who visibly demonstrate the benefits of a healthy lifestyle, while keeping the audience captivated with their skills. 

We would start with a revamped stage show that tours underprivileged elementary schools across the country.  Along the way, we can recruit and train new talent to lead shows and after-school programming, through which we can integrate many of the other most important concepts presented here on OpenIDEO.

This concept not only promotes healthy eating and food knowledge, but also thinking for one's self, anti-peer pressure and bullying, healthy activities, physical fitness, and trying new things, while including the parents in the process.
vegetable_circus_stage_shows.creator: b1bbf4f42563deb613ba7ce2171c302f

comments.text:
There are a bunch of other concepts that I believe would work very well with the Vegetable Circus: After School Cooking is Fun Club & Role Model Chefs, 17 of the 21 of the points from EAT Educate All the Time, plus the Hero Food Movement and Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Stickers and Tattoos (their concepts could blend together well I think!).  And perhaps Smoking and Junk; I think its presents a potentially useful strategy if used carefully.  Those are my favorites!
(P.S. my previous post was cut-off, but I also really liked Demian's comment below about a Summer Camp; a great long-term dream!)

We live in a Country where 2/3 of the adult population is overweight/obese and childhood obesity has more than tripled in the past 30 years (among children aged 6 to 11 years increased from 6.5% in 1980 to 19.6% in 2008, and among adolescents aged 12 to 19 years increased from 5.0% to 18.1%). Fast food joints abound and most school lunch programs do not follow guidelines of daily servings of fruits and vegetables. The Vegetable Circus is a creative initiative that intend to change the tide by communicating directly with the children, and by consequence their parents, using ludic activities with educational purpose. As a Chemist/Biochemist that works in one of the USDA Human Nutrition Centers I applaud their concept and give them full support do develop this program further.

Positive role models are always a good way to influence desirable behavior change amongst children. I believe that there are many good opportunities for story telling here. We all love good stories with positive outcomes.

FoodPlay is a great program; our goals are similar, though our methods vary some. A couple of our friends performed for FoodPlay, and they were kind enough to help us make sure that our program is both significantly different and, hopefully, an improvement on some levels. Here are some of our guiding principles:
Our shows are currently built on modules of information, so that each performance can be formatted to fit the needs of the schools we visit; we insist on each performer being genuine, and speaking their lines in a way that they're comfortable with; our shows are designed to be as dialectic and interactive as possible, resulting in us often going off-script in a controlled manner; we're part of a 501c3 non-profit, which distributes
Sorry for posting so many times...here's a link to FoodPlay's website: http://www.foodplay.com/

This reminds me of my friend Barbara Storper's traveling educational troupe called "Food Play". They incorporate hip-hop music, dance and dialogue to persuade school children to stay away from junk food and adopt a healthy diet.  They've been around for a long time and have made a huge impact on the lives of countless children across America.

This reminds me of my friend Barbara Storper's traveling educational troupe called "Food Play". They incorporate hip-hop music, dance and dialogue to persuade school children to stay away from junk food and adopt a healthy diet.  They've been around for a long time and have made a huge impact on the lives of countless children across America.

This reminds me of my friend Barbara Storper's traveling educational troupe called "Food Play". They incorporate hip-hop music, dance and dialogue to persuade school children to stay away from junk food and adopt a healthy diet.  They've been around for a long time and have made a huge impact on the lives of countless children across America.

It is important to have a longer presence with the kids than just 1 show, Demian; please note that this Concept's title includes "...After-School Programs", which we're running again in Somerville, MA now, this time for 3-5th graders. 
This concepts starts with the Stage Show tour as a mechanism for us to recruit young talent for such Food Circus Clubs. Including cooking lessons in these clubs would be the big change from how they stand now; gardening lessons as well would be a great fit (thanks Ian!)
A summer camp...now that's a nifty suggestion! Another long-term dream next to the TV show perhaps, but realistic methinks! Online communities are low-priority for us right now, but could be another piece of the puzzle.  Thanks everyone!

It sounds like the Vegetable Circus could have lots of entertainment potential.  The trick, to me, would be in continuing to develop kid's interest in and knowledge of food after the performance.  The love of vegetables and understanding about healthy eating will need to be nurtured in kids on a long term basis if it is going to have a lasting effect on their life styles.  Could the circus performance be the genesis of 'Food Circus Clubs' that kids join and continue to be involved in into the future?  Could there be an online community built around the Circus concept?  Maybe a Summer Circus Camp?  Some good developmental potential there.  Thanks!
This is a fantastic idea. My granddaughters don't particularly like vegetables, but they are influenced by their friends, kindergarten teachers, and circus. Hope you make it to their school.

What I like best about The Vegetable Circus is that it makes learning about and eating vegetables fun. It's an interactive model full of energy and people who really care about healthy eating and promoting active lifestyles. A group poised to create big and positive impact!
WOOT go west coast vege-circus... wait when you win does that mean you'll become multi-coastal?

What a great idea.  I've seen this group perform on the west coast -- they are talented, fun, and really have a way to get through to children.  Want to get kids to think that fruits, vegetables, water, and exercise are fun, the Veggie Circus have talent (and calories) to burn.
These guys rock! Spread the word.

I'm very impressed by your proposal - especially because you mention parents. I think that too many "bright ideas" in education fail because they don't recognize the extent to which success in cultivating healthy habits starts at home. 
I also concur with the folks who've commented about incorporating an element about cooking, and would like to encourage the Vegetable Circus to think further "up the food chain" and think about ways to incorporate gardening lessons too!
I love the Vegetable Circus!
Pearing food with circus fun will be a great carrot to lead kids to healthy eating! Shoot, it leaves me (s)peachless! This will definitely be fruitful.
You folks are just plain awesome!!!
Throwing in a cooking show and field trips about edible wild plants and I am on it!!!
What a great way to make eating vegetable "cool".

The combination of circus and healthy eating is a winner.  Circus arts can help support healthy eating behaviors by helping the kids become more aware of and confident in their own bodies.  This sounds wonderful!

I'm intrigued!  
This program sounds like it is effective and easily replicated, not to mention COOL because of the interactive components of both the circus tricks and the cooking/ food education. I would have loved this program when I was growing up!!

After examining the other most popular concepts, I believe that we should add cooking education to this program. We could have that be a primary element of the initial take-home interaction with their parents, and also integrate it into the after-school programs.

So many struggle with eating habits,making it fun to learn is the best principle !!!!!! And involving the whole family and starting with kids is great. They are often the ones that motivate us adults the most. GREAT job !!!! Keep on it !!!!!
The Vegetable Circus wants to bring the magic of Vegetables and healthy living into communities in all 50 states and beyond. Lets help these veggie-angels do more of what they are already doing!
the kids love being able to participate in these kinds of veggie circus shows! it really leaves an impact that is palpable and memorable!
I like your TV show idea too, but I think starting with a national tour of stage shows would be a good way to stir up enthusiasm first.

The shows are so much fun, and really get the kids moving, and thinking. There is such a good, strong message behind this program...
Let's help The Vegetable Circus grow!!
This is a good idea because it is interacting with kid's on a more personable/ Real world level. Two thumbs up!!

turn_passion_into_compassion_by_sponsori.description:
Children and adults who live below 250% of the Federal Poverty Level do not have access to fresh foods because of cost and distance. No amount of education can change access. You have to put the food in the the communities that need it. 
Meanwhile, there is a wave of passionate people (above 250% FPL) investing in Community Supported Agriculture (CSAs) for their own families. Have farms who offer CSAs sponsor a local community in need through free/discounted fresh foods, education, and community picnics.

herbie_the_hairy.description: Herbie the Hairy challenges kids to give it a full set of hair, using a fun planter pre-filled with compost, easy-to-grow herb seeds, & simple instructions/info for growing, cutting, & eating hair. Kids discover agriculture, cooking, nutrition, & new foods through play & the naturally encouraged adult interaction. The planter, which can be decorated as an art project, is made from repurposed items (yogurt cup, juice box, bottle, egg carton, can, etc.), ideally biodegradable for easy transplantation option.

comments.text: The food stamp idea is a good one, as it is often the poorest that are most afflicted by high rates of childhood obesity. Larger grocery stores already have systems in place for knowing what type of item you've purchased. So perhaps a two-tier system of food stamps could exist where a person could get $200 of food stamps a week for fresh foods or $100 of stamps for all other foods. By changing the economics, we encourage better behaviors.

could we tie this in to food stamps?  for a lot of families, finances can be a big barrier.  parents have to give their kids what they can afford.  making good food more affordable could go a long way.

change_the_economics.title: change the economics

comments.text: I love this idea because it allows students to gain first hand experience with the journey of their food from seed to plate. But keep in mind that the North American growing season and school year don't coincide. In fact, the reason schools have off in the summer months is so that kids (back in the day) would be available to work the farm during peak growing/harvesting season. You'd have to plant with kids in winter/early spring of the previous grade and resume food/garden education in the fall of the next school year. Might be tough for kids to grasp it all through such a slow and drawn out experience.

from_garden_to_table.title: From Garden to Table

fresh_kiosks.description: I guess we are mainly talking about socially disadvantages children / parents (concerning education, culture / language, finances)? An approach could therefore be to develop a healthy but fun and affordable kiosk chain with an educative mission – sort of "Dean & Davis goes Hasenbergl" ...

comments.text: Okay interesting! So while Mrs. super sporty, career-lady enjoys her fruit-proteine-acai ... drink in the gym, her child is eating crunchips in front of the tv; )?

I dont think it is should be mainly associated to socially disadvantaged children, however i am sure that a high percentage are effected. I see a lot of it is down to parents from all social/economic positions. 
There are many parents who don't have enough time, i.e. busy with work or other commitments, some simply cannot be bothered, or simply don't get it and themselves are not educated in the importance of diet and Fresh foods.
So teaching kids about the benefits of fresh food / diet, in general should be just as important Physical Education.

elementary_school_farm_farm_science_camp.description:
Twenty years from now, we want our kids raised with the knowledge of where their food comes from and to make sensible food choices.  During their early childhood education, we need to make it a sense of normalcy and practice that fresh food is a way of life, just like brushing your teeth every morning!

Elementary School Campus Farm
* Build a small fruit and vegetable farm on a plot, or for urban areas, in container pots
* Engage all grades level, teachers, family members
* Host farmers markets where parents can shop while they wait for the kids to get out of class
* Host fun student contests like “who can grow the heaviest watermelon”
* Creates a sense of ownership, responsibility, community, food science education

Farm Science Camp
* Similar to one-week 6th grade science camp
* Teach common food origination concepts, DIY farming samples, games, community
elementary_school_farm_farm_science_camp.creator: 17b182e0fe7b66a43216bc9444c4bd83

comments.text: Hi,it is good to tide kids to farms where they can find healthy food.

elementary_school_farm_farm_science_camp.title: Elementary School Farm & Farm Science Camp

With all the excitement, maybe involve kids in the shopping & preparation as well? What do you think?

farmer_s_market_meets_fast_food.description: If farmer's markets selling fresh fruits and vegetables played by the same rules as fast food restaurants - convenient, fast, heavily branded, heavily advertised and visually fun - kids might be drawn to them and more interested in eating there.
farmer_s_market_meets_fast_food.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Great reinvention of the fast food experience!

Arjan, Thanks for the very kind comment! This 'Grow2Go' concept would take some development, but I think there is definitely some opportunity there for expansion.  And I agree - the OpenIDEO platform is great for suggesting build ideas for other people's inspirations and concepts.  I know for myself, my creativity is catalyzed by the creative ideas of others, (heart shaped vegetables - I love it! :)  ) so I have really been enjoying OpenIDEO.  Hopefully we will be able to end up with a concept that can make a difference.  Thanks again!

That is one of the fun things of this platform, discussing ideas and getting to other ones. How about the best Turkey stuffings workshop for Thanksgiving? Or seductive herbs for Valentine's day? (I once made a special love-themed menu for friends who had just got engaged, with rose-spoom and heart-shaped vegetables).Anyway, I think this is one of the best concepts so far.

Arjan, great point!  I seem to remember McDonald's birthday parties too (though not ever getting to go to one...;) ).  This is a key factor to think about in regards to fast food brands - their ability to appeal in one way or other to just about every age group.  Kids get Happy Meals, parties and play areas, teens get a place to eat junk food, hang out with their friends and cause trouble, grown ups get a quick, convenient and cheap fat/salt/sugar fix and seniors get a place to have coffee and visit with their friends.  For this 'Grow2Go' concept to truly impact the communities it is in and compete with established fast food restaurants it will need to also appeal to multiple age groups.  And birthday parties for kids would be a great feature.  In addition to birthday parties, 'Grow2Go' could do pumpkin carving contest parties, smoothie-making demonstrations for older people, vegetable gardening workshops in the roof garden, etc., etc.  There are lots of opportunities here to spread the word about healthy food and locally grown produce,  And all could be branded and advertised to the public in a way that competes with typical, and let's face it tired, fast food.  Thanks again for the comment!

This reminded me also of something that a lot of kids did when I was growing up (admitted: quite a long time ago): celebrating their birthdays at the local McDonalds. With a visit to the kitchen to see how a hamburger is assembled and of course loads of happy meals and milkshakes. Imagine the possibilities of having a kid's birthday party at a Grow2Go.

Arjan, Thanks for the comment!  I agree.  I would bet that the nearest farmer's market is probably not on most teenager's radar.  I think a consolidated branding and marketing effort could do wonders for the visibility of farmer's markets not only with the general public but also with younger people.  And if these stores offered healthy food in a highly marketed / branded / slickly advertised way, much like fast food restaurants, teens might be swayed to opt for this instead of fatty fast food when going with friends to hang out and get something to eat.  Thanks again!
Great idea. Most current farmer's markets have well-to-do adults as their main target audience. Bringing good food to teenagers in this way could definitely work.

farmer_s_market_meets_fast_food.title: Farmer's Market Meets Fast Food!

it_s_not_only_about_the_food_it_s_also_a.description:
The food our kids eat, just like the clothes they wear, can tell a story about them and can have a significant impact on their struggle to be accepted by their peers or to "win" a leadership position within the group.
Unfortunately, in the cases where lunch is provided by the schools, the food looses it's symbolic power to differentiate as everyone is forced to choose from the same limited options, leading to a group effect instead -- so they all opt to follow the crowd (and go for the chocolate milk).
it_s_not_only_about_the_food_it_s_also_a.creator: 9b27d03c9c42981fccfd4836552d1810

Educational workshops and/or a media campaign to inspire parents and kids may be the answer. See www.eatdinner.org for more info.

an_apple_a_day.creator: f71fc40ef707de45430fddd10aceb918

comments.text:
I like the idea, but if a kid got a tomato with their meal, they wouldn't understand. They'd ask the parent what it is and why they got it. If the parent doesn't get it, then the tomato ends up in the bin. I feel this has to start with parent education or it's just going to end in more food wastage.
McDonalds in Australia already offers apple slices with their happy meal instead of chips and juice instead of coke and has done this for about 2 years. I wonder how well that's going. I know my kids are happy with the juice whenever they have it, but they always want to have the chips instead of apple.

an_apple_a_day.title: An apple a day

comments.text: I like this idea since it goes back to giving children "real-life" (and not just virtual) experiences, re-acquainting them with where food comes from -- making them appreciate food in a whole new way.

digger_tots.title: Digger Tots!

When playtime ends, these little guys can be plunged head first into the nearest garden plot, or garden pot, and they will eventually grow into a yummy melon, tomato, or pumpkin!

fresh_food_empire_the_game.description: Fresh Food Empire is a social challenge game around fresh food, integrated with social networking sites like Facebook. Challenges accepted and done gain points, with which the player can upgrade their Fresh Food Empire. The goal of the game is to grow a global Fresh Food Chain Empire, including supply chain elements like farms, starting from a food stall on the street selling just 1 type of fruit or vegetable.
fresh_food_empire_the_game.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: I've seen several other social gaming concepts in the platform. Maybe it would be a good idea to combine them into one for the shortlist evaluation phase.

Hi Gabriela, thanks for the comment. I think it's brilliant to add nutritional value to the game. In the challenge, the better the nutritional value, the higher the points earned. Same can go for a balanced diet: the better balanced the challenges, the higher the total score.
Partnering with games like Farmville could be interesting. However, in the concept the game is platform independent, because some statistics show that Facebook usage amongst teens is decreasing. I couldn't find statistics for Farmville users yet, but I'm afraid that our target audience is only a small part of the players. A partnership with another game would definitely need to be based on reaching teenagers.

I would also say it might be a good idea to partner with an existing game like farmville. They are already ridiculously successful and are very innovative in their ability to crossover to the real world (they have promoted a particular brand of blue berries in the past and now have tie ins with 7-11 where buying certain things unlocks special gifts).Oddly enough, farmville is turning up to be a great source of education regarding how fruits and vegetables are grown.  Gamers can get a rough idea of what fruit trees, shrubs and crops look like.  I wonder if there is a way of tying in nutrition advice into the game. Could be as simple as having the nutritional value of each crop seed (for example, red peppers could say 'rich in Vitamin C and A'.  Or more complicated by partnering with supermarkets and having gamers unlock special gifts when they spend $X on produce.

fresh_food_empire_the_game.title: Fresh Food Empire - The Game

_my_small_farm_diy_kit_for_kids.description: A kit for kids that contains everything that is needed to start a small farm of edibles at home, even in an urban environment, even in a small space.
_my_small_farm_diy_kit_for_kids.creator: 84c04044b0796f3cedaff79875d9bbd5

comments.text: Good stuff Yorgos!  I especially like the idea of using the same visual language that toy companies use to promote and sell their products.  Maybe characters could even be developed that are found in the instruction book 'comic strips' and then also found online in 'helpful tips' videos on the 'Farm Kit' website.  Anything to keep the kid's interest over the length of the growing cycle.  The characters could also be an avenue by which more healthy eating tips and info are presented to the kids.  Great possibilities here.  Thanks!

This sounds really exciting. We can include plants that are edible, so they can actually eat it if they want, unlike play food of the plastic kind. I can imagine kids giving it a lot of TLC , it will also be fun for them to see it grow. Perhaps we can include plants that are easy to grow, fast to grow (so they can see the final product within weeks), fun to watch as they grow, fun to eat, etc. You're right, communication of the product through packaging, how-to's, and highlights of the benefits, in the eyes of kids and parents, will be key.
This reminds me of the EarthBox Kids program in Alberta http://gfsa.wordpress.com/2010/06/29/earthbox-kids-in-fort-vermilion/
Great idea, and great illustration!

Very cute idea!  There are some kits out there on the market in the garden section, but none that I've seen catered to children.  This is just like having your own little ant farm or sea monkey kingdom that I use to have as a child.

_my_small_farm_diy_kit_for_kids.title: "My Small Farm" - DIY kit for kids

taste_the_difference_what_might_we_learn.description: Decades ago, the famed "Pepsi Challenge" once lured countless kids (including me) into trying their own blind taste tests at home. Could we encouraged children/parents to challenge processed foods with fresh ones -- to TASTE the difference? Really fresh foods actually do taste better than their less-fresh preserved equivalents!
taste_the_difference_what_might_we_learn.creator: 68c03a76152dc53fdd2c7c7ab07f2721

comments.text: This is great.  I've seen this approach taken with people of all ages to try and get them to admit they like a certain food.  In most cases the person tasting blind admitted to liking what they were eating.  But, when the truth was revealed (buffalo burger vs. regular, low fat cheese vs. full fat, etc.) the hostile attitude toward the food returned. There must be something beyond taste working here. Emotional or social influences perhaps.

taste_the_difference_what_might_we_learn.title: TASTE the DIFFERENCE: What might we learn from the old PEPSI CHALLENGE?

comments.text: Creative way of bringing sound into the process. "A Soundtrack of Your Eating Habits". Notice how different foods have different textures, and different sound when you chew them? I think this concept could be interesting. "Here's what an apple sounds like when you chew it...", "This doesn't sound so good..." - something along those lines.

landshare_scheme.description: Landshare http://www.landshare.net is an initiative in the UK that helps to connect people who want to grow things with people in their location who have land that they aren't using. Perhaps there's an opportunity to build something specifically oriented to youngsters, schools or perhaps connecting older folks with experience and wisdom to youngsters with energy and enthusiasm.
landshare_scheme.creator: 53134a6b4eaf1ae776a01a4610818ecc

comments.text: I like the way that landshare puts all generations in touch. I landshare with an elderly lady who used to grow veg in her garden before it got unmanageable for her. Now we swap stories about what is successful and what is changing in urban gardening practice; it keeps her up-to-date and is a great source of expertise for me. So, I don't think we should forget the older generation here in the UK; they have a lot of expertise about self-sufficiency.

www.myfolia.com
There are some really great services out there for this sort of thing - I especially like the way myfolia (once you've paid), provides you with detailed advice of what you can grow when, sets you dates to plant, re-pot, harvest etc.
If this is going to be marketed at children I think the 'social' aspect of the site should really be pushed. Sort of like a facebook for gardeners!

landshare_scheme.title: Landshare scheme

the_mythbusters_of_cooking_.creator: 08568b2ec4a87b3b0b512106deacca09

comments.text: hahaha is this true? does it exists ? it looks great !

invite_play.description: "Games like World of Warcraft give players the means to save worlds, and incentive to learn the habits of heroes. What if we could harness this gamer power to solve real-world problems? Jane McGonigal says we can, and explains how." - TED.com
invite_play.creator: 25bd98a22d94c4a47a0b1a1e23c3afff

comments.text:
I actually participated in the Evoke game she introduced in this TED talk, and I won!  I created a project called Binikou ~ The Human Powered School which encourages teams of kids, teens, and adults to come up with simple, practical solutions to helping young people get more of their basic needs met: healthy food, clean water, fresh air, warmth, light, and the freedom to express their body's excess solids, liquids, gases, and energy.  And the project has been giving a jump start by the Evoke sponsors, so that we can really make it successful.  Binikou is why I'm here at OpenIDEO, too, looking at more complex solutions to helping people get their needs met, so that they can be awesome!
So yeah, Jane McGonical is quite the inspiration!

Ever since I watched this TED talk...I've been wondering how to apply this to food. Is there a way to make shopping at a Farmers' market more like the epic win in WOW? How could a food lover "level-up" to become a "level 10 good fooder"? Can we use games to keep kids (and adults too) in a state of "Flow" where they are so engaged with learning about food, they lose track of time (search Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi for more on flow).

Ever since I watched this TED talk...I've been wondering how to apply this to food. Is there a way to make shopping at a Farmers' market more like the epic win in WOW? How could a food lover "level-up" to become a "level 10 good fooder"? Can we use games to keep kids (and adults too) in a state of "Flow" where they are so engaged with learning about food, they lose track of time (search Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi for more on flow).

invite_play.title: Invite play

This would be at least as valuable than the travelling critter shows and similar educational programs my kids have seen.  This taps into the "ice cream truck" vibe of some other concepts, in a different, creative way.
Food trucks have been a huge hit at UCLA http://today.ucla.edu/portal/ut/ucla-loves-the-food-truck-culture-153211.aspxToo bad they weren't there when I was there ;)

Square foot gardening is adaptable for dense urban conditions such as high rise apartment living or informal settlements.
grow_your_own_food_garden_in_dense_livin.creator: fe96e1403409d1d80835741b2edc6e70

comments.text: I like the idea of modularity.  If the perception of what it takes to plant and tend a garden seems too overwhelming for some people, whether due to time, space, knowledge, etc., breaking the project down into modular pieces could be a way to get people started.  Even if only by baby steps.  What if each 'square' was actually a self-contained planter or pot that came packaged with a specific vegetable seed and the necessary soil, etc. and then could be ganged together with other pots?  So each person could assemble their own garden in simple modular units according to their available space, time and vegetable interests.  Very cool idea.  Thanks!
For urban spaces, Sub-Irrigated Planters are even more productive and obviate any concerns of soil contamination:http://avisolo.blogspot.com/2009/10/how-to-grow-your-own-food-with-self.html

the_chew_it_forever_competition_.description: Implement a "CHEW IT forever" COMPETITION in every school - if u chew your bite for long (50 to 70 or 100 times a bite), you will discover that only health and fresh food tastes good (beside several other positive side effects)
the_chew_it_forever_competition_.creator: 06c50100c2893e3302d15912fbcf6bf9

comments.text: By the way, since reading this concept, I have made an effort to be more thoughtful about my own chewing -it really focuses me on the act of eating.  On a personal level I like this idea even more than I did before!

There is an iPhone application called Xtreme Krunch Kart, and the game starts when a player crunches a carrot, or produce a crunching noise intot the phone's microphone, this would go well with this concept.

@larry: nice, your input.i am not sure if competition is the right method in this case, nor am i clear how to handle such a competition. a song is not bad. def. i think by the issue of chewing we could succeed to reacht the task.

I like the idea of turning some attention to this aspect of eating, it's such a fresh perspective in many ways.  From a health POV, I like pushing against the concept of eating fast, and learning to really appreciate every bite.  From a epicurean POV, I like the idea of teaching people to really stop, think, and savor their food.
Personally, I gulp my food like a wild animal, so being able to be more mindful to not do that would be great.
So, how do we build on this, what would actually be the experience of these competitions?  How do we celebrate / encourage getting to that 30th chew, that 60th chew, that 100th chew?  Maybe a song or rhyme that lasts 100 chews?   I think I'll have to post a 'build on it' idea!
I was just eating some celery (with walnut-miso dip) and that's one food that you can't not chew forever. :-)

the_chew_it_forever_competition_.title: The "CHEW IT forever" COMPETITION

Some of these would be horror movies (like "how sausages are made"). Others might be adventure stories  catching fresh fish or collecting fresh eggs, or perhaps even romances like pollinating fruit trees and fruit harvesting  or honey.

the_hero_food_movement.description: The idea is to teach kids about the importance of fresh and healthy foods by a clear connection to their heroes. Everyone has a hero whether it’s Superman or Neil Armstrong. The idea also involves the parents but the key here is to let the kids take the first step since they are easier to reach. The goal is to create a positive spiral among student and parents in understanding the importance of fresh and healthy food.
the_hero_food_movement.creator: be3ceb39fa93771f13c03974b0503e32

comments.text: Good idea. Seems like a well thought through concept that's easy to build upon further and refine into something that could actually be applied in schools world-wide.

Good thought. I think wheter the teacher already has prepared some examples or the students share and think about the connection between their heroes and food (with some help from the teacher), the important thing here is to start a discussion so the students can learn about healthy food. And of course to bring that knowledge home and start cooking to later on win a field trip. Learn and reward.

I think the idea has some good potential.  The trick, I think, is for the teachers/leaders to connect the right 'heros' to the healthy food.  Kids tastes change pretty quickly as they mature.  So the hero role models that are put forward as associated with a certain vegetable, fruit or other healthy food, will have to be carefully chosen so as to resonate with the kid audience or risk being deemed 'uncool', 'old' or for younger kids, etc.  If the kids don't click with the hero they might not be interested in the vegetable or healthy food they are promoting.  This is not to say that the program could not be developed so as to be able to be tailored to a specific audience on the fly.  It just has to be considered in development.  Thanks for the concept.  Great stuff!
Hey Hampus  this is great. I especially love how you've outlined the idea using a video  using strong story-telling to convey a well devised concept. May the force be with you!
PS It would be great to have Marvel and DC aboard doing literature for kids.

This idea particularly works with kids outside of school, say at sports clubs.  I'm particularly drawn to the incentivisation and reward mechanism attached with it; the number of stickers you need to go to an amusement park or whatever is fantastic.

I kind've like the idea of Captain Carrot flying in to battle the evil Grease Monster and save the day. I think it would have worked on me as a kid, as long as the good guys could easily outnumber the bad guys. "Oh no! The Fat Fiend was hiding in my hamburger! Better eat The Sweetcorn Saviour and his sidekick, the Battling Bean Beauty to make sure he doesn't cause any trouble in there!" Endless combinations!

Very cool idea! If you could also implement a garden that the kids can help built and grow, I think this would really take off. Kids love seeing things grow or change over time, like when you were a kid and you had to plant a seed in  a Styrofoam cup, I remember racing home daily to see how much it had grown during the day.
Ps. I meant that they still recive individual stickers but the awards along the way are a sum of thoose individual stickers and the class as a whole gets the award.

Hi Rob!
I agree with you maybe instead of "invisibility" it could be something tangible like a toy to play with. I think it would be important that it's a collective award. Meaning that the class get the award instead of the idividual (so a certain amount of class stickers instead of individual stickers). That way no one gets left out and when it comes down to it, it's a group effort solving a group problem. What do you think?
Good input Rob! Thanks.

I agree with the main psychological point you're suggesting: kids perceive healthy eating as cool when they associate it with their role models. That's precisely why we recruit performers in the Vegetable Circus who have demonstrable talents that impress children; we also use that talent to keep their attention in our Stage Shows, and train kids in those movement arts & more in our after-school programs.
We've also been giving out stickers as rewards, and it's amazing how popular they still are with kids! I hadn't considered having the kids collect them to earn upgrades though; perhaps we need to offer things more real than "invisibility", like the right to use trickier toys (like a bongo-board, or poi).

Great idea. The heroes could be real people too - sports stars, celebrities, social leaders - I could see a great campaign developed around stars' favorite vegetables and how it keeps them fit & strong.
I really like this idea. Its a good concept. I like the thing about cooking with your parents. Cause I think, If you have cooked it by your self, you also want to eat it.

Hi Jonathan. I think you are right. I guess the definition of Hero at first seems more boyish. I guess the thought here was that anyone could be a hero and we have to try and make a connection to that person. My little sister at that age had baby spice from spice girls as her hero. Even a spice girl need powers to take the stage. What food that gives you a lot of energy could a spice girl eat? Bananas are good for energy. I'm so happy to see people commenting! Thanks

I love the idea from the kids side of things. I feel they will have all the incentive they need. However, from some of the toy market research I have looked over, boys of that age tend to be more attached to super hero's than girls. Maybe create a spin off of the same program for girls, something that would relate more to princesses or animals (based off the market research I have seen).

Wow, this concept integrates many of the minor inspirations and concepts I've come come across and come up with nicely. I really like the hero theme, show & tell, award/reward system, sticker chart, hands-on cooking with parents, etc. These are all good incentives for kids. Well done!

Though had to laugh when instructed in the 'How Are the Kids?' commercial to fill out the Change For Life questionnaire, mail it in and wait for a response with tip cards to be posted.
