vegetable_circus_television_show.description:
The Vegetable Circus currently exists on both coasts of the United States, using circus arts to teach kids about proper eating, healthy activities & more through stage shows, workshops and after-school programs.

With the help of Jamie Oliver and his production company, Fresh One, we propose that together we create a Vegetable Circus television program, that would include all our messages into a fun format that can quickly and effectively reach the masses.
vegetable_circus_television_show.creator: b1bbf4f42563deb613ba7ce2171c302f

comments.text: We live in a time where people eat food that hurts themselves. the Vegetable Circus wants to put an end to that. They make veggies cool. This would be a great TV show, hilarious, educational, It would be like sesame st. with Veggies!Two thumbs up!

Knowing how successful and professional the vegetable circus has been motivated the performance group I am in to also go the extra mile and also work with kids through performance while spreading a good message to kids.  The veggie circus has done a lot for kids and a lot for spiral glyphics performance group in which I am in.   Because of there help it is much easier to also pass good healthy knowledge to children through performance for us.  The children are our future and I m very happy to have the vegetable circus on the for front.
vegetables are awesome!!
If you have some great songs to go along with the show you could repeat/reinforce the concepts in videos.

Hey! It's the Vegetable Circus!  I know you guys!
I also, think, totally unbiasedly, that this is an excellent idea. :-)  Combining play, exercise, art, and healthy food into one awesome ball of media seems like a brilliant idea.  It could be a web show, if nothing else, with traveling groups that visit schools, for more personal contact, as well.

Given the other most popular concepts currently, I think the cooking & food elements of this show should be central; perhaps 2 full recipes demonstrated by kids per half hour, at least a third of the total content, with the age-relevant health benefits of the major ingredients explained, and some gardening instructions mixed in as well.
This would be a great way to reach out and inspire communities. The Vegetable Circus is fun for the whole family and being on t.v. would be a great way to inspire the young and young at heart!
What a great way to reach a lot more kids & get them excited about Fruits & Veggie's! Awesome idea!
There is SO much potential here...Jamie Oliver and The Vegetable Circus could do AMAZING things together on TV!

vegetable_circus_television_show.title: Vegetable Circus Television Show!

comments.text: A very interesting idea.  If Lebron James, as an example, talked in detail about what he eats, and what he LIKES to eat, kids might listen and actually emulate not only his moves but his diet too.  Push this idea further to have Lebron James talk about how his diet is an integral part of his daily workout.  The fact that he couldn't be this good on the court without always being good to his body off the court.  So that kids that want to be good basketball players and practice every day, but also eat fatty fast food every day too, come to understand that their dreams and goals are disconnected from how they live day to day.

the_food_curriculum_.description: To curate a short term program spanning over every school subject/discipline where every class  shall inform the last & the next.  A holistic and heuristic approach that makes sense and thus creates the relationships needed for pure understanding and behavioral change. As it is structures that arrive out of content and not content out of structures.  Use design methodologies as models for every subject, designs investigative nature can change habits, neurons, & ultimately lifes.
the_food_curriculum_.creator: 87071ee2050ad7bc38ed005d03434901

comments.text:
also as a point, to make, once children have taken part in these programs SO much data will be available, about likes dislikes based on what they have learned and what they want once theyve learned it, you cannot argue with that.
the fact that with every year that passes, ideas, technology, philosophies change, which is why the data stream will forever self analyise and NEVER be out of date in terms of what the mapped actuality of health and knowledge is at , thats the problem with current education, its based on continuously out of date information that becomes more and more irrelevant as the years pass.
this way, the content will forever be fresh and relevant.its called a two way feedback cycle, through doing you learn self evolutionary teaching is the way forward. which MUST facilitate the idea of speculative design and infinite scalability.

a short term program, because ultimately this is "one way" of looking at things in life, and although a fundamental corner stone to health wellbeing and longevity, if it were to "blend" too much into the background ie, part of the standard curriculum, it would lose its impact / saturation / value.It needs to be a focussed thing you do at a certain time of year, although parts of it can extend beyond that, but the fundamental idea of EVERY subject taking part is all because it extends BEYOND the school and into everyday life, to adults and to different cultures and industries and societies, this is not an easy thing to choreograph -but i think its possible and only one of very few ways i think it would be possible to tackle such a subject. 
The idea is to make very clear communicative connections in a short space of time from a 360 angle, and not dilute the power of the concept too much. 
Ultimately this is still ONE philosophical point of view and not THEE.

I also agree, however, why a "short term" program?  I think that no student ever took home economics seriously, but a food science class could have tangible content. Food science coursework could certainly cover all of the major areas of study and congeal them in to a fun, capstone type class.  There were also many other suggestions that I think would be easy to incorporate in to a class/lab type scenario.
i completely agree, it should be more subliminal than all the 'branded' ideas given thus far... il build on this in a bit today..

Interesting idea and think that it could almost be a subliminal way of getting kids to understand the importance of real food. There could be a social network for kids to post their progress on projects and ask for advice on problems. Allowing children themselves to discuss the issues and ideas they are encountering.

science >history>art>sport>geography>politics>economics>design
so much potential

comments.text: I love this idea.  Especially if it will help in breaking through some kid's stubborn 'picky eater' shtick and get them to try new foods that they otherwise would not have.  And being presented with the opportunity to taste something not usually eaten in an environment different than home without parents that have wittingly or unwittingly condoned their kids development of bad eating habits, might get kids to take that new and uncomfortable step..And in this regard, a little peer pressure might be a good thing.  If all the other kids have tried the roasted Brussels sprouts, a roomful of expectant eyes might get the picky kid to do the same.  And who knows, they might just like it!Discussions about different tastes and how we experience them, as well as exploration of how ingredients taste alone and when combined with other things could all be very helpful.  There are many interesting taste experiments that have the potential of helping kids broaden their taste palate.  And in turn develop their appreciation for good food.

healthy_kid_recipe_cards.description: Put recipe cards and cooking ideas next to the healthy food choices in the supermarket. This way people can be inspired or even be given the knowledge what to do with the raw ingredients.

comments.text: Good idea to think about!  What if the recipe cards were sponsored by some sort of online 'Kid Chef' video game?  An overlap with my Ratatouille concept perhaps?  In addition to a recipe, the cards next to each item would also have a code, that when entered into the Ratatouille video game, will go toward building the kid's game recipe ingredients, connect the virtual to the real helping them learn about food and of course give them points and experience to move them further through the game.  Each time the kid goes to the grocery store he or she can search for ingredients to complete a recipe or full 'meal' in the game.  Each new recipe the game offers could be more complex or originate from a different culture, etc. building an understanding of preparation, tradition and culture in the process.This activity would aim to get the kid interested in trying to cook these recipes for themselves (with supervision of course).  The game conveniently causes the kid to search for the real ingredients so since they are standing in front of it they might as well buy some of that ingredient to try at home.Recipe cards that connect virtual play with real world cooking.Fun stuff!Thanks!
Isn't there a similar mobile app that shows a recipe after you enter what ingredients you have? But i like the _analogue_ aspect of your idea.

I think of a website for discussing and voting these cards. Kids can post images of what they cooked and suggest their own recipes (choose ingredients, upload image). New cards with topvoted recipes are released monthly.

I like the idea, personally I always make use of these cards when they are available in the supermarket. They give me new ideas of recipes. The idea could also be combined with "my first cooking set" mentioned before. Kids could collect the cards and make meal wishes at home. Cooking a meal can be fun and become a family activity?
I love this idea. Many supermarkets already have recipe cards in-store that give ideas for what to make for dinner. How can we specifically make it appeal to kids?

create_a_new_supportive_consistent_food_.description:
Replace our processed food culture with healthful, deliberate behaviors. I've included a photo of the Jersey Shore cast (oh yeah!) at a family dinner to show how a strong food culture can triumph. The cast comes from an Italian-American food culture, and despite all the crazy choices they make, they continue to value quality homemade food. How is this possible? Growing up they probably saw family members buying and preparing fresh food, communing over homemade meals, and in general valuing quality food.


This concept introduces another food culture through behaviors and traditions, during lunch time, classes, and field trips. Classes and trips are similar to other concepts for this challenge. Lunch is turned into more of a traditional sit-down family-style meal with an adult leader in more of a parental role. Key areas of focus are shopping, meal preparation, and the sit-down experience. Ultimately the goal is to give kids another model for selecting and eating foods that can become second nature to them.
create_a_new_supportive_consistent_food_.creator: e570d4eb8d96d6a184300eb08e1c9e42

comments.text: Hi Ed, Thanks for your comment. I learned so much about food from my family as well. Amazing how quickly traditions can change in just one generation!
this is great, i love your concept, leveraging value of food via lessons learned from my family was my inspiration too. good luck!

Hi Kleber, I agree with you that family habits are most important. In the U.S. it seems that family habits unfortunately are trending more toward processed and convenient foods. If we could change these family habits directly that would be ideal. This concept is really about training kids while at school, since there's so much variety in kids' family circumstances.

Children learn to eat mainly based on family habits. If this revolution starts "in house" there's more chance to succeed. Of course, this will take time to build but meanwhile this effort may influence the past and future generations. Perhaps reinforce this concept creating healthy delis for practicality.

create_a_new_supportive_consistent_food_.title: A new, supportive, consistent food culture - with better habits come better choices

comments.text: I would have loved this in middle school.  If I could recreate this in the office, I would.

We did this at my Democratic school (Sands, in Ashburton, Devon).It was amazingly great. As with all things, particularly with young people, I think it's not just about the idea on paper, but executing it with the right vibe - staff can relax and be themselves with the kids, stick on some music and play together in the kitchen. Throwing a piece of boiled carrot at each other is fine as long as you know not to piss around with boiling water. It should be a lesson by accident x
amazing.

2 points:1) change the name of the cooking class/demonstration from 'home economics' - not inspiring for kids.2) VERY IMPORTANT to combine the healthy food message with healthy exercise. You need both.

To me, this idea should be paired with the other concept of having kids run stands at a farmer's market.  I love the idea of having kids cook for each other at school.  Imagine the sense of accomplishment and the sense of community created!  
Relatively easy to implement across many schools.  What would be the liability issues that need to be worked out?
Would need a professional nutritionist to make the best balance of the important food, but working closely together with a professional would be a good experience for children to learn themselves.
Wow! This idea is cool ;) Just wondering about the naughty kids ;) Anyway, it would be great.

Another thought -- what about a follow-on activity of cooking for their parents and teaching them -- one of the best ways to learn something is to teach it; teaching parents/extended family gives another opportunity to receive praise and unknowingly change their very home environment, which may be very unhealthy.

Nice idea! Actually giving kids responsibility is one of the ways we can embody the notion of responsibility for their health and long-term well being. Activity/challenge-based learning has long been a super-effective learning tool. It also taps into "knowledge is power" themes.
Nice way of using existing lunch facilities/resources to encourage children to learn about healthy eating, and get to know the lunch ladies better too!

students_get_to_create_that_day_s_school.title: Students get to create that day's school lunch for the entire school.

girl_scout_veggies_instead_of_cookies_ho.description: I'm inspired by the other posts about getting kids into gardens. Might there be some way to leverage youth groups like the Girl Scouts / Boy Scouts / YMCA or other to connect kids to fresh foods. What if the Girl Scouts boldly abandoned their famous cookies for farm fresh produce they helped grow? That's something worth going door-to-door with! Due to the concept of "food deserts" which are urban areas where large food markets are not found, your girl scout veggies would be a great alternative in these areas! Google food deserts and check out some community gardens and what they are doing to help serve these communities in Chicago-my home town for more information.

Great, I'm glad this idea inspires you! I think there is a great possibility a program like this would be a viable option for hospitals as part of a out-patient rehabilitation plan or as an addition to existing 'whole health' programs. 
A potential road block would be funding, though, I think if there could be research conducted that shows the direct positive benefit of the program on patient's health, many organizations would be very interested to jump on board!

comments.text: I like this idea. Maybe the game could be about what a character eats. So if you ate bad foods, certain things would happen to your character versus eating healthy foods. I think there is something really there about making it a game.
no its not an and ... Its an example of something that has a lot of succes between the online games and could be an inspiration to create something alike
Is this an ad by Zynga? or a way to solve the problem? (because it reads like an ad)!

I like the idea of it being a 'teams of kids on competitive farms' reality show.  Similar to my 'Farm vs. Farm' reality show inspiration.  Maybe, if sticking with the software game idea, there might be a way to tie the game into multi-player systems with other classrooms around the world. So each day when the kids came to school they could see what the kids from India had done on the virtual farm while they were sleeping.Or maybe build in math and science lessons to different scenarios of farm play.  Or real video clips of actual farm situations that kids can learn from or copy.  Interesting to think about the developmental possibilities.  Thanks!

I like the idea of FarmVille.  Can we extend it any make it into a reality show for children?  Could we have teams of children from different schools that create their own real 'FarmVille' and see if they can bring it to life.  Could be sponsored by Farmville itself, or fruit & veg companies, or Jamie Oliver!  Children would get to learn, share knowledge, understand how 'hard/easy' it is to go from a fantasy to a real world, etc.

I'd love to know more about the appeal of this...I'm not familiar with it but it would be interesting to know more about why this is so compelling. Is it because of the content, or more to do with the form of the game? Any thoughts? It's a great inspiration that's for sure.

inspiration_from_will_allen_and_growing_.description: “For kids to make their own soil, grow their own food, and then get to eat it, that’s a very powerful experience,” Will Allen says. “There’s nothing like hands-on experience for kids who are bored with school. They get excited about what they’re learning and then take it back to their classes.”
inspiration_from_will_allen_and_growing_.creator: 3c5ac18177dcfcbc5227922f019cfdb0

comments.text:
Claire, Will Allen is an inspiring personality and one of my heroes. I actually helped work on the garden at the University School of Milwaukee (known as "Karen's Garden") when I used to teach there (see link photos from our Earth Day 2007 garden launch event). I'd love to see personalities like Jamie Oliver, Will Allen, Joel Salatin, Alice Waters, etc, unite and join forces in this cause.
A few things that I'll never forget from my experience working with Growing Power on our garden project: 
1. Stop talking, start doing. 2. Start something. Even if your school/community garden just starts with one tomato plant, it is better than not starting anything at all (at USM, we started in stages. First, with composting from one dining room. Then the garden. Now they have the makings of a model school/community garden and food waste composting system in place).3. Food is a huge social justice issue. Only in the USA do we see obesity and childhood hunger in the same community. 4. Form community partnerships. Reach out.5. Engage youth.6. Worms, worms, worms!!! Will's composting and vermicomposting methods are GREAT-anyone who visits growing power loves seeing the worms!

http://picasaweb.google.com/mjmontagne/EarthDay2007Photos#

inspiration_from_will_allen_and_growing_.title: Inspiration from Will Allen and Growing Power

comments.text: This is the sort of national spotlight that made things like pomegranate, goji berries, acai berry, etc so popular. These hypes caused consumption of the various "superfruits" to sky rocket. We're all enchanted by the idea of an "undiscovered, mysterious" berry from the Amazon, so it might be difficult to generate the same appeal in something more mundane. But it could be interesting if we were able to apply the same sort of exposure to something that is more familiar, like eggplant, and provide a variety of different ways to prepare it.

This is the sort of national spotlight that made things like pomegranate, goji berries, acai berry, etc so popular. These hypes caused consumption of the various "superfruits" to sky rocket. We're all enchanted by the idea of an "undiscovered, mysterious" berry from the Amazon, so it might be difficult to generate the same appeal in something more mundane. But it could be interesting if we were able to apply the same sort of exposure to something that is more familiar, like eggplant, and provide a variety of different ways to prepare it.

Interesting... Maybe play it like the Chinese tradition of 'Year of the Dragon" or 'Year of the Tiger".  Every summer the First Lady (or some other cultural icon) could declare that it was the 'Year of the Tomato' or 'Year of Celeriac' or whatever.  The organizers would have to hope that the year's crop of the declared vegetable was a good one (last year was a bad one for tomatoes) but it could be a good way to get the conversation going.  Tie in to nation-wide farmer's market promotions, Food Network special shows (Iron chef battles featuring the veg), etc.  Thanks!

diet_thumb_personal_health_inspector_nut.description: Diet Thumb is an application to be built for the mobile device platforms as a nutritional guide and game.
diet_thumb_personal_health_inspector_nut.creator: d0df490d8535535b7c2db1a2c8731416

comments.text: awersome ! an app for iphones to help you improving your diet and excersices ? jaja lov it XD

I like this idea of utilizing apps and smart phones.I believe we can make this more visually understandable and fun.As Sascha mentioned, I also think that it would be better if many more people ate unpacked food. So maybe taking pics of food they eat and diagnosing that could be a way.

I like the idea of an app that tracks what you are buying in real time and feeds back to you nutritional info.  But, as others have mentioned, if the app is geared to bar codes does that influence the user (even slightly) to choose a packaged product with a bar code over an un-bar coded fresh vegetable?  Maybe, instead of a bar code reader, the app input could be photo recognition.  So it would recognize spring onions and a whole raw chicken, give nutrition info and also recipe suggestions, etc.  But, regardless, I understand the overall idea.  A sort-of 'health coach' you have with you at all times.  A great idea!

Bryan, I do like the convenience of being able to simply scan barcodes. For that matter, why couldn't some additional nutritional summary/points information also be displayed at checkout or on the receipt (just like how some receipts show total $ spent and total $ saved on discounts).

Ah yes, it seems Diet is more serving as a buzzword here really.  The original idea was for the individual to set their own values, like "I don't want to eat any item with more than ___ grams of fat per serving".  I did think about the fresh foods, and I thought that a "produce" button might be relevant.  I just think we should use technologically based ideas, instead of ideas based in things like cooking classes.  Have we forgotten what it's like to be a kid?  Kid's generally don't think cooking is fun, just sayin...Thank you for the input!  I'm glad to just put some ideas out there that could help make a difference!

I like the idea, but why base the app on diets?
I believe diets like Atkins (taken from your mock ups) don't work well on a long timeline.
And then: I'd rather like people buying unpacked fresh stuff than anything else.

diet_thumb_personal_health_inspector_nut.title: Diet Thumb - Personal Health Inspector / Nutritional Facts Database/ GAME!!

urban_meal_kits.description: “Children are natural mimics who act like their parents despite every effort to teach them good manners”
urban_meal_kits.creator: 28890c0b3a775ebd22755c0a1a35b9f4

comments.text: I agree with the opening quote in that it will be very hard to convince kids to make healthy eating choices if their parents are not also convinced to do the same.  But I think the real trick becomes figuring out how to get the parent to select an 'uncooked' meal kit instead of a frozen pizza, processed packaged meal or fast food.  A frozen pizza has only one step to its preparation, takes minimal effort, comes pre-loaded with fat and salt so tastes pretty great and would probably be cheaper than a meal kit.  That's a big perception hurdle to get over.  I think convincing a parent of the benefits of buying a fresh uncooked meal kit is achievable.  But it would be tough.  Lots of ad dollars and just the right ad message would be needed.
Awesome idea! Excellent work.
The key to this is that they are UNCOOKED. The cook still gets to have fun without worrying about the prep work. It's like you are on a cooking show.
Sound like some of the meals offered by Bighams in the UK http://www.bighams.com/
Sounds a lot like my idea. Good stuff

urban_meal_kits.title: Urban Meal Kits

how_might_we_make_healthy_cheap_and_easy.description: cheap and easy seems to be the way of the world - or at least for the majority of people juggling bad economy, over saturated life's and no such thing as work life balance...

comments.text: Dennis, I think you are asking some really good question. The money question for me is how do we fight a culture of cheap, quick, easy and profitable? I'm not so sure we even try to fight this system...I think we innovate from the outside with the early adopters and let the old system die. It will take a generation or two, but it can happen. I'm going to build off of your idea...thanks for the inspiration.

one way might be aligning "healthy" with previously un-related industries that are strong enough to use the "healthy" bit as an add-on to existing business models. Games (think real-life farmville- or even facebook robots executing commands that you post online); Appliances (think fridges with growing stuff in them - and it can prep, slaughter and water for you convenience); Entertainment (think corporate team builds or sport stars that have to farm to survive - or die on television for our entertainment.  I can see the merchandise in my minds eye).  I think the worst possible industry to try and compete in groceries.

how_might_we_make_healthy_cheap_and_easy.title: how might we make healthy = cheap and easy?

comments.text: Fantastic idea! Love the hands-on. Food = culture

I love this. Not only are grandparents often a trusted (even MOST trusted) source of knowledge and know-how for children, many have food preparation experience and habits that precede many of our bad ones! comments.text: As a kid I remember the frustration of going out to dinner with my family and being handed a kids menu, a different menu, to everyone else. A kids menu can be good in certain situations, but perhaps it needs a revamp?What about kids menus which include the same meals as the main menu, but in smaller portions? What if they also had the spices included in each dish listed for people to pick and choose based on their child's age and tolerance?

What is wrong with the world when a pizza parlor has a kids menu?  Isn;t pizza kid food by defenition?  Thanks for brinking this up.
I have taken my son to eat all sorts of places, and while I do steer him to different parts of the menu, or order and share with him.  I use the kids menu to get a kid sized portion.
But the BLAAAAHHH repetition of the kids menu is not helping our work here (mac 'n' cheese, chicken fingers, noodles with butter/oil, fries, or for a healthy option - "plain" grilled chicken,  steamed broccoli, baby carrots.)
Food is good for children of all ages.
But yes, less spice for small kiddies, they do taste more.  Stick to whole food flavors, not processed one.  (I say - bring back Ricci I Bicci)

end_the_idea_of_kid_friendly_food..title: End the idea of "Kid-Friendly" Food.

introducing_the_no_bake_sale_a_farmer_s_.description: Combine healthy locally-grown food with education and business that's good for the community, and you might get a Farmer's Market style table, stand, or even store that sells healthy produce and similar things that kids and teachers and parents have grown, collected, and made in classrooms and schoolyards.
introducing_the_no_bake_sale_a_farmer_s_.creator: c09d9310c3ca89257885d8363f40c09e

comments.text: What a good idea!

It's usually not a great idea to define yourself in opposition to something, since it's literally a negative connotation, and because it poorly frames what you ARE, but in this case, it seemed reasonable and amusingly descriptive. :-)  
Eventually, I imagine that people would have more positive names for these things, such as "young farmer's market" or school market or (name of school) fresh market, or something.  But starting off small, and playing on the ever-popular, but not at all health-promoting bake sale concept seems like it could be a real winner.
One of the best ways to develop a brand is to say what you're not -- in this case a non-bake sale says WAY more than a au-naturale sale. Awesome!
Thanks thanks! :-)I'm thinking of doing this for my own project, as a fundraiser.  Though we already have some schools that have a booth at the Farmer's Market here, which is awesome!
A great plan!
A great plan!

introducing_the_no_bake_sale_a_farmer_s_.title: Introducing the No-Bake Sale!  A "farmer's market" fundaiser run by the whole school

Yes!This is most important. It must finally be the parents that decide on what their children eat.

Sugar is addictive!When you eat sugar it gets the endorfines and hormones going wild in their heads  Sugar rush ! when you give something like candy to a kid, and it can get them cravings, you must know that it is dangerous!Artificial sugars like aspartame is releasing even more endorphines than natural sugar!!!
And nowadays it is not only candy or beverages that are full of sugar, many ready-made-food contains a lot! And the fast-food-chains combine their kid-menus so that they are maximum tasty and addictive.
Whatever you tell a kid about vegetables and fruit and how good they are for you, they will always choose anything with sugar in it!!!
If all parents knew this and the bad effects that sugar and poor quality of food have got on learning and health.
We should really implement an age barrier on when it is allowed to eat sugar, similar to driving licence or when you are allowed to buy alcohol.And we should impose a sugar tax, so that consumtion levels will be lowered drastically, and that food producers would not be able to inject it secretly.And the artificially types of sweeteners like aspartam should also be banned!!!

Don't I know it... and it's not just parents who don't care, there are plenty that DO care, want to introduce their kids to good feed and good eating, but are overwhelmed themselves, and just don't know where to turn!

comments.text: Cuties (tangerine oranges) have done a really good job at marketing directly to kids with its commercials and the slogan of "Cuties made for Kids."  They have managed to leverage their original logo of a cute orange and capitalized on it to appeal to kids.  Instead of using existing Disney characters to market their products which McDonalds and Burger King also do, Cuties have created a unique character that kids can relate to.

Phil, Thanks for the link to that article!  Simply amazing!! Exactly what I am talking about with this concept.  Because of the Shrek promotion Vidalia onion sales are up 30%-35% this year.  I love the interviews with parents that say their kids are freaking out over onions, excited to buy them, cook them and eat them.  Just think if other vegetables were promoted this way!  Kids would be going crazy in the produce aisle begging their parents to buy all sorts of healthy food.I am sure that this marketing cross pollination has been good for the Shrek brand as well.  The clever onion tie-in references something Shrek said back in the first movie.  I bet that kids, because they say the Vidalia onion promotional display, are now going back and rewatching the first movie, or buying it if they didn't already have it.  All this visibility in the produce aisle I am sure has helped to keep kid's attention focused on Shrek, has reinforced the older Shrek material in their minds and has gotten kids talking about Shrek to their friends.  All a good thing for DreamWorks.Really great to see that something like this got such great results and has excited kids about eating healthy vegetables!  Thanks again Phil!!

Vidalia onions are having a record sales year - why?  They decided to promote their produce to kids using Shrek!  ("ogres have layers")http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704123604575323433042544568.html
Thanks for the link Vincent!  Pretty interesting is right!  I didn't know anyone was allowed to slap high-fives with the First Lady! :)

Thought you all would find this interesting: http://www.disney.com/healthymagic
A new health campaign launched by Disney, featuring first lady Michelle Obama, one of the Jonas Brothers, & various Disney kid stars.

Vincent, Thanks for the comment!  Good thoughts about Disney cooking classes.  It might be very interesting for Pixar (owner of Ratatouille) to host 'Cooking with Ratatouille' classes.  The only difference between them and Disney is that Disney has a vast array of facilities around the world that could easily host such events whereas Pixar, I think, does not.  But I see no reason why Pixar couldn't do a 'tie-in' cooking class event at somewhere like Crate & Barrel or Williams Sonoma.  Ratatouille cooking classes for kids in those stores could open up huge new opportunities for Crate & Barrel or Williams Sonoma to attract the attention of a younger category of customer.  Which makes me start to think about the possibility of 'Kid Cooking' sections in those stores.  They could be stocked with kid sized utensils, lighter pots and pans for easier handling, fun cookbooks, food science experiment lab kits, food themed movies and video games.  The list goes on and on.  Boy, I wish the concepting phase was still open as I think there is more potential here for development.Thanks again for your comment!

Eddie, Thanks for the comment!  Some interesting ideas there.  I like thought of connecting kids to an online community and something larger and longer-lasting than just the in-store display.   And offering a new recipe would be great at getting kids excited about coming back.  Of course pre-packaged recipe ingredients would require a bit of coordination with the local grocery store staff but an issue not insurmountable to be sure.  Maybe a new recipe is featured every week that the film (or book) is in the theaters (or prominent in bookstores).  Kids could go online and watch a video of Remy offering tips on how to prepare that dish, read comments from other kids or post photos/videos of their own attempts.  And then the newly cultivated community of kids who have taken recipes and signed up online are given first notice about the DVD release or a companion cookbook, etc.  I like it!  Thanks!

Hey Demian, this is really fun.  How about there's a healthy recipe of the week, and everything a family needs is in one biodegradable container they just pick up.  e.g. 1 onion, 1 pepper, 1 potato, recipe card, nutrition info, colouring book/competition & link to video online with some.  In fact, let's put vegetable seeds into the biodegradable container and they can tear it up and plant it to grow things at home.

Awesome. In addition, just as you bring Disney to healthy food, you could also bring healthy food to Disney. Disney currently offers various popular cooking classes through their resorts/restaurants (including some for kids), but I believe they are more focused on the fact that these are taught by Disney "executive chefs", so really only appeals to existing foodies. Especially with Disney's efforts to revise their kid's meals to be healthier, couldn't healthy "Cooking with Ratatouille" classes be offered for kids?

Christine, Thanks for the link!  I figured there was a cookbook out there somewhere. I just hadn't seen it yet.  Interesting to me that the cookbook uses different artwork than in the movie.  Seems a bit less connected than it could be... of course it was probably some licensing issue :)  Thanks for the comment!
Great idea! There is a cookbook for Ratatouille published by Chronicle. http://www.amazon.com/Whats-Cooking-Cookbook-Kids-Ratatouille/dp/1423105400

Tom, great connector idea.  Maybe the rear-off recipe could have stickers for each ingredient so that the kids can put the 'eggplant' (aubergine haha) sticker on the eggplant they choose, the 'tomato' stickers on the fruit or tomato paste jars in another aisle, the 'herb' sticker.... etc.  so that using up the stickers shows them that they have everything for the recipe.I was also thinking that this idea could work for the Harry Potter brand too.  I think that there are a bunch of foods mentioned in the stories, pumpkin pasties, butterbeer, etc.  so there could be a stand in the veg aisle that lists them and has ingredients.  Take-away recipes could be in the form of book marks so that the kids could go back and tag the page in the book that the food item gets mentioned.  Of course cook books could be developed for all of these characters.  Or it might be fun for a 'sequel' Ratatouille cartoon cooking show to be made.  Remy could be in a kitchen and teach kids and parents how to make ratatouille similar to the movie as well as a bunch of other healthy French dishes.  Now that I think about it a Remy cooking show could be a lot of fun!Thanks for the comment!
I love this idea - could we also include a programme where we produce materials for the kids to plant in the isles themselves?  e.g. Ratatouille stickers to go next to the ingredients?

So is the object to figure out how to get kids to learn how to be more 'future' oriented and consider the consequences of their actions?  This differing 'time perspective' is very Interesting to consider.  Thanks!

I was trying not to get too far into the 'concepting' phase, but my point was that the systems we use should include a level of interactivity. The video was to demonstrate the point that children/teens have a different sense of experience due to interactive culture.
Can you elaborate on your idea? How can we use this new mindset to change habits and reach out to kids and youngsters? Are you thinking of some kind of collaborative garden or urban farming project?

That way parents can have fun cooking with their kids. Good intentions ('I should learn my kids how to cook') are then easily transformed into action.

social_network_based_on_home_gardens.description:
The most effective way to address this problem is a project with two distinct but integrated parts: home gardens and a social network-like platform, both oriented towards children and their parents. Basically, children are involved in the growing of vegetables, and as a result, are excited to cook with them. The Social Network supplies a framework for children to find and share recipes, tips, garden information, etc. 
This two-part approach fosters community – both online and in person. Children will begin to interact with each other, sharing recipes, suggesting plants, etc. Children become personally involved in the growing process, and because of that, will be excited to cook and eat the produce. Realistically, this will not be implemented every night of the week, due to busy schedules, etc. But perhaps it can be used as a planning tool on the weekends for parents and children to decide meals for the upcoming week, or can be used on a “special” evening when there is time to really put energy into a creating a meal. This way, children will learn to cook at a young age, and understand not only that it can be simple, but that it is fun and tastes good. As they grow older, perhaps outgrowing the social network, it nonetheless leaves a lasting impact. An appreciation of real food and a love of cooking is something that will last a lifetime.
social_network_based_on_home_gardens.creator: 99f5d38a3653a0ff34275480bdf1937e

comments.text: I've got your back mate.  Unreal idea.
http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/concepting/digger-tots/
yellowicepick - Thank you for your comment Please applaud if you like the idea
This would actually be great for drawing certain teens and pre-teens into the joys of farming and cooking fresh food.

social_network_based_on_home_gardens.title: Social Network Based on Home Gardens

fresh_fruit_pens_and_tattos.description:
Tattoos and markers will help encourage young children to eat more fresh foods in two ways:

1) EDUCATE PARENTS. Markers will indicate healthy food pairings and recipe suggestions (cucumbers and yogurt, carrots and hummus, tomatoes and cheese, etc). 

2) EXCITE CHILDREN. Once parents have more knowledge and ideas as to what healthy snacks may be, they can buy tattoos so their children can customize their fresh foods making them more fun to eat.
fresh_fruit_pens_and_tattos.creator: da9b15fdda5025b00f048e1cde77706d

comments.text: This is great!  Simple yet powerful, and taps into children's creative side.

I do like that the idea is really simple, cost-efficient, and most importantly achievable. There are many ways this could play out as well. 
We need to consider:
1) How will we create the tattoos? We will need to do some vendor research to see how this can be done. I can't imagine this would be terribly difficult, we already see some forms of 'tattoos' on eggs, and edible ink has been around for decades. I'd love to make it a sustainable ink...maybe even flavored? What if a batch of grapes had mini-smiley face tattoos that tasted like apples? WAY FUN! This might challenge a child's palate, but I think foster conversations with children (What is that, a grape? But it also tastes like what other fruit? Apples!).
2) Will we begin branded or unbranded? To Brent, Mike, and Demian's points,  I know brands carry a lot of weight. But I wouldn't want businesses to charge extra for branded fruits just to give them increased profits. We'd certainly need to work on a go to market strategy for this.
3) Will fresh foods come w/ tattoos or will tattoos and markers be sold separately...or free? I envision this could go either way, depending on partnerships with supermarkets (to Mike's point), and partnerships we get (not expecting Prada anytime soon Brent...sorry!), plus also the cost. 
4) How will this help encourage more healthy eating? As a stand alone concept, tattoos and markers will certainly encourage fun interactions and therefore positive associations with fresh food for children. But on a deeper level, tattoos would be part of a larger program, a bigger idea. I recall "tazo tops collectibles" in chip bags in the 90's. And I've seen some incredible ideas surrounding games in the other concepts.....would there be a 'collect them all 'component? Will it be a "Healthy Foods program on the Jamie Oliver site" - especially for the adults who are trying to find easy ways to incorporate fresh foods into their lives?
The feedback is great guys. Thanks!

I like this idea very much in that it potentially fosters kid's interaction with good fruits and vegetables.  I think, though, that the 'branded' stickers and tattoos will be the more compelling for kids and the ones they gravitate towards.  Very similar to my 'Branded Vegetables' concept in that the foundational notion is that brands and branded characters have a very large amount of persuasive power to kids.  Good work!

I think this is a great idea. I kind of like the idea of unbranded and branded "tattoos". I kind of think that you could make the branded tattoos to tie in with all type of fruit and vegetables to drive people to purchase healthy snacks (like you did with the peanut butter and cucumber). But would it be possible to actually sell the branded tattoos and donate the proceeds to the charity. You could almost position it so that if a supermarket is not branding or tattooing their fruit and vegetables that it is almost a crime, and it shows that a supermarket doesn't really support healthy eating if they don't brand their fruit and vegetables. It is an easy way for supermarkets to move beyond their rhetoric that we to frequently see.

Just wait until you can buy your prada apples @ waitrose. Joking aside - it's a very simple but fantastic idea and I bet it would motivate kids to atleast entertain the notion that fruit / veg is more than just healthy.

This is great feedback - thanks! I like the idea of making fresh foods fun and approachable. I also hope to make it educational and inspirational for parents themselves. Again, children are heavily influenced by their parents so I'd like to have adult labels that say literally "Mom,  "Dad", "Grandma". Then kids can have the fun tats! 
Another thought is to make the tats "ink" out of some sort of organic edible source...so that its not a chemical-based ink, but even using chlorophyll and plant science.

Love this! This takes the "here comes the airplane" trick to a whole other level. Parents should stop yelling at their kids for playing with their food and enforce it to act as positive reinforcement for eating their fruits and vegetables.
Even I'll use this... and I'm in my mid-20's!
nice! Kids would use them for sure
I could so see these ending up in lunch boxes... and having kids running home asking their moms to tattoo their apples too!

Thanks for the comment. I like adding toothpicks as chisels - forming food into scultures even. 
I like the fact that the pens/tats could be branded. Kids might eat  Dora the Explorer banana, for example.
Now that is out-of-the-box thinking! Kids love to play with food -- what about allowing them to make creations out of food with toothpicks, that they can then devour later?

easy_to_understand_food_ranking_system.description: Implement a simple to understand food ranking system on a 0-100 scale that helps kids easily appraise the differences between fresh foods and other foods.  Enable them to make those choices at the school cafeteria.  Create incentives to scoring healthy food points and healthy plate food combinations.
easy_to_understand_food_ranking_system.creator: e09ed176da6d8cae1f5a8864bbd8a58f

comments.text: This is available already! :-)  There are at least two of them that I know about.  One is the Dr. Joel Fuhrman version called Aggregate Nutrient Density Index (ANDI scores), which Whole Foods has started using, and the other one is by the USDA, which has been used for the NutritionData.com website (http://nutritiondata.self.com/foods-000998000000000000000.html), and their listing of healthiest foods (check out which food is at the very top of this one, at that link, it's a surprise!)

That would work with the game concept quite nicely.  An extension I was thinking of was to have playing cards that list "combinations" of foods that had point totals tallied up for a meal.  The healthier the combination, of course, the more points.  There's no reason that couldn't also be done with colors...  it just needs translated correctly.  I like it!

I wonder if we could make this easier with colours?  Perhaps if a child gets three 'green' meals a day, 2 'amber' snacks, and 1 'red' treat, then that would be their full healthy complement for the day.

easy_to_understand_food_ranking_system.title: Easy to understand food ranking system

comments.text: This is a great idea.  If the transportation details can be worked out easily, this could be a very efficient way to get the most out of limited resources.  Instead of spreading resources thin and planting a little garden in an empty lot within each neighborhood, hoping that it will survive with limited visits and attention, one mobile garden could be planted and transported to all of the neighborhoods.  So that a limited staff and limited resources could be shared, experienced and learned from by the maximum amount of people possible.  Thanks for the idea!
This is a fantastic idea.  Plus it builds on the idea that people can come together.  People working together would make a huge difference in how they eat and prepare food.

comments.text: That's a good point Vincent!  Supermarkets are another potential sponsor and they may be able to link together their sales effectively for this.  The ad circular at the front of the store can be linked by meal and include recipes so that families can take them home when they are done shopping - thereby also reducing waste!

Tied together with the produce aisle concept because I think the two could work well together.  Have the enticing display in the produce section with a coupon, shopping list (for the ingredients) and recipe.
Supermarkets may also have incentive to do/fund this, as it increases shopping basket size.

playingfooding_changing_paradigm_showing.description: From a research made on more than 100 nutritionists, psychologists and Pediatrics, (metacomunicazione) Playing is best way for children to learn something (77%) and it will work only if they'll be able to associate food with something fun and entertaining
playingfooding_changing_paradigm_showing.creator: 825ace1e7528a7ec6ff55a01cf1101b7

comments.text: What a fantastic idea!  So simple AND evidence-based!

playingfooding_changing_paradigm_showing.title: playing&fooding: changing paradigm showing cooking as one of the most creative acts

5_minute_monster_meals.description: This may seem obvious, but create children's cookbook with 5 minute or 15 minute recipes.  This way they know it will be quick, you won't lose their attention, and they can discover the joy of cooking easily which makes moving up to longer and harder recipes into an organic process.
5_minute_monster_meals.creator: 51c3fe097e073c0c21e9eaf9e0320ede

comments.text: Five to 15 minutes can definitely work -- especially if the book is broken down with advance prep. A parent's guide or section could focus on how to achieve engagement in the kitchen for the different aged children. Families with with a variety of ages could have different tasks for each -- and perhaps even the parent that doesn't cook often. The book should not just focus on the food (but should primarily) but should also provide tools to help them notice what is interesting in their children. presentation might be more interesting to my daughter versus my son who loves to knead whole wheat pizza dough!
This is a great idea and goes some way towards making good food 'cool' that has been suggested by some others for counteracting ads & marketing from big corporations.

One question: how much healthy food is able to be prepared in 5-10 minutes, and by children? 
Still, this is an excellent idea - though I think the food revolution has to start with the parents, and work its way down to the kids.

5_minute_monster_meals.title: 5 Minute Monster Meals

the_good_food_vending_quota.description: Vending machines are required to allocate a percentage of space for locally produced and sourced produce and snacks.
the_good_food_vending_quota.creator: 4b75751e170e00f56886726c3f46eecd

comments.text: Good idea but how to promote the healthier food copmared to the highly advertised 'junk food" ? If it is just for taste, it will not drive change - how to make this food more attractive will be key.

There are so many snacks that have popped up recently that use local ingredients and are natural - I recently had a rather delicious granola bar: http://www.shandiz.ca/shandiz-products.php?category=1
I actually don't think it's fair to have these products competing against the awful chocolate bars and shiny crisps packets. I say get the schools on board to regulate what the vending machine company provides and entirely ban GMO and sugar-filled junk-food options. It may seem harsh, but these are the small things that can be done to change behavioural habits in an environment where parents are watching over their child's every bite.

The real problem seems to be figuring out why, when presented with healthy snacks and unhealthy snacks at equal convenience and price, we are still more likely to pick the unhealthy snack, despite knowing the 'consequences'.Nice idea though.

Interesting thoughts on school boards and vending machines. In addition, whole vending machines could be "healthy": http://www.schools.freshvending.com/, http://www.vendingmachinesschools.com/, http://www.vendnatural.com/, http://www.healthyvending.com

the_good_food_vending_quota.title: The Good Food Vending Quota

comments.text: Exactly!  What is needed is a combination of tools for education AND social "buy in".

flavor_notes...high_mid_low_and_round.description: Flavor profiles can be constructed when you assigned them to a simple categorization scheme. Kid's education (especially games) that encourage health eating need to include learning about flavor. Having a simple scheme like High. Mid. Low. Round notes gives pieces that can be rearranged, combined and understood better.
flavor_notes...high_mid_low_and_round.creator: 9add5c1d0463a808d4b4415f808363ce

comments.text: Also interesting in terms of what needs to be added to veggies to make them "rounder", and thus tastier for kids?

That's a great idea. One that promotes awareness of what they are eating. In a classroom situation it'd go down a treat, as they could concentrate... no TV!
On a side note, many adults abhor certain vegetables, usually because of childhood experiences. e.g. over-boiled broccoli.

flavor_notes...high_mid_low_and_round.title: Flavor Notes...High, Mid, Low, and Round

parents_are_the_very_first_kids_heroes._.description: Parents are the very first kids' heroes. They should be the first to know the benefit of healthy foods in general. They should be the first to eat healthy food. And they should do it together with their kids by sharing the same table
parents_are_the_very_first_kids_heroes._.creator: fccb92826fc5cf5f54084f6e16707794

comments.text: I fear that reshaping adult eating habits might be a bigger challenge than raising the awareness of the rewards of fresh foods for kids. Adult-eating habits have already been formed, from their own set of values growing up, and habits are extremely difficult to change, especially bad ones. I'm not saying that parents with bad eating habits are a lost cause, but taking parents on is a challenge of its own. I do see the importance of having parents involved, because children with parents who eat healthy will more likely eat healthy. It's something we pass on, from one generation to another. Hopefully, the rad idea we come up with from this challenge will shed light on and be a possible solution to the, do parents or kids come first? question.

I agree that parents have a huge portion of the responsibility in leading their kids.in eating healthfully.  But the tough part is that 'telling' parents that teaching their children about healthy food is easy and getting them to actually do it are very different things.  The sad truth is that many parents have the same bad eating habits as kids.  Cheap fast food, advertising, cultural inertia, etc. are powerful behavior shapers.  So to me the question is how to focus on reshaping parent's eating habits.  And if that can be accomplished, their kids will more easily follow.  The trick is that the solution should be easier, cheaper and more compelling than fast food. Which is a tough one.  Good thoughts - thanks!

parents_are_the_very_first_kids_heroes._.title: Parents are the very first kids' heroes. They are the first to instruct

the_best_cooking_toy_easy_bake.description: One of the best toys ever is one that truly inspires kids to make easy and fun recipes, also improves relationships betwen the parents. How cool is that ?
the_best_cooking_toy_easy_bake.creator: 0de49c0126f91dc66a6c9edc3196d973

comments.text: thanks !! really smarth your commer, very constructive ! I also came up with these problems ... the thing with the sweet desserts and stuff... but here is an alternative for the boys ... but I tink it is not that very popularhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NCxbE85h7Gk

Easy-Bake is an interesting concept.  Kid-sizing and packaging the equipment, ingredients and instructions make the 'in the kitchen' experience an easy one.  And lots of women recount fond memories of Easy-Baking as a kid.  The bummer is that it has been traditionally seen as a girl toy instead of a toy used by all kids.  Also, it is a product that pretty much makes only sweet dessert-type things.  Might be interesting if the Easy-Bake brand could be pushed into more healthy directions and into other process categories.  Could there be an 'Easy-Saut'?  Or, speaking of healthy, an 'Easy-Steam'?  Interesting idea and good to think about kid targeted things that have worked in the past.  Thanks!

the_best_cooking_toy_easy_bake.title: The best cooking toy? Easy Bake

choice_architecture_for_grocery_shooping.description:
This concept is aimed at integrating food + lifestyle choices that create a beneficial situation for parents and their children each time they go shopping. 

What if a parent’s purchase of healthy foods enabled them to claim a discounts and benefits for their child's extra curricular activity?  A mother would have incentive to purchase more healthy foods that would in turn mean a subsidy to their child's swimming lesson or tennis court hire.
choice_architecture_for_grocery_shooping.creator: bac1161f308485387a307b2bfce571eb
choice_architecture_for_grocery_shooping.title: Choice Architecture for grocery shooping  "Healthy Groceries = MORE Active time for Children"

hungry_hungry_hannah_henry_doll.description:
Keep it simple. Plug into what kids do already: Play and Caretake. Kids play with their toys but they also mind their toys. They do this in obvious ways (typically: boy and girl tots and older girls) such as putting a toy to bed, but also in less obvious ways (typically: older boys) such as placing best friend toy cars together to keep each other company. So, create a charming doll or an animal that comes with a plate and food choices so that it is the child's role to create daily meals for the toy. The toy then will give feedback based on the nutritional content in the meal. The feedback will be concrete--"Too much food: I'm too tired to play now" or "Yummy almonds. I think they make my heart healthy, do they?  Though geared for younger kids there is no need to shy away from specific nutritional info, instead the feedback can help kids become familiar with food and the body--"Milk is full of protein. Thanks for helping my bones grow stronger." (off the top of my head examples, btw).
This toy is developmentally appropriate and it lays the groundwork for understanding and feeling invested in more involved and complicated food issues when the child is older.  It is biologically hard for young kids to make good choices. They do not yet have the brain development. But they CAN make good choices for others (because it is not caught up with their own needs and desires) and in doing so in a very simple format they are familiar with and can play with straight out of the box they can practice good choices and learn what choices are good and not so good, and more so, they can tie what we eat to a specific nutritional consequence. The goal is: children will be equipped with the knowledge to make smart food choices when their brains develop the higher thinking and future thinking as well as the delayed gratification we adults all rely on to make good choices.  
Really, the easiest way to encourage children to choose fresh over processed foods is to make sure the fresh foods taste better than the processed foods. Unfortunately, there is a massively powerful industry trying to do exactly the opposite by fooling our senses and taking advantage of our hurried society. My concept offers another way to encourage children to choose fresh foods: on one level the toy offers knowledge about food but on another perhaps more important level it  allows for a positive, fun association with food, health and the notion of making food choices and how important the consequences of food choice are (while tapping into a desire to care and take care of) thus laying the groundwork for mindful eating and good food choices (i.e., nutritionally sound fresh foods). Because the child is in control  and making decisions there is no off-putting didactic element.
hungry_hungry_hannah_henry_doll.creator: bb5494388035301b6f2edf3feb4ef65a

comments.text: This is a great idea, helping reinforce healthy habits through an existing mode of play.  On the high-tech end, using RFID technology would allow the doll to respond to particular food brought to its mouth.

hungry_hungry_hannah_henry_doll.title: Hungry Hungry Hannah/ Henry Doll

protect_our_own_environment.description: Let's protect grocery stores like we do wetlands.  No fast food chains within a mile!  The endangered species we're trying to conserve is ourselves.  How can we be sustainable in a polluted environment?
protect_our_own_environment.creator: 43e52827375398b116b7688f3291844f

comments.text: ...or better yet, no fast food within three miles of schools.

protect_our_own_environment.title: protect our own environment

student_run_farmers_market_.description:
Create a student run farmer's market within high schools. This can be organized as part of a economics club or perhaps a completely separate club. The idea is that a set of students (led by a teacher/sponsor) will be responsible for creating a farmer's market (on school property during the school week and potentially off school property on weekends). Students will be responsible for:

- Sourcing produce from local farmers
- Learning about each product they sell 
- Selling fresh produce at their schools "Farmer's Market"
student_run_farmers_market_.creator: b5bb0cac9ada925a5e985558e6f5bff0

comments.text: This idea is interesting. It would be even more if all students learnt how to grow vegetables,  growing seasons,etc. Local farmers could perhaps sponsor a lesson per week for that school participating in the scheme and that would increase interaction between the school and producers, as well as teach seasonality. Children are used to finding any kind of vegetables in the supermarket all year round, but they don't realize how much flavor  is missing from the real thing!

I love this concept! Yes, I agree with Matt - if some kids also got the opportunity to be producers that would be amazing. But learning how to source produce is also a valuable lesson (future business skills!) -- it ties in nicely with my concept, "Seed to Tray Education" where kids source and purchase and cook their own school lunches. If you added a farmers' market concept on that, they could actually develop a profit model too!
Great concept.  To build on it, what if some or all of the produce/food was grown/made at the school by the children?
I really like this idea.  It feels like something which could become a real movement, with active learning by participants and customers alike.

I was telling someone about this and we began discussing some other ideas: This partly builds on the CSA concept, but one of the activities that students can take on could be a subscription program. During parts of the year, as produce becomes available, students can assemble baskets and deliver produce to people's home or for pickup each week. 
Perhaps this just happens a couple of times a year for a couple week period, but this gives the students some more flexibility in developing their market as well as it requires them learn more about what produce will be available when and how it can be packaged together. 
Other school clubs could work with the Farmer's Market to use the subscription program as a fundraiser too.
Great idea!!!
Thanks again for all of the great comments and ideas. I added these to the project description in a summary format.
Great set of ideas building on this. Who wants to make it happen!!!

My concept ( http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/concepting/introducing-the-no-bake-sale-a-farmer-s-market-fundaiser-run-by-the-whole-school/ )was similar to this, and includes hands on food production for students of all ages, from growing food in a school farm/garden, growing sprouts, making simple trail mixes with some local foods, and so on, as well as selling the food.  And it can be scaled all the way down to a simple once in a while No-Bake Sale, that can be done in the school, as a way to encourage kids to buy healthy, very local! food for lunch. :-)

YES YES YES. Excellent. 
What I would also suggest is a "pilot" system where younger kids are given the opportunity to spend some time around the farmers' market where their older, high school peers will be running the show. That way, they'll be able to get introduced to the better eating habits/entrepreneurship that the older kids are doing.  These habits have to be ingrained early, and I'm afraid that high school might be too late. 
I also highly agree with the interdisciplinary approach that Thao suggested below.

I also love the entrepreneurship aspect of the concept . It's a great twist on the lemonade stand, learning and running a business.
Perhaps we can bring members of different school clubs, hence different social circles into the picture. You stated there will multiple moving parts; many tasks to carry out, and different functions to perform (e.g. finance, marketing), is there a way we can encourage members of the food club, students from the art class, or students in the computer lab to all come together and bring this concept to life? - this way, we'll have an interdisciplinary team running the show. Every member will be able to carry out new functions, and learn new skills.

Great concept. HEAL in Half Moon Bay runs a farmers' market with 3rd and 4th graders. We did the same at Full Circle Farm (www.fullcirclesunnyvale.org) with at-risk youth ages 16-24. It was rewarding and life changing for many - 2 ended up employed after the program in agriculture! 
Also, many schools are becoming CSA drop-off sites - a small portion of the share goes to the school, making it a school fundraiser as well. I've always thought it would be awesome if the CSA baskets could be from produce grown at the school - or sold directly at a farmstand - instant school fundraiser! 
Liz
My concept: http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/concepting/seed-to-tray-education-in-public-schools/
Thanks Meena. I think this idea could really be developed.
Love how this concept includes encouragement of entrepreneurship.

student_run_farmers_market_.title: Student Run Farmers Market

food_tunes.description:
Food Tunes!  The key to nurturing a culture of kids who make good choices is EDUCATION.   

Think Schoolhouse Rock meets Radio Disney.  Music is the best tool to educate, engage, and entice families with healthy food choices, simple fresh recipes, and general health and welness education. 

Songs with fun music videos can ride the popular cultural success of shows like GLEE, American Idol, etc. and can reach the general public. Catchy songs teach families how to: identify, taste, cook/prepare, eat, and enjoy.  I imagine hit titles like...'Homesick for Homemade Bread', "Fresh and Solo", "2 Good not 2 Eat".   Use spots during primetime PSA's, favorite cartoons, Seseme Street, previews in movie theaters, and more , to get the Food Revolution message out to the masses.
food_tunes.creator: 0ba2df6ba17ee2a0694746e7314e0f9e

comments.text: Fun video!  This idea has a lot of potential.  Those Schoolhouse Rock lessons still rattle around in my head.

open_kids.description: You always learn more when you are a teacher. Why not involve kids in teaching each other? Open KIDS would be a kindergarden/school programme in which schools would participate and kids would be the active participants under a supervision of their trained tutors and an expert - Jamie Oliver?/ They would all be thinking together how to change their own habits, how to teach each other about healthy food and about better/ healthier/ more interesting cooking.
open_kids.creator: f663744062e5876058493e584f1dbd3e

comments.text: Hey, thx Aaron! I imagine this as a bit of tutoring from the teacher and from Jamie or from other expert. First - some classes with main tips concerning eating, diet, healty cooking etc... second - creative thinking/evaluating the ideas for healtier eating and cooking in an online global community. This is just a general idea of linking school with after-school community so each kid's local inspiration is used globally and it inspires other kids: a. to find something healthy around them, to try it and to share it with the others b. to try or to cook something new and healthy that came as an inspiration from the others.
Apologies for the post uploading thee times  - slow Internet my end!

This idea is good, but my reservation about it - is that it lacks the leap between the thinking and delivering of information, and then actually acting on that information. We need something to bridge this gap.
A possible solution would be that the child who is teaching should give an interesting and educational task that the students must take home and deliver in someway or another to their parents. (Children love teaching their parents a thing or too!)
That way though thoughts and ideas can be translated into some sort of memorable action.
Other benefits of making a child assume the role of the teacher might be-   It would help to overcome nerves-   It would become something everyone in the class would do, so its not about people being picked out. -   It would give the child an idea of what a teachers have to go through, and so hopefully they child would begin to have more respect for the teacher.

Using an edutainment interface is a nice way to teach the basics, not only to kids but to other ages as well. This concept can be easily scaled.

Thanks for the comment! I think that if they are given a task from their tutors at school to research what healthy food and eating is about and to tell others about it, they will be able to get some knowledge and to give advise. It is not about them knowing, but learning under a right supervision and with the evaluation.

At that age group, often kids do not have the requisite understanding to be able to make the right choices, or give the right advice.  
Overall, I think this idea is trying to build on a good foundation, but lacks depth.

rotherfield_primary_school_edible_garden.description: I was cycling to work last week, past Rotherfield Primary School and heard a teacher saying "ooh look the carrots are doing well". I also noticed a few weeks ago, another school in Stoke Newington that have a wonderful new vegetable garden that's been planted in boxes right on top of the tarmac-ed playground. This seems to be the beginning of something. I wonder how the kids are interacting with it?
rotherfield_primary_school_edible_garden.creator: 49d75f861bdf99e6736c5f3f85e41b62

comments.text: It's incredible what a garden can teach kids without even trying. I am the children's director at a church and we are growing an outreach garden so when the produce is ready the kids are going to give it to the children from low income families that come to our food pantry. Not only are they learning how to grow their own food but  we are teaching the kids how important all of the nutrients in this food are and why it's so important that every kid have some. I am using ideas from the Green VBS curriculum from sparkhouse and the kids are so excited about actually donating their veggies to kids that need them. This is especially important because more kids from low income families are experiencing diabetes, obesity and improper brain development now more than ever. Don't be afraid to start small and "grow." We have three raised bed gardens right now and hopefully we'll do more when we plant in January.

Indeed. There could be a class a period each day for each class to tend to the garden in some way - this would mean the garden is constantly looked after, and the kids would gain a greater connection with the food they're growing!
...Though that might require a sizeable garden on second thoughts...

As well as it being used in their own cafeteria, why not integrate the whole process from seed to stomach and make the kids a part of the whole process. once a week they could have a class before lunch and gather with to cooks and take part in preparing the food for themselves and their classmates, maximizing their connection with the produce and educating those that may not have the opportunity at home to partake in the cooking process.

Maybe the food grown in the garden could be used in the cafeteria so they can compare the taste and quality of local hand-grown produce to fast foods. Most people can probably go through most of a lifetime now without eating something like this because their parents don't buy any and therefore they don't either; so they never know what they're missing.

Maybe the food grown in the garden could be used in the cafeteria so they can compare the taste and quality of local hand-grown produce to fast foods. Most people can probably go through most of a lifetime now without eating something like this because their parents don't buy any and therefore they don't either; so they never know what they're missing.
Love this capture Jessie! and, in the middle of London - who would have imagined we can create such a meaningful connection. Lovely!
sorry meant to say 'can't emphasize enough how much actually growing the food changes your relationship to it'

as someone who's just built an urban victory garden, I can't say how much actually growing the food changes your connection to it. we've just installed a sizeable rooftop vegetable garden at IDEO Chicago and the more I walk around my neighborhood, the more I am seeing schools adopt this kind of approach - dedicating what used to be blacktop to increasingly large community gardens. really inspiring!

rotherfield_primary_school_edible_garden.title: Rotherfield Primary School edible garden

Whatever we use we get instructions, we get lessons, we train, and we are educated about how that works and how to maintain it for best performance and long lasting.

About ourselves we know nothing or so much wrong, rarely and often lately enough. By simplifying basic principles how we function and how to properly maintain ourselves communication could be established on all age levels.

healthy_grocery_receipts_game_rewards_pr.description: After I checkout at supermarkets, I often scan the receipt totals to see how much I've saved vs. spent. It's becomes a game to maximize this %, and I've even had a friend call just to report a "high score". Imagine if grocery receipts included simple pie charts of the % (by weight) bought in each food group. If you’re within the advised range, you receive a discount on your next or current purchase. With loyalty cards, you can even track over time & provide additional rewards for say “4 weeks of health”.
healthy_grocery_receipts_game_rewards_pr.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Great idea. Nice subtle reminder of the healthy choices. Might run into resistance with criteria from the food suppliers.

I think this is a good idea because I've see this concept successfully used in practice. It is used by some of the public service programs at the MN Dept. of Transportation. A person can track online what kind of transportation they used that day (bus, bicycle, train, foot, etc.) and then the website gives them  a rough idea of how much people reduced their carbon foot print. They have a weekly drawing of a gift card for all that participate.

It's a nifty idea to use game points as an incentive, but it's probably better to use only things like fresh fruits and vegetables, since not everyone eats the same kinds of things, and not everyone agrees on the proportions.  For example, I eat almost no grains, (maybe once a week or less) and I'm much healthier because of it.
Also it would probably be better to have this run by an independent non-profit rather than a for-profit supermarket, since there might be major conflicts-of-interest. :-)
In Whole Foods these days, you might be able to pick up a card that lists the Aggregate Nutrient Density Index (ANDI) ratings of foods, telling you the top 10 foods in each department.  These scores could be incorporated into this game pretty easily, since they are already given a score!  For example: 
Kale  1000 points!
Orange  only 109 points
Whole wheat bread  only 25 points
Olive oil  a mere 9 points
And I believe the top 10 foods are kale, collards, bok choy, spinach, brussels sprouts, arugula, cabbage, romaine lettuce, broccoli, and cauliflower.  So you could also include fun recipes on the game score, so that people could find new ways of eating some of these not so popular foods.

I LOVE this idea. Safeway is doing something along those lines. I think one of the biggest challenges is that parents don't know how to be healthy, so building a program with a supermarket is ideal. That is the place you go to for food, period, so turning the shopping experience into a learning opportunity is fantastic.I wonder if this could turn into a month-long movement for nutrition education where we can partner with select supermarkets to provide parents and kids with workshops, have nutritional counselors available at the stores, provide incentives for buying fresh produce, etc.

iii. influence their ENVIRONMENTGo to the teaching colleges and universities and influence them -- show these budding teachers and principals and superintendents the impact of healthy food in schools and the impact on their students. ii. influence the MARKETWhat about a graphical scale that measure cost per "unit of nutrition" for the shoppers or parents? Something that visibly makes evident the "cost of cheap food". Some groceries have a "cost per unit weight", this is a similar idea.
