building_on_the_zones_on_plates_idea.description: This is a great idea and an easy way to influence healthy portions during every meal. If you could stock cafeterias with these, kids would definitely think more (either consciously or subconsciously) about which foods they were filling their plates with in the buffet line. BUT we should also include encouraging, poignant, or stimulating TEXT on top of the color coated sections, and utilize the RIM of the plate and/or the entire cafeteria tray.
building_on_the_zones_on_plates_idea.creator: 6837d41ff9a69f9b15bc555d86b3f065

comments.text:
I like this idea, but I guess I'd go much simpler and maybe incorporate humour?  Picture of local farmer  "Eat fresh food, my cows worked hard for it."  Or pictures:   one of a pile of some fried battered product made into a 'brick' wall.  The other a picture of carrots, celery or other produce made into a 'brick' wall.  The text could be "Every time you eat, you're building your brain.  Use the best quality materials."
For most kids it's not like they'll eat fresh food one lunch time and say "wow I feel so much better".  In fact, they'll probably feed worse, because they haven't had their sugar/salt/fat fix.  So I think the other plate or tray message should be something like "take one less white thing and one more green thing for lunch."

Which information should be on the plate? Healthy fats, phytonutrients in vegetables, antioxidants in fruit, etc. all have tons of disease preventative qualities, but kids in elementary school, high school, and even college are rarely thinking about their risk of Alzheimer's or Cardiovascular disease. (One exception is diabetes. It could be felicitous to include info about the risks and recent proliferation of type 2 diabetes). Kids think impulsively, and are swayed more by short term prospects. The plates should include the SHORT TERM BENFITS of eating healthy. Higher physical energy, healthier muscle contraction, mental alertness, short-term memory, fat loss, etc. And SPECIFICALLY which foods effect each benefit. Also, info regarding short term DAMAGE of unhealthy foods, like the mental and physical fatigue caused by blood-sugar spikes. Along with these should be specific, tangible, real-life examples, like how a serving of broccoli could help you make that winning free throw, or ace that math test.

One Example: ON THE RIM: "Are you ever tired after a meal? You shouldnt be!" (Quick digesting carbs with high-glycemic indexes are ubiquitous in cafeterias. Kids often suffer mental and physical "Crashes" after eating due to bloodsugar spikes.) ON THE PLATE: Examples they could relate to, and the "invisible" consequences of high-glycemic foods, like fat in your arteries and type 2 diabetes.ON THE TRAY: List of methods/foods for improving your insulin resistance, including easy, available, alternatives for tomorrow's lunch.

building_on_the_zones_on_plates_idea.title: Building on the "Zones on Plates" idea

comments.text: great inspiration.  your son is brilliant!  "Did it grow in dirt?"  brilliant!
Pam! I can't believe it took me so long to get on here! AWESOME place, and so great that you are putting Full Circle Farm out there as a model. Hurray!

In Brazil it is possible to find some farmers who allow visitors inside their properties so one can harvest fruits and vegetables on spot, paying accordingly to the harvested items. Sort of an open-air organic mall. It is different than growing your own food and certainly does not have the "common" appeal but it is an alternative for those who don't have neither access to a common farm nor a space to convert.
Lovely picture, by the way!
Thanks, Lita and Thao, for linking to other folks working on this. And, yep, Jorge... while I love the convenience of pre-washed, it's great for kids to know that the good stuff grows in dirt!
A great idea! And it seems to appear everytime someone has a plan to make better cities (http://www.terreform.org/); it can be done from scratch as well as applied to existing places. Congrats!

I passed this information along to someone else in an earlier post who had a similar idea, and I just wanted to drop it off here too: I met someone awhile ago who is pursuing the concept of urban farming in a project he calls "downtown farm". He uses his own home in Livermore to promote the idea. The premise is a farm in your backyard, and getting your local community/neighborhood to get involved. He keeps a blog about his work:http://downtownfarm.wordpress.com/ I know we can build it on this idea!
I totally agree. I was growing veg in school as a kid, and I still don't trust superclean, shiny packed vegs in supermarkets. Good point

Thanks, Brett and Matt. I love the vision of neighborhood farm as standard land-use. Ours was converted from a modestly-used field next to the middle school. Now the middle-schoolers can take farm and fresh-cooking workshops, plus produce from the farm goes right to their school lunches. Win all around!

Yes. I'm a firm believer that communal farming may very well be the wave of the future. It teaches kids to grow things naturally, doesn't involve the use of industrial pesticides, fosters inter-community engagement, and also promotes self-sufficiency. It's a nice catch-all to our modern society's ills. 
Excellent idea - I've had it bouncing in my head for quite a long time!
What a great concept...a neighborhood farm! What if all communities had not only had parks, schools, and playgrounds, but also a farm. Love it!

eat_like_an_animal_birthday_party_theme.description:
Eat Like an Animal Birthday Party Theme

Provide /make animal masks for the guests to wear throughout the party.
Play games of reaching and pretending to be the chosen animals.
Provide different menues based on animals chosen when RSVPing for the party

Let the goody bags continue the message with a small recipe book and animal mementos for each child's parent, to spread the message.


The phrase "Eat like an animal" inspires kids to eat leafy greens and vegetables, but many don't know how.
If the concept is too open-ended, parents may meet with unreasonable demands from their kids, or have difficulty obtaining the required foods, but given limited choices, kids can gain experience eating unusual things in a group atmosphere, which helps over-ride fear, as multiple people are trying new things together.
This means that only one parent has to do anything new or different, but many children get the opportunity for new taste experiences.
eat_like_an_animal_birthday_party_theme.creator: a69f5bebc9ea4c11ebc39685441c785f

comments.text: Going beyond the birthday theme, I think it's fun to look at the animal world for inspiration on how to eat. Animals eat natural food, like we should be eating.  If you eat a balanced diet of grains, vegetables, fruit and meat, you basically eat like a bird, giraffe, monkey and tiger.  Maybe that is a fun way of talking to kids about nutrition - have kids pick their favorite animals that eat from each food group to make up their own eating ID.  They could also get this communication in unusual places like Zoos and nature documentaries.

comments.text: A great Idea although I'm not too sure who would agree to which foods get the labels on this one, and who ever that was would their decsion be correct for the many!!

When I was a kid, I LOVED getting certain cereals because of the free toys I could get if we accumulated enough Proofs of Purchase. I think many kids were the same way. What if the stickers could get kids actual prizes (or virtual prizes)?
teaching kids to notice, read and understand food labels is a great start to healthier eating habits. there's a seed of an idea here!

Love the simplicity of the idea. Regretfully, I don't know how the governance of the labels would work. Who gets to decide which products get the label?  The "organic" food movement has the same problem.

Nice one! And I wonder if this could be extended so that you could collect the stickers onto a sheet and when you had a certain amount you got a free article of fruit, etc. To create an ongoing incentive to make Better Choices.

I especially like the idea of emphasizing the everyday and often low-key decisions. Changing habit in both parents and kids seems to me to be the key and people are more likely to change small habits frequently rather than big habits immediately. Its a bit like changing your light bulbs to the energy efficient versions; this helps install a change in mind set about the problem but is actually quite easy to do :-)
This is a brilliant idea - it renders often confusing nutritional labels more accessible and reinforces positive benefits of healthy foods.  Food packaging designers and companies take note!

comments.text: This is a great idea. And so many ways to expand it as well. Would it be an idea to add a 'tell your friends' option, if a child has eaten something healthy that he really liked, she could recommend her friends in the game about it. Sort of positive peer-pressure.Another idea that popped up while reading this concept is a quest to come up with a original recipe for a fresh meal. You could maybe even make that interesting by awarding this with a mention on Jamie Oliver's tv-show. That in every episode, one original meal and the creators are mentioned?Or in-game rewards, like badges, for food tried, healthier eating habits (based on the recording phase) etcetera. Would that be an idea?

Thanks for the feedback. Daylin, I think a shared meal or potluck is a perfect example of what a "quest" could include. The important thing would be for the quests to be fun, and somewhat competitive - the more kids perceive this as a "game," and an activity they're doing by their own choice, the more they'll want to take part. So, perhaps a potluck as one of the final "quests" - perhaps a whole class participates in this game over the course of a few months - could include some sort of competitive element, and if sponsorship or food subsidies could be included, that could incentivize parents to take part as well. Vincent - yes, we envision this game to be instituted through an existing educational curriculum, with the hope that built-in rewards and mild competition will encourage kids to engage with the game on their own and at home as well.
Love the "edutainment" aspect. As Marshall McLuhan said: Anyone who tries to make a distinction between education and entertainment doesn't know the first thing about either.
Is there a way you can make the quests more collaborative (with their peers)? Kind of like a progressive dinner, or pot-luck...the full meal quest requires collaboration.
Interesting approach. How would you envision children 1st finding out about/starting on the game. Through school?

watcha_eatin_.title: Watcha' Eatin'?

branding_vegetables.description: A savvy company could capitalize on the kid market for the branding of specialized and rare vegetables.
branding_vegetables.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: I know this is an older post, but I thought I'd add that my firm has done a fair amount of testing/research on this topic. Generally, consumers have found branding = industrial. Industrial vegetables are not very appetizing.Obviously, this view can be changed, but it will not be simple.

Jane, I agree with you in that provenance is a type of branding in the produce aisle. Georgia Peaches, New Jersey Tomatoes, Florida Oranges, etc.  and Dominik, I completely agree with you in that fruit and vegetables, in their natural state and cooked correctly can be wonderful.  But to your point about changing tastes and colors - people have been adjusting fruits and vegetables for centuries.  Fuji apples are a hybrid of Red Delicious and Virginia Ralls Genet apples.  Tangelos are a hybrid of tangerines and pomelos.  A portobello mushroom tastes 'meatier' than a crimini because it has been allowed to mature further.  There are many examples.  Really my point is more about brand names.  And with brand names comes advertising dollars.  Smucker's advertises it's jelly products.  But what if Smucker's developed an actual strain of grape hybrid?  There would be green grapes, red grapes, Smucker's grapes...  Maybe they are a slightly different color or a brighter flavor (or sweeter, or more tangy, whatever). But they are different.  Then there might be advertisements for not only Smucker's Grape Jelly but also Smucker's Grapes! Which might catch kid's attention.  Which is my main point.  Brand advertising dollars directed at the fruits and vegetables aisle might be a way to entice kids to make healthy eating choices.Thanks for your comments!

Baby carrots are another great example of reinvigorating and branding an existing product.  They are still the same plain old orange carrots, but people like them more (as shown through their spending habits).  In fact, that's the genius of them, they started out as the leftover/irregular parts of "real carrots" but packaging baby carrots in bags (since they are so small) lent itself to the opportunity for "brand name" carrots and in turn higher profitability for the companies and (in a roundabout way) increased social welfare by healthier eating. Its a win win.

I would agree more with Jane's thoughts on the idea of provenance.
I would be very concerned about changing the tastes and colour of fruit and veg. Kids should learn to enjoy and appreciate fruit and veg in its natural state. 
Broccoli cooked in the right way, or with complimentary veg / meat / fish / pasta, can be amazing.

This raises a bunch more questions for me: Perhaps branding here could be another way of thinking about provenancehow we care where this mushroom came from, and who picked it. As someone who, as soon as I get it home, picks off all the labels stuck on fruit that I've bought (to preserve the illusion that it came (straight) from a treeI do care where it came from) I wonder how branding fruit and veg might better connect it with its natural origin?

branding_vegetables.title: Branding Vegetables!

comments.text: I like this a lot! What a simple idea of turing a fun, easy and popular game into a powerful shift in mindset!

Hi Chris, just suggested an additional use for your Trump Cards concept through one of my concepts (http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/concepting/color-coded-lunchbox-cafeteria-tray/) and am linking to yours as inspiration. Thought you might be interested.

Hi guys, thanks for the positive feedback!  Jaime, great idea regarding making the game more addictive. We could easily implement a solution without any need to extend the game - as the user wins more games, they 'level up' which opens up more of the power cards making the available to the deck. Once a card is won, it goes into the stickerbook collection and therefore a player would need to have a high player level in order to both access and win the entire collection. Much like how the old 'shiny' badges in the Panini football stickerbook collections kept children buying more packs of stickers.

This is a great idea!!! Cool job!  There should be several ways to make the game more "addictive"; commercially successful card games tend to boost competition spirit and keep people interested... this is essential since kids go from one thing to another in no time. Once again GJ!
Wow Chris. Great, fleshed out idea. I collected various cards/games when I was a kid & could definitely see this catching on!

comments.text: Ha! Good thoughts!  I love the Popeye Spinach game in your photos.  I just wrote a comment about Popeye for this Inspiration http://tinyurl.com/368uj8w  My point there was about money.  And here it is similar.  Why did Popeye love spinach? Because he just did. The Spinach Growers Association didn't pay him to love it. It was part of who he was.  I think in contrast, today's characters are more geared toward earning money through product endorsement.  They won't lift a drawn finger without getting paid first.  I think your inspiration leads to the need for the creation of more children's characters that promote healthy food and lifestyle choices.  The only issue is how to make it 'cool' enough that kids will like it.  And now that I am thinking about cartoon characters... I wonder if the cheese industry saw an increase in cheese consumption with the growth in popularity of Wallace and Gromit.  Not to mention that Sponge Bob looks a bit like cheese...

children_food_ambassadors.description: Instead of adults telling children what's good for them, why not train children to function as food ambassadors?
children_food_ambassadors.creator: 8ff066618ab46c3e5bfd0153bf43c99b

comments.text:
We did this in, wait for it, 1979. My grade six teacher was concerned about the school canteen selling a lot of junk food. (not sure if that term was around then lol)
A boy and girl from our class went to each class in the primary school to ask the classes what foods they thought were an issue. It was done, chiefly under banner of dental health, ie removing sugars from the diet of youngsters. When we ran out of suggests we gave a few back to the class.
Then 5 of us presented one night to the school board and campaigned to remove all sugary items from the canteen. We won the day.
The tuck shop mum who managed it was furious. She continued to sell bags of mixed sweets under the counter to those not on her blacklist (like me and the others who presented to council!).
Obesity wasn't such an issue then but one girls mother filled her lunch box with sweets in a pathetic (and tragic) attempt to win her daughter some friends. People just used her daughter rather be-friend her. 
She was big in primary. I saw her several years later attempting to board a school bus, she was so obese she had to board the bus stairs sideways. Her mother should have been publicly whipped (just kidding but what a thing to do to your child). Apparently it's normal. I saw a mother in US feed M&Ms to a baby during an interview about homelessness. Homeless and education-less is a bad state of affairs for the greatest nation on earth.

Great idea! I know of another project where kids help each other: in austrian schools, kids of all ages are trained to mediate between classmates in case of conflicts. If kids can implement that, they will implement your idea at ease.

This is a great idea in that involving kids on every level from, cultivation to prep to evangelism can only lead to greater knowledge and respect for healthy food.  I would be interested to see how the curriculum or program develops and what knowledge kids would be sharing with their peers that would make a lasting impression.  Some great opportunities there.  Thanks for the concept!
View the TED.com video on 'how to start a movement'. Get one kid in each social group who is a leader / persuader to champion good food causes and practices. More will follow ... it's human nature!
I think that you cannot overestimate the importance of children learning through collaboration. Lovely idea.

children_food_ambassadors.title: Children Food Ambassadors

I do agree that changing kids attitude toward fresh food starts with parents, but on the other hand it doesn't have to be through showing the costs of bad habits and unhealthy consumtion. 
It can be a through a constructive behavioural change, there's enough good on fresh food: it's cheaper, healthier, less polluting, natural...
And on that last point that its been discussed, I have to say that maybe organic sourced vegetables are a bit more expensive, but using standard budget-range vegetables will always be better, healthier and cheaper than processed meats, prepared meals and other unhealthy kinds of food that are often chosen because of the convenience (I'd even say convenience is often chosen first over price in an average family).
My question to you is this, then: if the parents can't afford the healthy food, then how is it going to get into their kids' mouths?

totally agree with you that we should edudate parents because they are the one preparing the food for children; however, not every family can afford organic and natural foods. when they are struggleing with their housing and job, the healthy food would never be their priority.

japanese_future_of_food_video.description: This is an awesome vid made by the japanese ministry of agriculture which encourages people to eat healthy, local, traditional food for the health of the people, country and environment. comments.text: Love the video!  (not to mention that I am a sucker for axonometric cartoon worlds)  It is a great way to present a lot of information logically, memorably and in a relatively short amount of time.  However, a couple issues were raised with me after watching it.  First, I wonder if the information is simplified a little too much.  For example, people's expanding girth is attributed to increased consumption of meat, oil, etc.  But is it only that?  Nothing is mentioned of portion size, increased amounts of processed foods, globalized marketing, etc.  Too much information can become confusing and boring but the danger here is that simplifying the causal explanation can maybe distort the solution.  Secondly, the positive message of the video is to eat more locally.  But it seems as though the subtext here feels a bit nationalistic.  Traditional local foods (rice, fish, etc.) are touted as good but outside foods from other countries (meat, oil, etc.) are seen as bad.  Japanese flags are put on foods to mark 'good' while foreign flags suggest 'cheap, bulk' infiltration.  Is the video suggesting that increased nationalism is the answer?  Is this subtle isolationism?  But the anomaly here is the information that 40% of the ingredients of traditional Tempura Soba is imported.  So does this mean that traditional eating habits, as good as they may be, also hold flaws?  Should Tempura Soba be removed from Japanese menus?  I am not sure that just because something can't be grown in a country suggests that it shouldn't be eaten by that country's population.  Maybe a more subtle argument, or different logic approach may be needed.  But the video is definitely great as a way to spur conversation about finding solutions.  Thanks for the idea!

wow... very well done and educational - thanks for posting it. but you have to wonder about the impact a video like this actually have on worker class consumers - if it was broadcast on public television for instance. first off - would you sit and watch a 5 minute educational government video - or would you rather go to the loo and grab a beer before the next sitcom starts? would it change my mind to buy more expensive food? maybe - if I'm a forward thinker - and have the insight to care enough about the future - or my growing pot belly.  But if I'm struggling to make ends meat on a tight budget - I will most likely eat what I can afford - sadly, the imported bulk.
The "green" label has become somewhat of an elitist thing my country (south africa - who face very much the same and other pressing issues).  This means organic and quality domestic produce is only sold in high end grocery stores + trendy farmers markets and way to expensive for the average person living in a shack with no television. 
I'm just skeptical about mass media / advertising's role in trying to change minds sustainably. In the battle of healthy vs. easy and cheap - the latter usually wins.  
how do we make healthy = easy and cheap?
the thing that stood out for me which may be overlooked is the point/theory of changing diet - away from indigenous / cultural diets - and the greater impact it has. I know of cultures that consume a lot of meat and fats - but somehow it works for them. The same goes for trees that grow in deserts - cause they're indigenous to that region - anything else will die - or you will disturb the biosphere if you force it to grow there. It begs the question - what is my culture - and what do is my cultural make-up dictate as a diet.  does the gastronomic evolution of my kind (geographical /cultural) over hundreds of years have a "right way" of eating - because it's more sustainable for my health and my area? Is it the global village idea poisoning us because we're starting to eat foods we are not supposed or adapted to?
As you say, awesome video!

japanese_future_of_food_video.title: Japanese 'Future of Food' video

comments.text: Thanks Madeline!  Sorry I missed your inspiration before.  Great idea!

I agree!  Check out my idea posted August 3rd:http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/inspiration/food-tunes/
Pop music videos, especially with stars, could get a captivated audience.

I see what you are getting at with "healthy eating pop songs." There is no question that celebrities hold a great deal of influential power over the youth demographic. Kids pay attention and are eager to emulate their favorite singer or star. I think harnessing celebrity for social awareness and change is a great idea from a marketing standpoint. I think songs about healthy eating may be heading in the wrong direction.
I would suggest using celebrities that hold a large youth audience's attention (like justin Beiber) in a campaign-type format (speaking in TV segments, public service-type ads, appearances in public, or in video clips on websites). They could speak to how they eat healthy why they think its important as well as what that does for them personally. Teens want to be like celebrities, and like you suggest, If they see the stars doing itit will inspire them to do the same. Basically we are talking about making healthy eating "the cool thing to do." As it should be.

With a little bit of planning, this could be fun and educational for everyone.

We could also encourage kids to bring something out of the ordinary. For fear of getting duplicate and/or common items like apples and bananas, we could encourage them to bring a fruit or food item that is out of the norm. The more creative they get, the better. 
Try this: 10 must-try exotic fruit:  http://blog.hotelclub.com/10-must-try-exotic-fruits/
Exotic fruits like jackfruit, or lychee? These fruits look different from your everyday apples and oranges. They're colorful, weird shapes and sizes, fun to look at and maybe the kids will even sample/taste them, and develop a life-long love for fruits.
Nice adaptation of show & tell. Easy for a teacher to implement.

comments.text:
I am guilty of putting the camera before the fork. Photographing food has become a culture. Many people blog and/or keep a diary of the foods they eat, including myself. This inspiration reminded me of an NYT article I read awhile back: 
http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/07/dining/07camera.html
You're right, it's just so easy and fun. Thanks for bringing this great idea up!
Good idea! I might add the concept of before and after photos documenting a change.
Well done! Simple and effective.

love this idea and its simplicity.
Building on this, you could also take pictures of yourself during the course this exercise to see a progression. Maybe it could further encourage healthy dieting.

Nice idea @JamesMcB more likely advertisers would track your dietary trends and quite literally serve you Ads in the forms of foods you might like.
If your going to post what you eat you may as well post where you ate it.. "FourSquareMeal" ;D
Could photo-recognition be used to analyse each dish and give it a 'healthy score' tell you how many calories etc?

There seem to be bunch of people blogging 'everything I ate' on the web. Definitely existing behavior that has something intriguing about it. Here's one example: http://everythingiate2008.blogspot.com/
And it's fun, not a chore, to take pictures, to share and compare.

Your post and the referenced study show the power of awareness.  So many of us have an idea of what we eat that is far from the truth.  If we can't realize that we have bad eating habits, we can't change them.  Understanding what portions are, both on the box and on our plate, is an awareness that can be improved through education, a complement to your inspiration.

eat._educate_all_the_time..description: An integrated approach to reconfiguring our attitudes towards nutrition at school and at home, all year round.
eat._educate_all_the_time..creator: b419aa71200ed65b3c31b6f959c2e707

comments.text: Great stuff!You put a lot of work into this which I appreciate very much.And I couldn't help but recognize the image on page 23! :)Your concept is what I think is great about OpenIDEO.  It naturally allows designers and ideas to build on one another and branch out and expand and create solution possibilities and opportunities where there didn't seem to be any before.  You are correct in that a holistic approach is to be the goal if we are going to cause real, lasting change in kid's attitudes and choices in terms of healthy foods and lifestyles.  Thanks for putting that together!

This is a more cleverly branded version of the same idea i had.  I think that slight tweaks in the actual subject matter of our many school courses could teach our kids about food instead of other more hypothetical examples (envision all math word problems being about farming, cooking, or nutrition...envision a chemistry and biology class that teaches you about components of food and checmicals on nutrition labels.)
Really like the simplicity and clarity of your PDF, thumbs up from me!
Great stuff  comprehensive and compelling.

I really appreciate you taking the time and effort to collect these ideas and present them within a framework having an order of magnitude.  In particular, your slides on "understanding time" and "starting early" with pregnant mothers were very strong and really set the tone.  You also make a really strong point about getting beyond the "fighting fire with fire" approach however several of your slides still cling to this approach.  this is a great concept w/ great presentation.

Hi Rob,
Thank you for your feedback, you really hit the nail right on the head. I was hoping that many of the ideas that other people have come up with would find a place somewhere within the framework of EAT and hopefully would be used to then bring to their own school programmes anyway.
When I was considering my submission I was looking at Vegetable Circus and loads of the other amazing ideas that have been thrown up so far.  The general thrust is that some ideas are very specific, some cover several areas (Vegetable Circus included) - for maximum impact many of the ideas here need a framework that will need developing that encompasses many of these ideas to the point where it's a continuous process throughout the year.
My friend Alastair mailed me last night and he had this to say: 
"A lot of the stuff around creating behaviour change through 'awareness' campaigns is verging on useless, because we're competing in a field alongside brands with big advertising budgets and big street traction - so those things always appeal more to adults than children. The most interesting core element of the 'Educate all the time' concept is actually stepping away from those things towards the choice architecture / ambient conditions stuff - in other words, getting into everyday culture in ways advertising can't, so its the "good" food ethic (I use that word with a heavy sense of suspended judgement!) is always the most clear and tangible in any given room."
I agree to a point; but what a lot of the ideas here allude to is a 'fight fire with fire' approach.  The snack and beverage industries have millions to spend in branding and awareness campaigns, all of which are designed to influence our behaviour to make sure we buy their products.  We must do the same to promote healthier eating, but do so in such a way so it becomes entrenched in our very psyche.  Thankfully, designing choice as illustrated by the authors of Nudge, can have a tangible effect as seen in Redesign the Cafe, and some of the other ideas presented in EAT.  In addition, schools, particularly primary schools, represent one of the last bastions of institutions that are relatively free from advertisement, and therefore the place to engage with young minds.
Love this!

I like how this idea syncs with the Vegetable Circus; your concept covers a lot of ground, but still needs a method of implementation. Here's how I see our concepts overlapping, as they do for 17 of the 21 points you bring:
1) Understanding Time: Vegetable Circus stage shows can occur in the school, during the school day; our after-school programs bring the education to the kids.  That education will include the training to make the kids capable of following through themselves the rest of the year.
2) Educate Parents: Supplementary take-home materials will focus on including the parents in the process, so they can make sure their kids cook at home, help with shopping, and play safely.
3) Start Early: This program is aimed at elementary-aged children (5-10), the earliest ages that we can effectively target.
4) Re-Educate Dinner Staff: Not currently covered, but possible.
5) Good Food is Convenient: A message promoted and explained by all of our programs.
6) Theme It: The Vegetable Circus is a theme itself; the after-school programs could use cultural themes for both food and play education.
7) Cross-Curriculum: We cross movement arts training with food education, plus some social & mental skills along the way.
8) Re-design the Cafe: Not currently covered, but possible.
9) Join a Club: We'd be creating clubs in the form of after-school programs. There is a focus on trying new things in our programs, which should also set up kids to try and join new clubs later in life.
10) Update Parents (I): Take-home materials for parents to supplement the initial stage show experience, and then internet-based updates for parents kids in after-school programs could be a good idea as well. 
11) Make Food Fun: Vegetable Circus shows exist to demonstrate this exact point!
12) Apply the Law of the Few: Consider that our initial stage show is designed to have performers which children consider cool and popular use their knowledge and skills to subtly convince children to take charge of their own health.  
13) Tell Kids How Much They Love Broccoli: Our programs focus on using methods that work more genuinely than "triggering false memories", but we certainly tell kids how much we love healthy foods and talk to them about retrying foods.
14) Involve Parents in Pricing: Not sure how we'd include this.
15) Work with Role Models: Exactly why we're using talented performers to deliver these messages, on stage and after-school.
16) Join Communities: See "9) Join a Club"
17) Update Parents (II): Final performances have been a part of the after-school programming, where they can demonstrate what they've learned or created to their family and community. 
18) Come Dine with Us (I): Yes, we should have kids cooking; this ought to become part of the after-school programs. And this is one of those places where Jamie's help in particular would be golden.
19) Come Dine with Us (II): I'm not sure how this would be implemented.
20) Positive Association: This does work; we love seeing how kids react to free fruit! And our whole program uses this technique by demonstrating the benefits of healthy lifestyles in a fun and exciting manner.
21) Advertise in Public Places: The Vegetable Circus is a living, breathing advertisement; once the programs have some degree of popularity, we could unite the right allies to promote healthy eating as proposed.

comments.text: Interesting question... In terms of things like Star Wars, 'epic' was a compelling story told about the struggle of good over evil.  With cool space ships and laser guns of course.  So the question maybe is how can a story be told about carrots, or any good food for that matter, that will have the same compelling nature?  Do carrots struggle against evil?  Evil wabbits maybe?  I personally think that some foods are epic.  Like a bottle of champagne, a good wine or an amazingly prepared dinner.  But that's an adult perspective.  And what about them makes me think 'epic'? Their price?  Their care in preparation?  Their level of deliciousness?  Their alcohol content?  Yes to all of that. So the question is what could make a kid think of a healthy food as of such great import that they should stop and take notice?  It's a good question.  And a tough answer...

how_do_we_make_food_epic.title: How do we make food epic?

comments.text: I think that kids will quickly get bored of this. The first 3-5 times it will be delightful, and then they'll say: "I get it, I get it, just give me the fruit already!"
Ok, but what about a button: "what else?". The second-level story can be improved telling about where this specific fruit was planted, which chemicals were used, who worked there, etc.

This made me think about a nutrition course I took in college where my professor spoke about the varying colors of fruits and vegetables and how each color meant that there was a higher concentration of phytochemicals in these plants that each had specific health benefits. For instance, lycopene, found in tomatoes and watermelon, has cancer-fighting affects and makes these fruits red. I think if children were educated about eating a variety of colorful vegetables for health, it would not only keep them interested, it would keep them healthy and provide an easy way for them to remember the nutritional information and pass it on to others (especially future generations- or even their parents!).On a personal note, I strongly believe that food is my medicine. I haven't been able to afford healthcare for a while so to prevent/combat illnesses and/or infections, I often research vitamins and minerals that I might need more of at any given time and eat the foods that exhibit them. Wouldn't it be great if children were raised to   know the vitamins and minerals in most fruits and vegetables and know how these vitamins and minerals could benefit their overall health if consumed? In order to make this a priority, the focus of healthcare in this country has to shift to prevention rather than treatment and must heavily incorporate new education about nutrition that emphasizes eating for the nutritional properties of food and not the misguided notion that avoiding fat and carbs (and calories) will make one more healthy.

I think the evaluation criteria above don't go far enough to determine if an idea will catch on with kids - and I think this one will.
Great ideas Demian and Emma. Salads in high traffic areas, dried fruit in all other areas. The possibilities are endless, and variety is key!

Good idea to incorporate informative and fun animation!  How about skip the spoilage issues and have the vending machine stock dried fruit products?  Dried fruit is great in that it can come in snack sized pieces, is easy to handle, carry and keep, is nutritious and tastes great... sometimes just as good as sweet processed snacks.  As far as fresh food goes, the baby carrot vending machine is inspirational!  They have done a lot of work on clever graphics, marketing, ads, etc.  It would be great to apply this strategy to other vegetables that could stay fresh for long enough to sell.  Great opportunities for development here!Thanks for the idea!
Great idea, would love to see vending machines with bagged salads and fresh fruit ... maybe a sales pitch to coca cola under their corporate social responsibility banner?

I agree Thao, fresh, packaged fruits and vegetables could easily be added to a concept like this. The whole thought of this exercise in my mind was to change children's eating habits through positive re-enforcement and fun. 
It has already been proven out that people will take the stairs (instead of an escalator) if it plays like a piano. Or that recycling will go up significantly if the recycling machine has a gaming aspect. 
Positive reinforcement through fun is a great way to "start the conversation", and hopefully change kids habits at school and home.

Life is too busy. We tend to schedule our life around fresh foods, not the other way around, and that is a big pain. Health is not the number one priority - taste, convenience, low cost - these things ranks higher in our minds.
Today I read a NY Times article about a vending macine that sells baby carrots at a high school. This vending machine competes with the junk food vending machine. http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/25/health/policy/25vegetables.html?_r=1&hpw
Perhaps the items in the vending machine could follow the ides from the article to help make eating vegetables easier:
1. packages fo cut broccoli designed to go right into the microwave2. washed, ready-to-eat bagged salads 
An article about a Del Monte special refrigerated vending machines that stocks fresh fruit snakes like pineabpple chunks, grapes, apple slices, baby carrots, celery, tomato, etc.
http://www.freshplaza.com/news_detail.asp?id=51151
If I were a student today, I might go for the healthy alternatives.

Our ideas have gone through the inspiration phase, concepting phase, and now the evaluation phase so we've come a long way. I'm seeing many overlaps, odds and ends that can be fitted together. This is a really good idea. To keep it engaging, can we introduce weekly cartoon characters to deliver the facts, who then can become their "hero" over time? Can we somehow bring in social interaction through social networking or social media? For example:Have all their friends on Facebook cheer them on at the moment of truth, when they're choosing the fresh item over the unfresh item.

I appreciate anyone who has given applause. Please feel free to add comments on how to keep it engaging! Several ideas:
1. Networked system to allow children to keep track of their healthy choices across multiple machines.2. Connect with a website that provides alternatives to sugary snacks, and allows them to add additional healthy snacks (for points).3. Achievement systems to cheer them on and "level-up" as they continue to make healthy choices.
Make it fun, make it engaging, leave kids wanting more. It's habit changing and fun.
Joe

This would great public art piece as well.  I would place vending machine 'shells' around the trees in an apple orchard at harvest time.  It would be great to have kids experience getting fruit from a vending  machine, in the context of the sights, smells, and sounds of being at an apple farm.

There are so many things I like about this idea! Yet,on a practical level there are some challenges--1) freshness would mean machine would have to be stocked frequently. 2) lack of use would lead to waste. 3) Novelty would wear off over time, in, for instance, a school setting. On a more practical level, I wonder if it would work as an information kiosk in a grocery store. Parents would potentially like it because it gives kids an activity to do at the store. The assumption would be to put it in the produce aisle, but go ahead and put it by the processed stuff. What would come out of the tube would have to be changed to something inedible. And the whole profit-making angle would be gone, but...Anyway, really like the core of the idea.
It is a good idea, it makes profit to the owner of the machine, therefore I find it totally feasible and sustainable!

Common excuses parents use is 'time', they have no time, they therefore turn to the tins and packages.

comments.text: I like the idea and the image you posted up. The image looks like a food wheel, and you can turn it around to view different food groups. Maybe we could use a a food calender or that wheel could be a refrigerator magnet. Stapling it on to the refrigerator door could be a last minute reminder to eat healthy: "don't grab that cold left-over pizza, eat that healthy alternative..."

seed_to_tray_education_in_public_schools.description: We all know:  School food service sucks. Kids don't get enough time outside. Families  don't cook. Basic kitchen AND farming skills are being lost in a single generation.  A problem? Yes. But not one without a beautifully integrated solution: Seed to Tray Education. In plain English: put kids in charge of their own school lunch!
seed_to_tray_education_in_public_schools.creator: 4cae0fc2e410f00fa630315edb2bcb2f

comments.text: Wonderful idea!  I'm a public school teacher, and I would SO be on board with something like this.
I think this is a great concept. Kids have huge creativity and can be given a lot more responsibility than we often imagine. I think many of them would learn heaps from this kind of opportunity!
A public school in Paris showing that school lunches don't need to be the stereotypical school lunches we think of: http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=6902333n

Matt, I think it's highly compatible. I know the folks that run the HEAL farmers' market in Half Moon Bay: http://www.thehealproject.org/ - 3rd and 4th graders run a stand at the Coastside Farmers' Market, selling what they grew at school. 
A big part of their program is student empowerment and entrepreneurship!
I wonder how this concept might connect with the Student-run Farmers Markets idea?

Thank you Demian! As you say, the financials will always be the biggest challenge. I'm doing my own at-home challenge in November to see if I can do it in my daughter's lunches for a week. I actually think it's very do-able if you focus on a plant-based diet with beans as a primary protein source. Healthy too! 
I also think integrating farm-toschool with this concept has a lot of potential as well. I worked to start an 11-acre farm, and I can speak from experience when I say that food waste is a sad but regular occurrence on even the most sustainably-minded farm. If we could harness the bargaining power of impending waste and school-district size volume (i.e. come to the farmers' market at the end of the day, and make some deals and be prepared to take it ALL) then the price for fresh food could be significantly reduced. 
Of course, that requires whoever's making the lunches to be VERY nimble when it comes to fresh ingredients - and that's where culinary education and kids in the kitchen pays off - they are the most creative cooks I know! :) 
I'd say the biggest barrier is: working kitchens. In the two districts where I've worked, the kitchens were dismantled in favor of heat & serve literally decades ago. I helped get an old, mothballed kitchen back online (with kids' help!) at Full Circle Farms' home middle school - it was a beautiful transformation. 
But - word to the weary: it took almost 3 years to get that kitchen going, and nearly as long to start getting ANY of the farm's produce into the school! But in my mind, it was 100% worth it and if I could spend my life doing this over and over again, school district to school district to school district - I would, in a heartbeat! 
My best, Liz Snyderwww.ieatreal.com

Great idea with a lot of potential!  I love the way this concept takes what most everyone sees as a processed food mess and liability, school lunch programs, and turns it into a multi-faceted, integrated learning opportunity for kids.  Even if the program struggles... after all, developing delicious healthy lunches for less than $2.59 is not the easiest thing to do...(Jamie had a hard time on his 'Food Revolution' show), I think it would be a great learning experience and real-world business training for kids.  So many opportunities, as you mention, for parallel learning in multiple subjects and disciplines.Great stuff!
SOOOO excited to be on the shortlist!!!

In today's news: results from Berkeley Unified are in! The conclusion? Integrating cooking and gardening into the school day while implementing farm-to-school in the cafeteria results in kids making better food choices! 
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/09/22/MNBI1FHT33.DTL

Thanks Clare! Yes, Edible Schoolyard is a great model - they have an amazing on-site kitchen where culinary education is an integrated part of the garden setting. I'd like to see it taken one step further - where the business side of the whole thing, the costing, sourcing, labor, marketing and menu planning parts - are all put into kids hands. 
The more I think about it, the more I love it for High School - imagine a school where *running* the lunch program was a highly competitive program, one you applied to get into your senior year - you could put on your college applications that you had real-world business, culinary, and environmental experience. It would be a real stand-out honor, and it would challenge really talented older kids to take responsibility for their own health, for the planet's future, and for their school's bottom line.

This is a fab way of integrating food and cooking into the curriculum in a more holistic fashion. The edible schoolyard run by the Chez Panisse foundation has a similar ethos which I have loved reading about in their journal http://www.edibleschoolyard.org/journal/ .  Children should see where their food comes from. I especially like the way that kids can find their niche but still be part of the whole creative process.

Thanks Jordan! I agree, middle and high school are the most neglected grades when it comes to all kinds of nutrition education. As the mom of a kindergartener I value early education a great deal, but I think that there should be many more programs that empower older youth to take charge of their own health! School food service is the perfect venue for both teaching nutrition and leadership. 
Food Lab in Davenport is an amazing model - 5th graders cook lunch for the rest of the school: http://lifelabvideos.blogspot.com/2009/01/project-food-lab.html
I'd like to take it a step further - where students also source and budget their lunches. It's a real-world skill that will serve them for a lifetime. 
I'd love to see that Google Map if you think of the name!

Love it - this is a particularly good way to get teenagers to get involved; arguably a a much harder group to work with than children.  This will be of particular appeal to business studies and economics students, or even keen students wanting to run a club of some sort.  
I'd also emphasise looking at the distribution chain, I saw an amazing project put up on Google Maps (it's name escapes me) where they literally plotted on a map where their school lunch ingredients were coming from - local shops and businesses stand to gain a great deal from getting young students to source their school lunches to them. It's a win win scenario for all involved.

seed_to_tray_education_in_public_schools.title: Seed to Tray Education in Public Schools

comments.text: Maybe the purchase of "good food" could be accompanied with Bunny Money like the points that you could get from chips or box tops. Maybe a pretty or exciting tag attached which can later be exchanged..

"selling expensive junk food"... ummmm even though 'junk food' seems cheap, it is pricey for what you get.  That is the model for many 'junk food' manufactuers.  This is a model for captains of industry... not how to teach kids how to make good choices.  IMHO

comments.text: I like the 'hand-held game' aspect of your idea.  So once the game which builds up to the final recipe is played, and all the ingredients revealed, the game can be taken to the store as a grocery list and then brought into the kitchen and used as a fun interactive cookbook as the kid and their parent/supervisor cooks the recipe.  Fun development potential!  Thanks for the idea!
My gosh I lov it !!!
Very cool cookbook-rolled-in-a -toy concept, and I also really enjoyed the drawings. I think this toy or kids kit would go great with some of the other concepts and inspirations.
I got it ! like a View Master ! OMG I had one of those like a million years ago ! haha Got idea man !
great job ! I love the way that your idea began... the sketches and now the final concepto ... it's awersome !

after_school_cooking_is_fun_club.description: Fun cookery after school club for infant and junior schools... As well as learning about healthy food as part of the curriculum.
after_school_cooking_is_fun_club.creator: 96637be261342546b5afaa23772834dc

comments.text: Great idea! Kids love being in the kitchen and helping out. Making them a part of the process will spark interest and these kids will gain valuable skills. Educating them on the garden and how foods grow/seasonal foods will also tie them to the land and expand their understanding of what food is and where it comes from.
Linking the growing of the vegetables with the cooking is ideal, if the location allows so - the more hands-on learning the better!

Great idea! Just a thought that maybe parents could be invited to some after school sessions and get to sous chef their kids. This could encourage kids to particpate more and give them a chance to be 'in charge'!
Thanks for such a good idea! That would work really well as an end of term special thing to do, where the kids can show the parents how much they have learnt... and the parents can learn too!

I'm starting an afterschool wellness club. Can you share any of your program ideas? We're growing food, trying new foods and exercising, but I would love specific ideas. I can send my email address if you can share ideas.

Hi, specific ideas will depend mostly on the age of the kids and what facilities and equipment you can access. I like the sound of what you are planning. I think is important to gradually cook the same ingredient in more than one way, so kids can see versatility and adaptation. Also, you could have a fruit or veg of the week, you can gather facts about it, or have quizes, and other fun games so the kids learn where their food comes from and which foods are healthy or not.

Thanks for the comments! The aim really would be to get the kids to have fun, learn and experience, hands-on, how easily healthy tasty food can be prepared. As a bonus, this also would provide another useful option for parents for after school care, and on that day the children would definitely have something healthy to eat: whatever they prepared at the club! Week after week, the kids would develop preferences and favourites, which hopefully they would want to re-create at home, and thereby, slowly but surely, breaking the habbit!

This idea ties well to the fact that many of the kids who are hardest to reach where nutrition is concerned also need quality after school programs. Teaching latchkey kids select and prepare healthy meals and snacks for themselves would go a long way toward preventing junk food habits from forming in the first place.
Its All about the Kids!!!

after_school_cooking_is_fun_club.title: After school 'Cooking is Fun' Club

Even more relevant, Linkwell Health (http://www.linkwellhealth.com which is partnering with various orgs such as Blue Cross/Blue Shield), provides coupons for nutritious food. Could this be extended to children?

get_health_insurers_to_promote_healthy_f.title: Get Health Insurers to Promote Healthy Food

re_label_food_to_simply_show_how_much_ca.description: We often find it hard enough as adults to understand how the tables on the back of food products work and what they mean to us. With children buying some of their own food outside of the house they may not realise that they are over-eating. A simple new labelling system would clearly show how much of a product it is advisable to eat in terms of days and weeks, allowing a considered choice to be made before purchase without unintentionally scaremongering.
re_label_food_to_simply_show_how_much_ca.creator: 8cd97515ad2f05101eb2b20d02a4716e

comments.text: Does anyone know who runs the food labelling system in the UK? I know it changed fairly recently and became standardised, but it hasn't been updated since then. It's a shame that the step was taken to standardise it but the idea is still quite confusing when it comes to understanding moderation - but still good that the step was taken at all.

I think this is great, as it focuses on the positive messages, puts them into context, and is easily interpreted. I like the colour-coding as per traffic-lights - gives easy visual read, universally understood!

I think the key is putting the figures into context. It has to be obvious to the person reading the labels what level of intake of a particular product is healthy. If people have to think too long about whether something is healthy or not they may stop thinking altogether - if they can tell at a glance then they may rethink what they're doing, or about to do. It also makes it easier to keep tabs on how much of each colour/foodtype we're eating.

Love this idea! I definitely want to build on this. After reading an article called "Calorie Counts Are Coming to the Menu" by NPR: http://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2010/08/25/129420833/get-ready-for-calorie-countsI wanted to ponder more about it before coming up with a concept, but you beat me to it!
Basically, the highlight of the article is the FDA plans to implement requirements under new law overhauling health care for better nutritional labeling on the menus of some restaurant chains.
It would be very cool if we could come up with simplified labels for kids. Even as an adult, I get confused with what items on the labels mean. Is it really fresh? Is it really healthy for me? It's so confusing.

Just in case you want to see the full-size picture, which has a fuller explanation of the idea written on it, here is the link...
http://www.box.net/shared/dtxesoo542

re_label_food_to_simply_show_how_much_ca.title: Simplify food labelling by putting it in context

involve_the_parents_and_do_the_integrati.description: If you want to raise the kids' awareness you have to raise the parents' awareness and things are more likely to fall into place. The parents' awareness is likely to rise when they connect good food with emotions of satisfaction, safeness and comfort. To do that we need an integrative approach that reinforces the incentives for parents to cook good food at different levels/stages/places/dimensions. See the description for some particular actions that could be taken.

is_halloween_scarier_than_we_think_.description: As a kid, the holidays were the most memorable. Halloween, Christmas, and Easter were major events in my young life. We had no school! We got treats and gifts!  If kids could associate very fond memories with healthy food then it will replace junk food as the new treat or comfort food. How could we have a drive-thru Trader Joes? How can the Farmer's Markets get closer to the lunch room? Where are the holidays based around health?
is_halloween_scarier_than_we_think_.creator: 1fcf019a673e8e3b640dc22543539382

relocate_local_farmers_markets_to_school.description: Have a farmers market on / near school property. Fresh produce awaits parents and their kids when school is let out for the day.

comments.text:
Glad to see someone already posted this! By bringing the market to the schools, parents and kids can benefit from having an easy way to get food.
Providing quick meal planning cards would help them see what the food in the market could become (e.g. tomatoes, onions, etc. for sauce).
Nice. Potentially convenient & fun for parents and children, effective for the farmers market/farmers, and delivery of produce for the school cafeteria could naturally occur on the same day.

Have school lunch programs buy local from farmers and families that grow their own "organic" produce. Food should come from the "under 30 miles" rule to insure freshness, cut transportation costs, and support the local economy.

relocate_local_farmers_markets_to_school.title: Relocate Local Farmers Markets to Schools for end of day veg/fruit buying frenzy

the_hungry_hedgehog_iphone_app.description: Encourage young kids to eat good food though an interactive app. Kids choose the food they are eating and they see their hedgehog friend eating the same.

health_food_mascots.description: Have you ever noticed how almost all of the junk foods have mascots, or some type of cartoon character on them that they easily recognize? Maybe healthy foods could start making their packing more friendly and attractive to kids. It doesn't teach them the benefits of eating healthy but it might get them to.
health_food_mascots.creator: 5437f004137c720cbcb5e5193f397ef0
health_food_mascots.title: Health Food Mascots

young_chefs_club.description: Young Chefs Club is a comprehensive line of cooking utensils scaled to child size proportions. YCC uses the concept of parent-mimicry to teach children that cooking can be fun, healthy, and delicious. Included in the kit is a cutting board (which doubles as a space for food prep), a miniature range (operating with lower heats), utensils, YCC apron/badge/decals for customization.  The various parts of the kit can be put together in multiple ways to match each child's height and preference.
young_chefs_club.creator: fc525f504806547f7e611630f89dcdc2

comments.text: How might we extend this concepts to situations where the parents do'nt already cook, to break the cycle of poor choices?  It would be great if YCC can extend education upwards to the parents, and get them to actively support their kids making better choices.

young_chefs_club.title: Young Chefs Club

family_centered_grocery_store.description: A series of family and children centered grocery stores that are designed specifically to engage children in the grocery shopping experience.
family_centered_grocery_store.creator: 4d574575c7c91e6854d98029ceb56fe5

comments.text: Unique contribution - I love the concept!  I just read this article on redesigning grocery stores: http://urbanland.uli.org/Articles/2011/Mar/NewbergGrocery  Perhaps an indication that the market is interested in a new grocery experience!

There could also be an area within the grocery store for scheduled cooking classes, or drop-in snack making sessions (kids could stop by a booth and learn to make a quick snack, that they could then eat...a more participatory type of sample booth). There could also be a community board in the grocery store where kids could post recipes or photos of meals they've made. Kids could submit their recipes and possibly get their photo and recipe posted up as the "chef of the month/week".  Giving kids recognition and attention is a great way to encourage and motivate them. Create a community environment within the grocery store.

I think coupled with this idea it's good to think about how kids could get to the store independently, and how kids could be involved in the design of it.  There is lots of information on this through studies on Children's Independent Mobility and also Child Friendly Cities.   I think it's an excellent idea, but if it's all designed by adults and can only be accessed if an adult takes a child, it will lose some of its potential

I've always thought that having only healthy foods to choose from, and then letting kids pick whatever they wanted, would be the ideal way to feed kids.  So this sounds like a great idea!  Foods could also be prices by the piece/package to make it easier for kids (and adults) to know if they can afford something.

family_centered_grocery_store.title: Family Centered Grocery Store

5_karat_gold.description: Bring together all of the kids ideas and recipes into a book and publish it then distribute. Then make fresh vegetables and fruits into sweets, leathers etc.
5_karat_gold.creator: 7a18f4ddf356c2babbe55d2c6c892268
5_karat_gold.title: 5 Karat Gold

urban_farms_help_city_kids_learn_about_f.creator: 24f6e3dc1bbc5a5dfb1e5c6481b94eb7
urban_farms_help_city_kids_learn_about_f.title: Urban farms help city kids learn about farming and fresh produce

make_cooking_a_game.description: Making cooking into a game can change a lot - for the kids - but also for the "grown-ups": Something stressful gets playful, mess is suddenly an option or even a feature, it actually adds to the fun and on the side everyone can learn a lot about food and how to deal with it.
make_cooking_a_game.creator: 344d76cd8e11966f90a65069857223c2

comments.text:
You've heard of date night or game night. At our house we have KIDS COOK night. They prepare a menu, we shop as a family, we cook as a family and we eat as a family. Whatever weird and wacky thing they come up with, we enjoy creating and experiencing together. The benefits go beyond nutrition to researching, planning, shopping, creating and delivering a healthy meal. 
We all learn better by DOING. I applaud ideas that place kids in the role of Chef for the day!

just found this great concept "lets play" by designaffairs STUDIOS: it takes international cuisine to everyones kitchen as an easy cooking game:
"People who think cooking is a burden, or boring or dull will be gobsmacked how much fun it actually can be! Cooking is an experimental, cultural, exciting experience  and with lets play its easy and fun!
With its universal design, lets play takes international cuisine to everyones kitchen as an easy cooking game. Greek, Italian or Thai recipes are surprising, cool experiences you can share with friends, family or kids."
(visit http://studioblog.designaffairs.com/?p=400 for a detailed description and lots of sketches/images)

make_cooking_a_game.title: Make cooking a game!

the_cereal_box_digital_toy.description: Don't you just miss the old days when you poured the entire box out to get that God-forsaken toy? Well, today we can brings this back using digital content sharing as the prize and fresh food as the new cereal boxes.
the_cereal_box_digital_toy.creator: 9b0994abf351bbd1060a5e372da1303d
the_cereal_box_digital_toy.title: The cereal box digital toy

family_meals.description: I think that the correlation between the decline in family's eating meals together as a group, and the decline in America's eating habits is to huge to be ignored.
family_meals.creator: 9ee6605eed782761c2dbb4d9fe2e1821

comments.text:
I think focusing on the social influence of family meals and translating that into a learning tool is a great start to a more permanent behavior change! I recently read a study that discussed the striking influence friends and family has on an individuals diet, food choices, and behaviors. 
I think there needs to be more education and campaigning efforts aimed at families, (first at parents) to take a more active role in choosing healthier foods, cooking healthier meals, and getting kids involved in the process of food selection and creating great tasting recipes. There is research that suggests we adopt the habits of those around us, healthy choices from the parental side could potentially  influence healthier, long-lasting habits in children .

family_meals.title: Family Meals

local_food_street_parties.description: Might communities be inspired to hold kid's street parties that celebrate their local food—perhaps an adjunct to their local farmers' markets?
local_food_street_parties.creator: 53134a6b4eaf1ae776a01a4610818ecc

comments.text: This would be a great way to talk about food that's in season and get people connected to the food they eat!http://openideo.com/open/localfood/inspiration/eating-seasonally-means-knowing-what-s-in-season/Especially in low-income areas or "food deserts", these street parties would be a great way to get people together, introduce/revive food traditions. It might start a discussion on how to get better access to low-cost and nutritious food in their areas.

local_food_street_parties.title: Local food street parties

get_their_hands_dirty_to_keep_their_bell.description: Share with kids the joy of growing food and getting dirt in their fingernails and you'll feed their belly's and soul's for a lifetime.
get_their_hands_dirty_to_keep_their_bell.creator: 6df70899fee3f8fb611c4fc65a039fb6

comments.text: I can't think of a better way to learn something than the do-it-yourself/hands-on method!
Good point, and really nice picture as well!

get_their_hands_dirty_to_keep_their_bell.title: Get Their Hands Dirty to Keep Their Bellys Full . . .Knowing the Path to Plate.

My idea is to teach fathers to give them cooking healthy alternatives for their children especially on weekends when they are at home, now the alternatives are divorced parent has the fast food outlets also offers amusement parks.

city_farms_helping_kids_see_where_their_.description: Living in a big city is one of the best ways to remove that sense of where food comes from. City farms do a great job of fixing that, but locating small farms in dense urban areas. This photograph is from Hackney City Farm, my old local farm. Here you can watch the pigs, sheep, chickens, and cows grow up and help care for them.
city_farms_helping_kids_see_where_their_.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Kids love farm animals, and you can find these types of places in the city or the country!

city_farms_helping_kids_see_where_their_.title: City Farms - helping kids see where their food comes from

erase_the_line_between_treats_and_health.description: Kids grow up associating certain foods with pleasure and reward. By substituting healthier options, we can teach children that fruits and vegetables are not only good for you but are foods for which to strive for.
erase_the_line_between_treats_and_health.creator: 25f87ad2e28333a367a6139a3df46946
erase_the_line_between_treats_and_health.title: Erase the line between treats and healthy food.

mobile_nutritionbuddy_app_with_visual_fe.description: create a mobile app.  take picture of bar code and/or food and/or add text of what you are eating.  get visual feedback, infographics on nutrient nasties and nice per input and accumulated over day/week/month/year....  show deficiencies, excesses, imbalances and show the good stuff, progress and improvements ...
mobile_nutritionbuddy_app_with_visual_fe.creator: 8ac7dc42fa6a7094dfad3364c84d3f2e

comments.text: I like where you're headed, but less than 17% of kids under age 10 have mobile phones.  Also this doesn't tie in with what motivates kids -- why is tracking food important to them?  Why is this something they want to do?  Just because it's an app, doesn't mean they want to use it.  I think that your last comments about making it a game will be the thing that makes or breaks this idea.

mobile_nutritionbuddy_app_with_visual_fe.title: Mobile NutritionBuddy App with visual feedback loop

the_healty_market_project..description: When you have to sell something you need to know it and you have to describe benefits and pros. The goal of the "Healty Market" is to make groups of young people engage in a real fresh-food-sale (location could be a corner into a real supermarket) where they can become fresh-food-evangelists and, at the same time, earn some $ from % of the sales they push.
the_healty_market_project..creator: aaeaec25ec6f1d3f8a0606cf6e2a0896

comments.text: Yes, when you provide an argument for something, you end up becoming more of a supporter for it. Maybe kids trying their hand at selling at farmer's markets could be the new lemonade stand (with the kids getting some % of sales & attracting more customers, it could be a win-win)!

the_healty_market_project..title: The "Healty Market" project.

how_can_urban_agriculture_familiarise_ch.description: About half of the population of the planet lives in urban areas, alienated from agriculture. This part of the population is more likely to consume processed food. Could urban agriculture shift kids' preferences to fresh food by allowing them e.g. to plant their own crops?
how_can_urban_agriculture_familiarise_ch.creator: 84c04044b0796f3cedaff79875d9bbd5

comments.text: This is a great idea to be supported and shared around. I heard of urban farming in Paris too. How can one turn into an active advocate of urban farming in their community?

"Urban Farming is proud to be partnered with the Triscuit Home Farming Movement to plant fifty community-based Home Farms in twenty cities across the United States this year. The Home Farming Movement encourages people to connect back to the simple joy of planting their own food at home."
http://bit.ly/d50HTU

how_can_urban_agriculture_familiarise_ch.title: How can urban agriculture familiarise children with fresh food?
