a_healthy_mail_business.creator: d26a77fe07d338d6e23f73b852a9186a
a_healthy_mail_business.title: A healthy mail business

kids_can_cook_but_need_our_help.description: Kids are curious and creative but the arena for producing meals - the kitchen - is not very child-friendly. Fridges have heavy doors or are inaccessible, ovens are considered dangerous as are hobs, ranges & gas rings. Can we create a mini kitchen or a worktop where kids can interact with ingredients like Play-Do but produce something edible at the end? Cooking toys, safe food mixers, long benches could be little aids that would give parents comfort to allow little ones to get involved.
kids_can_cook_but_need_our_help.creator: f71dbe52628a3f83a77ab494817525c6

comments.text: I remember having fake foods (plastic bananas, apples), and fake utensils (plastic cups, plates) to play with as a child. They were fun, but none of which were edible. A mini kitchen, that's safe for children, with higher stakes (i.e. they can eat the food) would be an incentive for kids. Parents on the other hand, would probably be less inclined to buy it, because it would require monitoring and cleaning = more work for them. Can we combine safety (for kids) and convenience (for adults)?

Yes, cooking is currently dangerous for kids so I would like to hear ideas on whether it could be made less so. Also, I would think it's great if kids start to see cooking as a game, which would inspire creativity. Not sure if this is possible but someone else had an idea about a low-temperature cooker which I thought was great.

Hi Thomas, I really like the way your idea goes but in fact i dont know if a "toy kitchen" will really help. Cooking healthy food could then be seen as a game, when its dangerous.I think that your idea could link with mine in the point that both pretend to make the kids the main characters of the action. Mine tries to be a rebelation against "the way my parents eat/cook" and "how will I do things when I grwo up". What do you think? We can build one on the other :)

kids_can_cook_but_need_our_help.title: Kids can cook - but need our help

dismissal_detox.description:
My idea is inspired by "Incubate and Amplify Youth Food Entreprenuers."
Student club to sell healthy snacks at dismissal bell.
dismissal_detox.creator: 87c36594ad1cadf8756d5c55df7da39e

comments.text: How about creating an organization that has chapters in individual high schools, middle schools, and even elementary schools? That will increase funding, recognition, and brand awareness. If kids could take a cut of their earnings after the bell, that'd be even better - it'd teach them sales skills, which would reinforce the healthy benefits of healthy foods to themselves and their schoolmates.

dismissal_detox.title: Dismissal Detox

webkinz_tamagotchi_youapp.description: Easy app/mini device game that kids use to track what they eat in a game style where they try to build the health of.... themselves!  Web element connects them to recommendations, contests, social networking, status updates, and the like.
webkinz_tamagotchi_youapp.creator: 39508fcb1076930a65d777f547d44ce1
webkinz_tamagotchi_youapp.title: Webkinz + Tamagotchi = YouApp

give_a_tool_for_explicit_planning_a_nudg.description: Organize, budget, and plan meals made up of core recipes - recipes that everyone should know.
give_a_tool_for_explicit_planning_a_nudg.creator: 888f6550662e25f5c20eb936d15188d0

comments.text:
Food APIs would be AWESOME.
I happen to work for an API infrastructure company... coincidence?

Good idea - this is a way to engage parents, who buy most of the food for kids.
Many online supermarkets allow you to order the ingredients list for a recipe card - maybe if you could design a 'meal builder' site that helps people plan a week's shop, points out nutritional content / missing food groups, and maybe also helps suggest how to preserve leftovers - I got through university by cooking up big pots of stews and the like and freezing portions - saving time and money.
If a few supermarkets would offer APIs to their websites one could even do a price comparison tool - or just print out a generic list for those with the time/money to use independent grocers.
I am most targeting parents... high school students interested in cooking may also get nudged.

give_a_tool_for_explicit_planning_a_nudg.title: Give a tool for explicit planning, a nudge may be all most people need

healthy_food_guide_scanner.description: If people could instantly learn the chemicals and composition in their food and other goods, they would start buying green, thus putting pressure on companies to make more environmentally friendly and healthier products. In turn having healthy food around us and healthy choices being made.
healthy_food_guide_scanner.creator: 28890c0b3a775ebd22755c0a1a35b9f4

comments.text:
Once such scanner technology is installed, there are lots of add-on functions that could provide win-win-win's to shoppers, the store, & food producers. In fact, the Stop & Shop supermarket chain in Northeast United States, already has over 200 stores that offer scanners that can be used while you shop to check & total prices, receive discounts, and self-check out. Adding "health" functionality to such systems would be great next step.
Links: http://www.physorg.com/news139225121.html, http://www.stopandshop.com/our_stores/tools.html, http://www.stopandshop.com/our_stores/departments_partners/index.htm?svcid=SCAN_IT

Interesting indeed! ;-) The healthy scanners could not only give you information about the food, but to keep track of what you are putting in your basket to buy; showing you what other items you could then buy to complement your diet in a healthy and balanced manner. Going even further, what if based on your purchase it send you recipes and suggestions of what to do with this healthy food selection.
Love this! Could be a phone app that you can take with you to the supermarket, and can take a picture of the barcode to 'scan' the item.
i like this idea, kids would get involved from a really young age wanting to operate the "game" and adults would have immediate answers to any questions they have. fun idea and practical too!

healthy_food_guide_scanner.title: Healthy food guide Scanner

mission_impossible_oliver_b4_s_little_ch.description: A different approach to teach the kids how to appreciate fresh food!
mission_impossible_oliver_b4_s_little_ch.creator: 79de317fa67a3e0726bbe2fbeadbe187

comments.text:
This type of psychology really works! I have tested myself! My kids really enjoy when they cook their own food! It seems that they are more eager to eat what they cook than when other person cooks. Its really about the game!  
Nice work!
Fantastic Idea! Way to go! I believe this type of approach can really make a difference! ;)
Cool!

mission_impossible_oliver_b4_s_little_ch.title: It's all about the game!

community_gardens_online.description: Use social media to launch urban farming in your neighborhood.
community_gardens_online.creator: 77f324edb92eb13ee5b903dd6545b300

comments.text: To be successful, this idea must bring together children, parents and school teachers, since we cannot expect kids to organize all the activities online through social network.It is also very dependent on the relationships with the building owner, local companies with vacant lots, local authorities...etc.My overall belief as regards to this challenge is that one isolated measure will not suffice to change food habits. It is a range of actions that will probably need to be implemented, through a program involving several participants with very different roles. If kids are able to live in such an environment where healthy food is valued and acted upon, they may feel more prone to adjust their taste, perception and habits.My 2 cents.

I like the idea of an online AND an offline component! I've also tried to think of a few ideas of my own to engage kids through online communities as well as offline communities. Through the photos you posted, the idea of using the rooftop as a gathering place might be fun; I can pictures kids watering plants, and just hanging out; it could possibly be an after school project, or school club. The rooftop idea would especially go well with urban communities where large plots of land is not readily available.

community_gardens_online.title: Community gardens online

build_a_dinner_kit.description:
Create excitement around cooking a meal by turning it into a game kit. This contains instructions for different meals and child-safe tools such as measuring spoons, tongs, and apron.

Each recipe involves a series of missions.
Mission 1: Locate ingredients in your local super-market
Mission 2: Measure out ingredients to match your recipe
Mission 3: Work with Adult if cooking is required
Mission 4: Plate your presentation and reap the rewards!
build_a_dinner_kit.creator: b9ba7582cb2ca077bc9897d89f45cb81
build_a_dinner_kit.title: Build-A-Dinner Kit

build_a_meal.description: What's the equivalent to "Build a Bear Workshop" or "American Girl Place" for the fresh food experience?
build_a_meal.creator: ebe6941ee8a10c14dc933ae37a0f43fc

comments.text: Possibly instead of "Build a meal" it could be "Build a Feast". Make it a group activity for birthdays or special occasions, and have a group of kids ( 8-10 kids is about right for a birthday still, right?) participate.  The emotional attachment can come from making it something special, perhaps traditional family dishes which are complicated to make, so get cut from the menu in a lot of homes nowadays. It could even be arranged like this company, which has unfortunately stopped operating http://www.slicedtomatoes.ca/about_us.aspx

I think 'Build-a-Bear' is a very interesting concept to explore as a way to engage kids in experimentation and discovery of fresh and possibly previously untried foods.  The danger, in my opinion, is that it just becomes 'salad-bar-at-kid-height'.  The trick, I think, is to come up with a way for this concept to build a sense of emotional attachment in the kids for the food that they create.  As 'Build-a-Bear' does with its stuffed animal assembly process.  Maybe the key lies in how 'Build-a-Bear hides a little heart inside the doll.  Maybe in the food concept the kid hides a 'heart' of bacon (or cheese) within the salad that they make here?  ... or maybe not.  But I like the larger point - engage the kids in the creative process and discovery of healthy foods.  Could McDonald's utilize this idea in terms of a 'Build-a-Happymeal' type thing so that kids might choose slightly healthier food combinations?

This idea is reminds me of the 'Fresh Choice' restaurant food chain kids go down the cafeteria line and choose which fresh foods to put on their plate. They are technically 'building' their meal. I think your intention for the concept is to add more interaction, education, and fun into the process? If so, that could be a good way to build on an existing/successful business while adapting it to fit kids needs and interests.
I  love this idea Jenny. It's not only educational it has so much potential to be fun and interactive.

build_a_meal.title: Build a Meal

what_s_for_dinner_the_last_class_of_the_.description: Last class of the day would bring cooking curriculum back into schools and solve an age old daily question 'WHAT'S FOR DINNER?'.  Kids would cook a tasty meal with enough servings to feed their family and bring it home for dinner!  This addresses several opportunity areas:  (read more in description)
what_s_for_dinner_the_last_class_of_the_.creator: e47652a6ce5ae9850b2542adf001e071

comments.text: I think it's important to think beyond stereotypical cooking teachers. Think food design. Rachel Khoo: http://www.rachelkhoo.com/ (a Brit based in Paris), Julie Rothhahn: http://juliehhh.com/ (Frenchwoman based in France), Marije Vogelzang: http://www.marijevogelzang.nl/studio/home.html (Dutch eating design with a restaurant, Proef, in Amsterdam), Tricia Martin: http://www.eatingisart.com/ (an American who wrote her thesis and started a company on the topic). I could even picture a online cooking school which is facilitated by an in-school teacher.

I love this idea!  It is incredibly practical and 'ticks all the boxes'.  While the concept is not entirely original, I agree that it is time for "home-ec" style classes focused on healthy living to come back into the national curriculum!

I like your reference to Dave Eggers and the Superhero Supply Co.  The genius behind that model, I think, is that it attracts volunteers to contribute, not only by the desire to help, but also because the concept is super clever at it's foundation, it's product offerings are fun and clever, it's graphic identity is smart and crisp, etc.  It resonates with the kids coming for tutoring support AND with the adult volunteers who want to be a part of this hip, tongue-in-cheek community.If 'Superhero Supply Co,' is used as a conceptual launching point for an after-school cooking class a couple things come to mind.  Since 'Superhero' is about tutoring kids with their schoolwork, maybe a cooking class could intertwine 'teaching moments' into the meal preparations by bringing in related lessons about math (weights, measures, fractions, etc.), science, business, etc.  The more educationally relevant the more school systems and parents will support it.This also makes me think that this idea could be an extension of the storefront concept that Jamie set up in his 'Food Revolution' TV series.  But of course there is a lot of opportunity there for development.  Thanks for the idea!

An excellent idea!If you can show how interesting creating food can be, and make it fun, creative and relevant, then the pupils would be willing to engage and play with the vegetables and utensils!This could lead the way to children been able to be independent and take pressure off mum and dad to make sure the kids are getting healthy meals.They could also learn about local/seasonal produce and the benefits of using these.
Great idea. Similar to the Lunchdate in Schools idea. Combining critical services like grocery provision and education to make life simpler for families.

I think this is quite an innovative idea if school were take on the full idea.  With so many parents working full time this could alleviate the pressure and encourage young people to take an active part in their family.  I feel another positive of this concept is the idea that children cook together, maybe it would stay with them thoughout their adult life so they would cook together as a family.  The meals that the young people would be making need to be looked at carefully.  A few months ago my nephew made angel delight in his supposed cooking lesson!  The children at our local high school make meals which use very little transferable skills.  I would love to see this kind of concept being taken seriously by schools.  It could also incorporate cooking locally produced food which parents could pay for.

love it! just as the "role models" idea, I like that it bring kids into the kitchen and integrates them with food in a more practical way. I found this could be less abstract than telling kids about what ingredients, produces or type of foods are better than others, to actually provide healthy foods for them to try and like. (example: making and trying broccoli quiche, as opposed to being told by someone that broccoli is a good thing to eat) (also prepared dishes are closer to what you actually might find at the dinner table or a restaurant menu)

Great idea. Starting at school by giving children the knowledge on how to cook a simple but good meal should be very effective. And I agree with the "Last Class Of The Day" principle. In The Netherlands when I grew up, a weekly swimming class was mandatory for all primary school students. So why not cooking?
Creative time choice and leveraging of school facilities. Another approach/benefit: this could be an "after-school" program, not just a "last class of the day".

what_s_for_dinner_the_last_class_of_the_.title: WHAT'S FOR DINNER!?  - The last class of the day

py/tuple: Food Knowledge - To what extent is this concept teaching people about food knowledge?
It's teaching people a great deal about food knowledge
It's teaching people a moderate deal about food knowledge
It's teaching people a little about food knowledge
It's not focused on food knowledge
Cooking - Is this concept focused on getting people to cook?
It's all about getting people to cook
It's moderately about getting people to cook
It's getting people to cook a little
It's not focused on cooking at all
Originality - How original is this idea?
This idea is extremely original
This idea is somewhat original
This idea has some originality about it
I have seen this idea before
Scalability - How scalable is this idea across communities and geographies?
This idea can be scaled across many communities and places
This idea can be scaled but needs some work

Couldn't agree more. I really love this idea, because it has so many layers: it makes the best use of available arable lots, gives a sense of purpose to kids and helps them connect with nature.I think we should hear more about these kind of initiatives in the mainstream media.You have my applause. ;-)

A really great idea.  An urban farm project could also take advantage of vacant lots in urban areas by creating multiple farm plots. Each plot could feature a different collection of produce and the teams of kids could rotate between them to learn about all of them and help cultivate them over the summer.  This would not only help to educate kids on the variety of great food that can be grown and eaten locally but also produce a harvest that they can sell at farmers markets, learning about costs, profits and the math involved in running a business along the way.  A bonus would be community beautification as the vacant lots would be cleaned up and populated with beautiful gardens.  I have a couple other ideas about how this might work.  I will build on it.  Thanks for the inspiration!

comments.text: I like this idea, and it inspired my half-baked idea of Food Assembly!

I like the concept of 'Show and Tell'.  But my concern would be that in poorer communities some kids might not have parents with the care or financial resources to provide them with a lunch that is comparable to the others in the class.  That underpriveliged kid would then feel humiliated when they publicly ended up on the loosing end of the 'lunch rating' spectrum.  And tasting other kids lunches unfortunately would bring up all sorts of possible problems from parental consent, to sharing issues, food allergies, etc.Maybe another approach would be to have a show and tell centered around the craziest thing that the kids ate recently.  So the kids describing the weird thing their mom made and then the process of them eating it might get kids yelling 'ewww!' or 'yuck' initially but then interested in tasting crazy things themselves so that they can tell the class about it.Or the the vegetable that they just had which they thought they were going to hate but ended up liking.  Which might get other kids interested in trying it themselves.  Whatever it takes to get kids talking and sharing and excited about eating new foods that they might not have been interested in before.But your initial idea is a good one to work with.  Thanks for the interesting concept!
Yup, good idea. We have a lot to learn from Thaler and Sunstein - their work on Choice Architecture has massive implications for society.
Similar to 'Evidence trail'
A very nice and interactive idea. And it has a lot to build on. The recipe archive can go a lot of places.
I can just picture the kid at the supermarket bugging his dad to get more veggies for his school lunchbox =)

comments.text: Thanks for your comments.   Although, yes i agree that involving the Government in passing laws may be a bit far fetched.  However, consider this... if the initiatives are only funded through "support" from Government then it is only a matter of time before the Politician who assists with this, moves areas, moves states and then the initiative falls on the ground.  Passing a law ensures its permanency in the Schools not set by boundaries of particular politicians but an agreement that is voted and counted and secured for the future.  By not exploring this option the idea of educating kids in nutrition is a passing fad, and unfortunately it won't last.  Re: Rose Keith, in Australia we don't really care about naming ideas as socialist etc.  As long as they work!  Any hoo, how is "revamping policy" not a socialist movement?!!  Thanks for your comments... Good Luck to all
Apologies for double post... technical hitch!

I've applauded because I agree that children need to have the opportunity to grow, prepare and eat their own food.  Much better to encourage this at school with their peers, rather than be restricted/influenced by their parents' food habits. A child's sense of pride in a job well done and the fun they'll have along the way will be the best encouragement they could ever have. Although I'm not totally enamoured with the 'passing laws' side of this, I do strongly believe that examples need to be set from the top. Government needs to support schools with more money for better cafeteria food, school kitchen gardens and regular exciting cookery classes.  I agree, learning about nutrition is an important life skill but link this with encouraging children to grow/prepare/cook healthy food, have fun with it and learn to love it.  This way their tastes will be influenced long before they can necessarily understand the science behind their choices.

I've applauded because I agree that children need to have the opportunity to grow, prepare and eat their own food.  Much better to encourage this at school with their peers, rather than be restricted/influenced by their parents' food habits. A child's sense of pride in a job well done and the fun they'll have along the way will be the best encouragement they could ever have. Although I'm not totally enamoured with the 'passing laws' side of this, I do strongly believe that examples need to be set from the top. Government needs to support schools with more money for better cafeteria food, school kitchen gardens and regular exciting cookery classes.  I agree, learning about nutrition is an important life skill but link this with encouraging children to grow/prepare/cook healthy food, have fun with it and learn to love it.  This way their tastes will be influenced long before they can necessarily understand the science behind their choices.

There are basic things a child should learn to be a successful adult (like math and reading) and nutrition is one of the most vital and valuable things to learn early on.To me this is the most basic change that needs to take place - it's a simple solution compared to some of the other concepts, but one of the most powerful in terms of the impact it can have in a short period of time.

I agree that health and nutrition need to be included in our public education classrooms. However, to make it against the law not to teach this type of curriculum leads us down a slippery slope toward a socialist society. Schools can offer the basic tools and involved parents can push their districts to revamp policy. I have been able to do this and so far have been successful in getting much of the junk food out of vending machines in my district. It is not always an easy task and can be time consuming, but if we can effect change we need to MAKE the time.

think_sex_education_change_content_pass_.title: Think Sex Education, change content, pass a bill to make food educ. compulsory

Imagine a similar type of farming game, where the virtual farm is connected to an actual farm.  In addition to the animated game, there would be a video feed of the kids' plots of land, they would get to know the actual farmers etc.  When the fresh, healthy and organic food is harvested, it is then Fed Exed to the players.
a_virtual_farm_game_where_the_food_grown.creator: 2a2d91f284214400f25281b4bced1c92

comments.text: Great idea! I've heard a kind of cross-reality facebook game in japan, where palyers have to complete certain tasks to get "hidden treasure" in the virtual game. I will see if i can find the example!

a_virtual_farm_game_where_the_food_grown.title: A virtual Farm Game, where the food grown is Fed Exed to the players

food_superpowers_for_kids.creator: 98302eb9727009d08199b25b7b72b1cb
food_superpowers_for_kids.title: Food Superpowers for Kids

shopping_cart_provokes_healthier_purchas.description: A multi compartment shopping cart, where the compartments represent a healthy balance of food, such as 50% of all food having to be fruit & vegetables. So families and kids automatically shop "the right way".
shopping_cart_provokes_healthier_purchas.creator: a7c15c415c37626de8fa648127ba1ae5

comments.text: I love it! it has this elegant "Nudge" factor... why just educate kids, educate everyone!

I just realized that the mass production of this cart would be costly and it would make it harder for food markets to want to spend the money. If it's possible I think it would be cool to have the same concept but it would be attachable to existing shopping carts on wither the left side or right side. Also that way the children would stay next to their parents. This way you use less platics and you save a lot of money on the wheels so it would cut costs.

You know this is a great concept. I have seen shopping carts that have a little passenger seat with a TV in it. Instead they should spend 1/20 of that cost to have a little side tray that attaches to shopping carts that has your concept. So variety of foods can be put in portions.

This would work for any age kid, but I can just picture young kids with a mini-sized version of this cart walking through the grocery aisle with their parents. 
Someone submitted an inspiration to reserve the lower shelves for kid items. If we combine that idea, and the idea of a colored compartmental cart for different fruit group items, I think the grocery space would be a lot more kid-friendly. This would be a great start for forming a good shopping habit for fresh foods.
When you do your groceries, you also shop for drinks, right?

I see a great potential on this concept, however the flaws are around a realistic everyday shopping experience: - To what extent are kids involved in the supermarket shopping scenario to learn from it? Aren't parents mostly relying on online shopping or possibly doing it on breaks without the kids going along with them?- Where would tuna/bean cans be placed in the cart for example? Frozen ready veggie ready meals? Wouldn't shoppers consider their choices as 'healthy' when they can place them in the vegetable compartment even if they are not fresh products?One way to tackle this could be by inspiring people with simple recipes while doing their shopping (e.g. on a small screen embedded on the cart) always based on fresh-seasonal products and possibly also on offer.

I just came across this article on an experiment from Wholefoods on a grocery cart, different concept but based on the idea of helping you make the right choices while shopping:http://www.engadget.com/2012/02/29/whole-foods-experimenting-with-kinect-powered-shopping-carts/

I love this idea! It focuses on behavior change instead of learning to change, which is great if we are targeting young kids. Most food psychology books state that we don't really make conscious choices on what or how much we eat; most it those choices, rather, are made by what we see visually. If we can adopt this shopping cart for kids, it will teach them the behavior of buying foods by food group, and the repitition of the action will create eventual behavioral change.

Good idea with a lot of potential!  I think Teresa's comment below is interesting.  Since food companies would probably lobby against it's use at typical markets, maybe this type of cart would simply target the stores that the food companies compete to get into such as Wal-Mart, Whole Foods and Trader Joes.  Those stores can probably dictate terms more than others.  Not to mention that it could reinforce each store's health conscious brand identity.  What if the cart could also scan the items that were going into it and then send information to the shoppers smart phone or iPad?  Put in a chicken, some parsley and fava beans and the cart would then send a list of possible recipes that could be made with these ingredients.  The shopper would then save the ones that were interesting and continue on, adding the other needed ingredients and building meals for the week.  Sort of like a shopping list on the fly.  The cart could also give nutritional information.  Drop in some carrots and it could tell you about the vitamins it has, growing season, where the carrots were sourced from, best preparations, etc.  Also, as it scans, the cart could keep a running tally of price, price per lb./g, total calorie content, etc. and give suggestions on how to nutritionally balance what is being bought.  I guess I am thinking of the cart as health and nutrition translator and coach for the shopper.Lots of fun directions to develop this.Thanks for the concept!

This is a good match to the plate concept. Perhaps the categories should be more open, to address vegetarians or other sorts of food restrictions/preferences. One suggestion would be using other terminology, such as Proteins (which would encompass meat, eggs, fish, soy protein and other suitable substitutes).

Great concept. I think in isolation this concept will not achieve what we are set out to achieve. However, this should definitely be an add on to some of the other proposed concepts. 
Good stuff.

Ok, I know the Built On This time is over (I found out of the page today) but this idea came to my mind. Finally parents buy the food, let give them a glimpse of the future. What the cart should do is to portray in the front of it or the side of eat, in a little screen, how would a child of average age 10 will look like if it ate for 15 years the type of food that is inside the cart. Finally, the blow to your mind, when you get your ticket in the cashier, at the back of it, you will find printed the image of your virtual child that ate for the next 15 years exactly what you bought for that week.

Great idea. I am wondering if goverment and corporations are as concerned as they say or just as concerned as they should be. A cool way to implement this is to add some bonus for the buyer. Having a full veggie section gives you a discount on the overall expense of your grocerys. That way you add better food to your diet simply to get a reward.

It would be great to have slogans on shopping carts added to motivate shoppers.  Something from Michael Pollen perhaps:  "Eat Food.  Not too much.  Mostly Plants."  
Or what if you could set your cart to help you shop according to specific diet?  The stores would benefit in drawing shoppers who are on a fad diet and at the same time the shoppers would get the extra help they may need.  In addition to fad diets the cart could help with healthier choices.
I really like the idea of reminding people about wiser choices at time of purchase.
Cool idea!  Keeping it simple and visual!

My daughter who is 3, only wants to go shopping with me if we go to the Trader Joe's that has mini-carts for her to be the shopper. She feels so proud pushing it through the aisles and filling it up. I agree that this concept would be perfect for this kind of mini kid shopping cart.  3 year olds love to categorize almost as much as they love feeling like they are in charge:). I also know of some parents who bring their own mini shopping cart (purchased at any toy store) to grocery stores that don't have them.  You could sell this version at a toy store. Could a grocery store possibly stop you from bringing it in? I doubt they would.Combine this idea with the kid sized grocery store (or section of a grocery store) and my daughter would be in heaven, and taking ownership of her already pretty good eating habits.

I really like this idea. It's simple and may be just the nudge people need. However, I'm concerned about how it fits with the economics of a grocery store. A grocer like Whole Foods might use it, but the big chains likely make large margins on junk food, not to mention the advertising dollars / product placement throughout the store. Part of the reason why we eat the way we do, is because junk food providers spend way more $ on advertising than fresh food providers. 
Maybe this could be sold as an insert, that a health-conscious shopper could buy, to use in any cart at any store. Bring your own bags, bring your own cart divider. If you want to get really fancy, people could design their own inserts based on their dietary goals.

A nice idea, but what about dairy, fats and oils? Protein rich foods tend to be denser than fruit and veg so they need less space, whilst grains, breads etc, tend to be bulkier. The real challenge is not getting the right stuff into the trolley but making sure that the food is eaten when it reaches home.

A nice idea, but what about dairy, fats and oils? Protein rich foods tend to be denser than fruit and veg so they need less space, whilst grains, breads etc, tend to be bulkier. The real challenge is not getting the right stuff into the trolley but making sure that the food is eaten when it reaches home.

The great thing about this idea is that it should quite effectively help aid behavioural change. Most of the time people just need a small reminder to change their ways, but sometimes it's not present. I'll be interested to see if this works over a wider population of people.

This is great. Maybe we could even work with supermarkets to color code stuff so that little kids could easily find the right "color" stuff to put into the carts. It could become a game in the supermarket.
Great idea... I can already picture the kids telling the parents off as they try to put a packet of buiscuits in the trolley!
Love the idea but I'd find it intrusive, as if I put some crisps in the wrong box I'd get a dodgy look at the counter.
I like how visual and simple this is.  This could be implemented right now.
I like the visual/spatial/tactile process of filling the cart, plate, etc.

wow! I think this is a great idea because it recognizes the large influence parent's choices have in shaping kid's behaviors over time. By promoting healthier eating at home, I would expect kids to become familiar (and developed less resistance) to all food groups. It starts at home, kids tend to imitate what adults do, that's how they learn pretty much everything.

How about a more universally accepted version (that will work for every healthy diet), where there is 3/4 of a cart for fresh produce, and just 1/4 for everything else?
Because, for example, I don't eat grains or animal products, and I would definitely not want to promote the idea to kids that they are supposed to, since they are not a necessity for health.
The overall idea is kind of neat though.  Giving people a visual sense of how much whole, fresh foods they might want to get is a good way to go about it.  Though I imagine that you might have some conflicts of interest with the stores, since they tend to earn more money on the heavily processed foods, and get incentives from corporations to have high profile product placements for junk food, and they might not want to jeopardize their profit margins just to keep people healthy.

Great idea.
Have a look at Nicola's final design, similar to yours except being a plate.
http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_nuIO6IH8heA/SKhBUKBM5EI/AAAAAAAAAO0/CWm6bZNfjQE/s1600-h/DSCF8384.JPG

This is cool. The first thing that came to mind was the nutritional pyramid we all love from grade school. Somehow that idea could inspire the look of the cart. Plus each section could have a handle and be removed for easy shopping.

I think this a great idea. It would not only work for children but for adults as well. Could we also assigned a section of unhealthy food section on the trolley? Imagine standing next to someone at the check out with a trolley full of junk and unhealthy foods. What would the person next to you think? And would you want to be seen as  an healthy person by a shopping trolley full of items in the junk food section of your trolley.
Great idea! Would be cool if a handheld device was added in which kids could use it to take pictures of " qr codes" and learn more about foods they are putting in cart!

This is great! Visual Feedback/Nudging integrated into people's regular grocery shopping routine. In addition to a brand new multi-compartment cart, perhaps a cheaper compartment kit could be sold/distributed to grocery stores, enabling them to retrofit their existing carts (more palatable than the >$100/new cart price tag). What other things could be done to encourage grocery stores to adopt and scale this idea? For "Whole Foods", it might fit with the brand/reputation they are trying to convey. How about other grocery stores?

shopping_cart_provokes_healthier_purchas.title: Shopping cart provokes healthier purchases

comments.text: Every child should have the opportunity to grow their own food. This would create a relationship between the food source and what the eat. They can even raise small animals: chickens, rabbits, fish. When animals are humanely raised with free ranging and organic feeds, quality of the meat is greatly improved. This may have the affect of creating more vegetarians, vegans just because of the act of slaughtering the animal. They should also learn that we do not need a lot of meat to fufil our needs for protein. There are many non-meat ways to get the protein they need.

super_foods_recipe_game_contest_for_kids.description: Using the Aggregate Nutrient Density Index (ANDI scores), that Dr. Joel Fuhrman developed to score foods for nutritional quality as the game scoring system, hold a contest where kids can create their own yummiest recipes with the highest nutritional rating, in several different categories.  Winning recipes are scored on nutritional quality primarily, but with bonus points for yumminess, as judged by a panel of kids from all over the world.
super_foods_recipe_game_contest_for_kids.creator: c09d9310c3ca89257885d8363f40c09e

comments.text: I think you're onto something -- we need to make this a challenge activity/game-thing, where kids get to learn how to make the healthiest foods, but ones they like.

You could have a personal page where you ranked the yumminess of things you've tried, so that you can maybe print out your own recipe book, tailored to your own taste!  Your scores wouldn't be made public, or at least wouldn't count in either versions of the game/contest, since it would make it too easy to mess with the system.

Aha, sorry if I misunderstood the frequency.
You could also add yumminess in to the mix-and-match function, so that next to the nutritional quality, you could see a yumminess score based on what people have liked before.

Sure, you could do a companion non-reality game as well.  I was thinking that the website would have a function where you could mix and match ingredients to see what their nutritional quality (score) was, and you certainly could make that more gamelike, with some kind of amusing extras, and maybe a bit of a storyline and characters doing interesting things.
And this is more than a one-off, in my mind.  It's a regular thing, where maybe each month or two there was a contest for a different category, and then at the end of the year a new recipe book would be published with the winning recipes.  So, there's no reason this couldn't continue indefinitely. :-)

Interesting concept! Do you think it could be turned into a game like Farmville (or my own concept here: Fresh Food Empire), instead of a one-off competition? That would maybe make it even more attractive for kids to participate.

super_foods_recipe_game_contest_for_kids.title: Super Foods! recipe game contest for kids

experiments_you_can_eat.description: A kids online show and cookbook explaining the science of food and food preperation. Through experimenting in the kitchen and with lifestyle chioces viewers have fun watching experiments that ultimately demonstrate why fresh is best and how different choices impact our life and health.
experiments_you_can_eat.creator: df1d7c99f41588ec0f1f0b3cd2364c3a

comments.text: Great idea! Sort of like Alton Brown-meets-Mr. Wizard food science show for kids.  Or that short-lived Ted Allen show about testing food assumptions, etc in a lab-ish setting.  Kids might really get into a well illustrated and fun description of, say, how food rots.  Or whatever.  I still remember the show '3-2-1-Contact' from when I was a kid.  It was a sort of mash-up show of science, art, sketch comedy, etc. A kid-food-science show could be great fun and ignite a lot of interest.  Kid-gastronomy! Great stuff!

This would be very cool.  In fact, the In fact, in the UK, one of Jamie Oliver's friends, Heston Blumenthal bases most of his work around chemistry.  From the royal society of chemistry, you can see some ideas and videos on kitchen chemistry:
http://www.rsc.org/education/teachers/learnnet/kitchenchemistry/00_video.htm

I think taping into the science side of food preparation can be very attractive to some kids. Once they learn about nutritional aspects in food they could learn to read and interpret labels in the "chemically enhanced food" they like so much.

experiments_you_can_eat.title: Experiments you can eat

epic_win_level_up.description: Imagine an online community for those who love local food. To grow and maintain social identity, badges or levels could be achieved based on trips to farms or framers’ markets. For example, two pounds of local asparagus from Edgar Farms could move you to a level six foodie (another +3 if you blog about it and +2 if you include photos).
epic_win_level_up.creator: d67654ba4567d6b8e71db0a1ea0d13ee

comments.text:
Thanks Matthew. I just took a look at your post. Fascinating how similar ideas bubble up.
As for gardening...some love it some don't...but as Wendall Berry said, "Eating is an agricultural act." I'm okay with a love of food starting with eating and only moving to the garden for the truly interested.

I think this sort of approach could be really powerful - I cited the same talk in a post I made :)
I think buying locally sourced foods is one way of making this work - but it might not work so well for underprivileged kids. Especially as this is targeted at children, I reckon if more attention was given to growing vegetables it might garner a more level playing field.
However, this starts a bit of a discussion on whether an interest in gardening is necessarily the best way to create interest in food...

epic_win_level_up.title: Epic Win - Level-up

making_sense_of_portions_and_proportions.description:
Are we losing sense of what a healthy-sized meal portion looks like?
Are we losing sense of what a healthy-proportioned body looks like?
making_sense_of_portions_and_proportions.creator: 4e57ec6b9ec044e7c5c234542f2299d3

comments.text: This is a tough one but I totally agree.  Larger and larger portion sizes are used as a marketing tool.  Actually, we should be working to cut down on the food we eat.  The U.S eats twice as much daily as some of the poorest nations in the world.  Our caloric moderation is a matter of both personal responsibility and social responsibility.  And society's 'This is me, accept me as I am' mantra, as nice as it sounds, is unfortunately just not a healthy trajectory to be on.  The goal, I think, is to figure out a message that is supportive to everyone ('Let's all work together and get in shape!") rather than judgmental ("You are overweight!  It's time to get in shape!")  It is much easier to make changes and do the tough things while in community with supportive people than on your own.

making_sense_of_portions_and_proportions.title: Making sense of portions and proportions

comments.text: This is a wonderfully simple and easily implementable ideacards are tangible, collectable, swappable  kids love collecting  and cards can be colourful, informative. You can imagine a system of "levels" too, easy recipes for beginners and more complex later. Connect this with a virtual world too, like Pokemon.

fruit_boost_an_exciting_learning_experie.description: Fruit Boost is a service that will visit schools in socially deprived areas of the US and get children excited about fresh fruit for the first time in their lives. It provides an exciting and empowering atmosphere in which they will learn about leading a healthy lifestyle through the experimentation, teamwork and communication involved in making fresh organic smoothies together.
fruit_boost_an_exciting_learning_experie.creator: ba8e7c280ecbdeb475b8a3883a36f4d2

comments.text: Thanks for your comments...a 'juicing bag' sounds very interesting and maybe more universal for smoothie cocktails! Its crazy how many children don't know what a kiwi or mango is...these are some of the most sweet and enjoyable foods on the planet and kids in America (and the UK) are scared of them! I hope this concept helps them to realise they're not so bad and that they'll end up pestering mum and dad for more fruit to use with their new toy :)
All kinds of health stuff can be put into a smoothie and not taste as bad to a kid (e.g. spinach, coconut juice, flax seed).
Oh, and you could also send kids home with a "juicing bag" that's just a bit of fabric which they can put fruits in and squeeze to make juice at home.

I really like this idea.  It's fun and exciting, and if you add fresh greens, such as spinach, kale, beet greens, wheatgrass, and wild edibles like lambs quarters and wood sorrell (both are very common "weeds"), to your juices you'll have a super power packed food to give these kids.  I've done green smoothie making with kids, using a human powered blender and fruits and greens from the farmer's market and the kids had a lot of fun, though many were wary of fruit, which was just bizarre!

fruit_boost_an_exciting_learning_experie.title: Fruit Boost - an exciting learning experience letting children design and make their own smoothies from scratch

comments.text: Similar in theory to Adriana Olmos's inspiration about the 'La Machine' game http://tinyurl.com/2g9zyeu  I think you are correct in that we need to teach kids to be interested in the workings of their entire body.  Not just how something fatty, salty or sweet tastes good in their mouth but also how that food supplies their body with nutrients or gets converted into fat.  And, yes, how it makes it's exit.  Our body, and its relationship to the food we eat, is a multifaceted fascinating thing.

Oh how true! And so we need to fast-forward the development of diagnostic toilets as depicted here at 2:00. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Cri0Si70gU I think Toto and Matsushita are on it. http://www.caslon.com.au/fridgenote3.htm quotes a Matsushita spokesperson in 2006:"You may think a toilet is just a toilet, but we would like to make a toilet a home health measuring center. We are going to install in a toilet devices to measure weight, fat, blood pressure, heart beat, urine sugar, albumin and blood in urine."

start_at_the_beginning.description: Change packaging so that cartoons, prizes and toys are not there to entice our children. Marketing food to our children that is bad for their health should be illegal.  Sugary cereal commercials with cartoon characters should not be allowed.  How many commercials have you seen for healthy products?  Put a prize in the bag of apples or the all natural granola.  If the children become accustomed to eating well at home then they will make the better choice at school.
start_at_the_beginning.creator: 41ecf2deaafbd695a2e23a12692ad0b2
start_at_the_beginning.title: Start at the beginning

kids_vegetable_growing_kit.description: Terracycle (a company that upcycles waste), has been producing/selling these small Kids Vegetable/Herb Growing Kits. The planters are made from Stonyfield Yogurt cups filled with compost, seeds are embedded in the carboard, and growing instructions are included. The kits are simple, easy to use (especially as the seeds are for good "beginner" plants), and affordable (probably partly why they were picked up by Walmart).
kids_vegetable_growing_kit.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: I really like this one... very clever and fun ...

This is good as it encourages recycling and sustainability.  I think Demian has something about things taking a long time to grow.  Perhaps classes could set up webcams to make a time lapse video of things growing to add some fun to the whole experiment.  Would would be even more fantastic would be if the pots were bio-degradable and they could then just be planted into full garden after a certain size.  I don't know if any yoghurt makers and making biodegradable pots.

I think I may have the web service to solve our "reminder" problem:
SproutRobot (web service). Check out their website: http://sproutrobot.com/
This web service tells you when to plant fruits & veggies in your garden, AND sends you seeds when the time is right.

Good point about keeping kids engaged in "kid time". The email tips/reminders sounds like one way of doing it. Guess this could also be an instant message, sms, etc (depending on what a kid is using/has access to).

I think it is an interesting beginning to a good idea.  As great as re-use/recycling is, I find the straight re-use of the yogurt cups a bit odd looking.  As soon as the kit lid is thrown away (or recycled) the information, story and brand are lost.  But I like the main idea of trying to excite and engage kids in taking part in growing their own vegetables and herbs.  The trick, though, is holding their attention.  Growing stuff takes a long time (in kid time) and it might be pretty easy to loose interest.  Maybe this could be connected to daily emails to give the kid more tips and info about the stuff they are growing and to remind them to water, etc.  Whatever it takes to keep them interested.  Good stuff!

kids_vegetable_growing_kit.title: Kids Vegetable Growing Kit

the_people_s_grocery_west_oakland_.description: An old liquor store was converted into a health food store in a very unhealthy part of West Oakland. This is the stores farm which is   cultivated by local community members and schools.

grow_play_cook_food_fight.title: Grow -> Play -> Cook -> FOOD FIGHT!

vertical_farming.description: Vertical farming is a 30 story tower in a city that would feed 50,000 people. The tower would house crops - hydroponics - as well as livestock such as chicken and goats.
vertical_farming.creator: d1aacd22b4aa8bdc73b7b0053eb8a201

comments.text: I love the idea of bringing farming to urban areas and integrating people back into the cycle of farm to food!

vertical_farming.title: Vertical Farming

role_model_chefs_teens_teaching_younger_.description: Teenagers will go through a chef training program to teach cooking classes in elementary and middle schools.  Both teens and younger children will learn the benefits or healthy eating and get excited to cook with their friends and family.
role_model_chefs_teens_teaching_younger_.creator: 3db2357725166252ced4f99e928b8ffe

comments.text: I really like your approach and find it very promising. One short notice. Propably it might be difficult to recruit older students that act as cooking coaches. It will be critical to communicate the personal benefit that one potentially has, by taking part in the project. One such benefit could be the development of core competencies that are needed in todays business environment. Such as inspiring other people, educating others, changeing perspectives etc.By that you could highlight the personal outcome for older students that cannot be motivated only by doing something useful.

genius idea to work with the natural tendency of children to ape the older ones as opposed to fighting it. though i believe getting the teenagers genuinely exited about teaching and sharing may be slightly tricky. perhaps team cooking games and competitions can also help excite the kids further.

I may be echoing other posts, but I like how this idea bridges between young and older students. This concept has allot of potential, especially if healthy cooking/eating practices are reinforced at home. It seems critical to communicate the "why" in all of this. Showing students the rewards of a better diet and lifestyle. I've only started eating better in the last few years after realizing that I am not invincible and the importance of consistent energy in the workplace.

Children will, in the most part, make their own choices on what they eat and like. I believe the decision come from a perceived experience of food. Also, young people dont need (in their own minds) to worry about health. This concept is great because it dosent hang on scaring kids with health issues, it changes the perceived experience with the influence of piers. If you were to bridge the gap between the older and younger students in the lesson, the younger students would see and make the link of growing older, becoming cooler, eating smarter. Good luck with this project.

Jackie, this is a great idea! I hope it spreads to all corners of the country. It's hard for busy parents to convince their kids to eat healthy when what they get in school is easy to prepare processed food. It can be easy when given the right tools at an early age. When young impressionable minds are susceptible to the pressure of what all their friends are eating (after this program more fresh veggies and grains!), with the helpful guidance of older kids - the healthy path will be easy to pave. Good luck to you!
This is awesome!  Great way to build awareness!!!

Jackie is well on her way to revolutionize the way kids eat and look at food, through mentoring and participation. She's a cooking instructor, specializing in teaching children how to eat healthy while having fun and she's getting her RD and Master's in Nutrition. What's not to love?

Mustafa:  I've been teaching kids cooking classes for several years now and most of my classes are actually half girls, half boys.  Their parents aren't forcing them to take it either.  Kids more than ever are curious about food and I give the food programs on TV (like Iron Chef and Top Chef) a lot of credit for getting us to think more thoughtfully about we are eating and get excited about cooking!  It's no surprise that enrollment at culinary schools is up -- there's something *cool* about being a chef now.  We need to use this to our advantage and draw kids in the same way, but focus on teaching them good eating habits and how to make better food choices.  When I first started teaching I was shocked to find that kids now have more developed palates than I did at their age.  They are serious little foodies!!

To ah-nah-EES]:  Believe it or not I read an article about a kids cooking show not too long ago.  There's one in Chicago called Jr. Cuisine Cooking Show and another in Tulsa called Cook Time with Remmi.  I think it's a great way of teaching kids but I just hope the kids actually get to cook what they learn about in their own homes with their parents so they can get the full experience !

Patrick:  Thanks for your comment.  I envision that if this idea would come to fruition we would absolutely use the facilities of culinary institutes to teach the teens.  But training doesn't necessarily need to happen in a culinary school.  Lots of the training can be done right in classrooms and school kitchens too, which makes this project accessible to everyone -- even areas that may not have a culinary school nearby.

Emir:  As a culinary instructor, I know the importance of giving kids the space they need to explore and experiment.  Discovering a whole new world of foods, tastes, and textures is exciting and will surely get kids to take ownership of their food choices, which is the most important part of this project -- teaching them about food but also showing them how to properly fuel their bodies so they feel great, have lots of energy, etc.

i think.... if children understand why food tastes good and bad and how you can control these variables they will "do the maths" ..showing simply is not personable enough, they need to have new found knowledge and want to 'experiment'... set menus and meals are the wrong way to learn how to cook in my opinion and learning how to cook an actual meal rather then understand what happens in the process of cooking and eating from anyone on a philosophical level, is quite damaging....theory is way more important, and the doing, can be done as part of trial an error,.. on a free form basis..

You're right; kids need to be taught these skills by slightly older people who they can relate to! If the Vegetable Circus Stage Shows & After-School Programs concept wins, we plan on including cooking education in our after-school programs, in a manner very much like your concept! I'm glad to see this overlap!
Brill concept- I have previously taught kids cooking classes with  teenage chef assistants and the younger kids were always more receptive to the teens than myself as an adult.
Jackie - love this! This is also part of my concept - getting kids cooking for kids, and passing on their enthusiasm for good food.

Kids teaching kids seems like it would be be very effective. It reminds me that many of our schools now have culinary academies, as well as other non-profits helping kids learn to cook: see Guy Fieri's feature on Worth our Weighthttp://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20100909/NEWS/100909525/1349?Title=Santa-Rosa-cafe-wows-Fieri

I actually see this as a great model for a TV show. it seems to me that kids do look up to teenagers. having other kids be part of the show as cooking assistants could also increase the factor of identification. I like this idea since, by picking recipes that are kid friendly, it shows that cooking is within the range of kids and teenagers, and, as some of the inspirations were pointing out, kids/teens do tend to eat things they have helped prepared. the hurdle is trying to address is the prevalent mentality of telling kids to stay away from the kitchen ("cause is dangerous", "cause they will make a mess", etc) and instead integrate them with activities and recipes that are age appropriate.
I think more guys like cooking than one would think. I made a cookbook when I was in elementary school.

I really like the idea. but how can you carry a teenager to go to a chef training program unless they already like food and cooking? - I believe, the girls might go for that, but not the guys and the main aim is addressed to both girls and boys- I HOPE my predictions are wrong and the idea WORKS.

role_model_chefs_teens_teaching_younger_.title: Role Model Chefs:  Teens teaching younger kids how to cook and eat healthier!

jamie_s_high_school_vegetable_competitio.description: With Jamie Oliver as the host, harness team spirit and have high schools compete against each other on this TV show to research and then make the best dish using the featured vegetable.
jamie_s_high_school_vegetable_competitio.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Thanks for the comment Aaron!  My thinking is that kids are going to watch TV anyway.  And they usually watch pretty ridiculously vacuous stuff.  So to produce a TV show that is actually trying to present knowledge about healthy food and encourage healthy eating choices I think is a good thing.  And, as you mention, to do so in a fun competitive format could really attract kid's attention.Also, I think this show would be the catalyst for a large amount of educational opportunities.  The schools that participate in the competition could generate a huge amount of curriculae as they prepare in the months before the show.  History lessons to research the origins of the selected vegetables, farm visits to learn about agriculture and proper cultivation, recipe development and writing lessons, in-school cooking class pre-competitions to select the final team to compete, etc.  There is a lot of potential there for building knowledge about vegetables.  And, considering that the last time Jamie took a camera into an American classroom and the kids didn't know what a tomato was... we have a lot of work to do.I think a competition based reality show would be a great way to hget kids excited about cooking and eating healthy food.  And educate them in the process.  So a little time in front of the TV to help build knowledge of, and interest in healthy food I think is a good trade-off.Thanks again Aaron!  Good stuff!

Although I agree, its not great to encourage children to sit infront of a TV, on the larger scale, I have always liked the relationship competition has with knowledge and awareness. 
The show should try to become something schools really value being on which could increase their reputation. Teaming up in a competition will always open opportunities for collaborative learning and sharing of ideas, which is never a bad thing.
Food competition formatted shows are very popular right now - I can see the programme writers and production companies quickly adapting to the format described or one similar without a great deal of difficulty. 
It would be interesting to try and pitch it in the middle for example, shows like The Simpsons have the ability to cross the boundary and work on a child and adult level (I know this brief is primarily for children)

Jonathan, thanks for the comment!  Sitting in front of the TV... I totally agree, not the most vigorous calorie burning activity that kids could be doing.  I guess, I am thinking that kids are going to sit in front of the TV no matter what, so there might as well be something on that educates them about vegetables and gets them interested in cooking and eating healthy food.  Instead of them just watching some vacuous reality show about punks living at the beach :).  But I do like your ideas.  It could definitely be incorporated into the concept somehow.  Maybe a major portion of the cooking competition happens, as you say, on an inter-school level, just as varsity sports does.  Schools compete with other participating schools in their area with winners going on to state level championships.  Winners of large region or state competitions would then compete against other winners on Jamie's show.  This might enable school enthusiasm to build and vegetables and healthy eating to stay in the student's conversation for a longer period of time.  Heck it could even get worked into the school curriculum somehow.  Thanks for the comment!

I like the idea, but was wondering about the fact that it is encouraging kids to sit in front of the TV. Would a Comedy Sportz High School League take off work better ( http://www.comedysportzla.com/education/high-school-league.html )? It would basically be a scholastic bowl style event, that would be run on a per high school basis. There would even be the possibility of selling tickets, to raise money for the school. Also, having multiple small events at many different high schools, would get a larger number of children involved. Additionally, any food cooked (or left overs) during the event could be given away to local families.

Meena, Ha!  That would be a lot of fun to produce a Jamie Oliver show.  Great idea to have people share their attempts at the show's featured recipes or other dishes featuring the episode's highlighted ingredient.  It would be super important to build a robust online home for this show to build a community, share ideas and to keep kids attention.  Maybe there could be a 'Vegipedia' section where people can contribute information about the featured vegetables, posting growing tips, history facts, science experiments, etc.  And to make it fun for kids maybe there could be a section where kids could upload photos and descriptions of their failed attempts at cooking the featured recipe or the yuckiest tasting thing they ate with the featured ingredients.  Jamie has never been afraid to gross out kids from time to time:)  Then encourage kids to suggest fixes or different techniques to each other to improve their cooking attempts or make a dish taste as good as it possibly can.  Another thing to figure out would be a way to translate some of the show and website content to a texting situation.  If we can tie kids obsession with texting on their phones to a new excitement about food, (and a dose of competition and school spirit couldn't hurt) we will be on our way to much more healthy eating.  Thanks again for the comment!

Hey Demian... clearly they should have you on board as a producer of the show! Now that you focus us back on "getting kids interested and excited about healthy ingredients they might not normally eat" perhaps folks at home could be encouraged to upload images of their own dishes cooked with the featured ingredient to the show's website after each episode. They could show a couple of interesting ones on air the following week.

Great idea Meena!  A good way to engage not just the teams but the entire audience.  There are lots of features that could be developed to enrich this concept.  There could be video clips of each team, their high schools and the research projects that they conducted in preparation for the competition.  There could be a segment in which Jamie leads both teams through an experiment using the featured vegetable that might show the fun that can be had while learning the science behind good eating.  There could be special guest visits from celebrities kids enjoy like sports figures, pop stars or TV personalities.  There could even be a segment that somehow incorporates a video game tie-in.  The possibilities are many.  All, of course, to aid in building excitement for the main cooking competition between the high school teams.  A show like this has great potential for getting kids interested and excited about healthy ingredients they might not normally eat.  Thanks for your comment!

Great idea Meena!  A good way to engage not just the teams but the entire audience.  There are lots of features that could be developed to enrich this concept.  There could be video clips of each team, their high schools and the research projects that they conducted in preparation for the competition.  There could be a segment in which Jamie leads both teams through an experiment using the featured vegetable that might show the fun that can be had while learning the science behind good eating.  There could be special guest visits from celebrities kids enjoy like sports figures, pop stars or TV personalities.  There could even be a segment that somehow incorporates a video game tie-in.  The possibilities are many.  All, of course, to aid in building excitement for the main cooking competition between the high school teams.  A show like this has great potential for getting kids interested and excited about healthy ingredients they might not normally eat.  Thanks for your comment!
And maybe people could SMS in their votes as well  could enhance ratings and sense of audience involvement?

presenting_the_jonas_brothers_the_fresh_.creator: 69e69a7d5647f6e44e97a2c5057f2d91

comments.text: I think that this is really important.  When bombarded by poor role models and images, kids will start to make poor choices.  In a similar inspiration, 'Popeye & Spinach', a  strong association was made between spinach and health for people.  I think we need much more of this, on TV, in computer games, and in advertising.  I remember driving down freeways in the USA and seeing huge adverts to fast food places every junction.  This is like a 'red alert' for children.  If we're going to advertise the poor choices, we need to think about advertising the good choices, and raising awareness in as many situations as possible.

presenting_the_jonas_brothers_the_fresh_.title: Presenting The Jonas Brothers & The Fresh Vegetables

the_complement_guy_nutrition_quota_app.description: In Adams Morgan, a hip DC neighborhood, there is a complement guy who gives random passer bys complements -- ranging from nice boots, to "oowee." Good magazine reported on this "feel good" design contest, which reminded me of how happy the complement guy made me, and got me thinking about an app that distributes random and fun complements to kids who daily track their nutrition quota through an app.
the_complement_guy_nutrition_quota_app.creator: 30d7aaf0963f962998e931a248b420f4

comments.text: This kinda reminds me of the viral, "Free Hugs," video on YouTube. Because our collective food IQ is so low, we're going to need reinforcement ideas like the app you suggest. Perhaps, too, we could have a food ambassador in schools who rallies a team of students to do things like the compliment guy in DC and the free hugs guy...but centering around healthy food of course.

Celebrate a shift from short term, superficial thinking & a need for a quick fix to a sustainable lifestyle.

create_a_fresh_food_loyalty_card.description: Parents get extra discount, extra points on their loyalty card when purchasing fresh and healthy food
create_a_fresh_food_loyalty_card.creator: 9e3502cc75851bc901b51fbfc1e6db11

comments.text: Hi Dave,we could imagine that kids receive some cards (such as the baseball cards in the US) every time that they purchase fresh and healthy food with their parents. I have posted some pictures of a similar action performed by a store in Belgium (Delhaize). It was a great success my kids were asking for the Pixar cards and exchange them at school. As parents we were going to parties and we were exchanging the cards to complete our kids collection. During the operation 2.3 million cards were distributed. Parents received a pocket of 5 cards for every purchase of 20 in the store. Our kids were always asking when we go to buy foodstuffs...
Great idea - inspiring kids can only do so much if the parent's aren't motivated to buy fresh foods, but how could something like this be an incentive to kids as well as parents?
Excellent idea since the fresh food must be available to the kids in the first place. The parents must have an incentive and be rewarded for purchase decisions.

create_a_fresh_food_loyalty_card.title: Create a fresh food loyalty card

using_fresh_food_at_school_to_help_my_fa.description: Bring fun kid-themed Fresh Food Stands to schools to make fresh food as attractive to buy for a kid as it is to buy junk food. Assign fruits and vegetables specific scores they can accumulate to help their hero to defeat an enemy.
using_fresh_food_at_school_to_help_my_fa.creator: 263fe7899f87c408285c07a06cb36ac4
using_fresh_food_at_school_to_help_my_fa.title: Using fresh food at school to help my favorite heroes to defeat their enemies

good_food_advertising_campaign..description: Combine various good food stakeholders together to create a traditional advertising campaign that uses the same techniques and approaches as advertising giants.
good_food_advertising_campaign..creator: 4b75751e170e00f56886726c3f46eecd

comments.text: Yes, get those with a stake in the success of healthy food together for creating/funding new ways to encourage consumption (it doesn't just have to be advertising). Examples: http://bit.ly/cv5vBk (produce industry promoting fruits/veggies through store displays, online games, school materials), http://bit.ly/dCYXGP (~50 carrot growers $25M effort to promote baby carrots through portable snack packaging, vending machine availability, Halloween Scarrots,  iPhone app, TV spots, etc.).

Still does images make you always trust the quality that stands behind those pixels? I guess the most important are facts, things we can touch, smell or eat, I would not be satisfied with commercial ads, does not really count how many shops sell today GREAT looking vegetables, but that is all. A look. Same as the ads. An add would not tell you how that Tomato ended being a tomato, and the makeup, is all made to look, not to taste or to be healthy.

little_ambassadors_the_kitchen_rebellion.description: A brand new TV-show where the children are in charge! We want to challenge kids aged 9-12 years to increase their knowledge of good food. Through an inspiring and exciting tv competition they are challenged to explore where the food comes from and various ways to prepare it. Find little ambassadors labeled products in your local grocery store and visit our online community to vote and influence the program.
little_ambassadors_the_kitchen_rebellion.creator: 5511a25c1e90d5b54f6329da88055f22
little_ambassadors_the_kitchen_rebellion.title: Little Ambassadors - The kitchen rebellions

low_income_apartments_gardens_coaches_co.description: Gardens in low income subsidized apartment with garden coaches.
low_income_apartments_gardens_coaches_co.creator: ac9d5f6fc86324084ad296705d7fe89f

comments.text: I think this idea uses the right lever to solve a big part of the identified problem.

This has the added benefit of creating community ties, and therefore a support network between parents to help each other stick to a change in diet. The relationships created could be a spur to other community efforts.

Definitely a good idea I'm tryin to pull off in Portugal, hope u guys can find a way to get a go at it in the us.. also think about bringing school children to these community gardens, specially if there are elders involved.. It'll be a beautiful sight I promise.. A community garden tied to a school also helps bounding the school and the work that's done there to the community therefore it should also help in reducing drop out cases.. I'm hoping my project will also open up teachers mind to get into some more field work from farming to composting it provides a valuable experience driven opportunity for teachers to step outside their classroom and make classes much more interesting specially in the Science related classes and I'm hoping in a few (well maybe longer than I'd hope for) it'll become standard in any science class of any level of teaching.Once again best of luck!
The organisation Cultivating Community, in Australia, does community gardening with low income apartments in Melbourne.
Nice story & focus on where "food landscaping" could do a lot of good!

low_income_apartments_gardens_coaches_co.title: Low Income Apartments - Gardens - Coaches - Community

tool_kit_for_teaching_preschoolers_about.description: If parents do not know how to garden, cook and eat fresh foods they cannot teach their children to garden, cook and eat fresh foods. A TOOL KIT for parents of preschoolers would give specific resources to grow, prepare, cook and eat food. The TOOL KIST would be age specific so that the ideas fit the developmental stage of the child. There are tremendous resources across North America; we don’t need to create new programs or ideas to create a food revolution. We do need to change behaviors. We need to make growing food, cooking food and sharing those experiences with 1-4 year old children convenient, enjoyable and affordable for all parents. People are not engaging their young children in food growing and preparing because they do not have the knowledge or interest. As health and food are more publicly linked and as food safety rises as a concern people will get motivated but they will still need a clear set of instructions. The TOOL KIT would give options for growing food on balconies, in yards in urban gardens, it would explaine how Community shared agriculture allows you to get farm fresh food with less effort than visiting the supermarket and how cooking can be quick, easy and even fun.
tool_kit_for_teaching_preschoolers_about.creator: 94ba109684110eb825cb4fc2e6afc111

comments.text: This is a great idea, and I think it needs to be combined with other ideas to provide more incentive and opportunity. Sometimes parents not gardening or cooking isn't about lack of knowledge, but about lack of time. Maybe brainstorm ways that groups of parents can support one another with community garden plots or sharing produce, sharing gardening work, sharing cooking nights, etc. Also, brainstorm ways that more of the responsibility remains with the kids.

This is a great idea, and I think it needs to be combined with other ideas to provide more incentive and opportunity. Sometimes parents not gardening or cooking isn't about lack of knowledge, but about lack of time. Maybe brainstorm ways that groups of parents can support one another with community garden plots or sharing produce, sharing gardening work, sharing cooking nights, etc. Also, brainstorm ways that more of the responsibility remains with the kids.

Thanks for the link Meena, your idea looks great. I think Toolkits are the key if you want to bring about change, people need help and short of 1 one 1 consulting an appropriate and easy to use toolkit gives people the steps to follow and the confidence to take the first step!

Great concept. You might be interested in a toolkit idea about growing food I had over on the other challenge: http://bit.ly/9WnZeV I'd actually mapped it out towards the end of our inspiration phase and was then heartened to discover your concept along similar lines over here. Collaborative platforms indeed attract like-minds and breed synchronised thinking!

This is a great idea and rooted in 4 key themes!  The TOOLKIT could be a growing and integrated system of elements that are all linked (through branding) to be age-appropriate tools (digging, planting, seeds, recipe books, cooking tools), literature, story books, web-based information for sharing ideas, results (how my garden grows! what we cooked last night!) that can be built-up and COLLECTED over-time, handed-down. Imagine the pleasure of gift-giving to take the child to the next level.Imagine starting with a core kit that can be extended in multiple directions, say from eating first, to making to eat, to growing to eat, and ever more sophisticated.Perhaps also a reward system for contributing (pictures, recipes, ideas and adaptations) and earning community points to be set against acquisition of new elements.

I could not agree with your comments more. As the parent of an urban preschooler, I was just discussing with the preschool teacher how to get more experiential learning in the classroom - bring the outside in!  We were talking about baking bread and food preparation in general which led to a discussion around composting and a program my son's older grade-school aged sister and I are involved in at her school called Cool the Earth (www.cooltheearth.org) with the Garden Club and after school program. Cool the Earth has been very successful in educating kids about climate change, our carbon footprint and what we all can do to reduce it and one of the key reasons is their very good TOOL KIT. In the last 6-8 weeks of school, we were able to take 1,850 actions to reduce our impact on the earth (approximately equivalent to eliminating 140 cars from the road).  So much foundational work happens at that early age I am surprised there aren't more out there - especially for the preschool crowd.

tool_kit_for_teaching_preschoolers_about.title: TOOL KIT for teaching preschoolers about food
