promoting_health_food_like_junk_food_fun.description: Carrot Producers have invested $25 million in launching a multi-faceted campaign to promote baby carrots vs junk food including convenient packaging, vending machines, scarrots (for Halloween), a video game, social media, & tv ads. Check out the attached videos & website: http://www.babycarrots.com/
promoting_health_food_like_junk_food_fun.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Showing kids why and how fruits and vegetables. Examples of beautiful healthy foods make you stronger, taller, and smarter. More specifically how carrots are good for your eyes.  Perhaps examples of winning a race or a sports game or doing well on a test. My little sisters would not touch a vegetable. I told them that carrots would make their eyes bright and avocado would make their hair shiny. I told them that these beautiful foods would make them smarter and beautiful. They're perspective completed shifted and now they beg for vegetables because they feel/hope they will be rewarded with the positive effects. Perhaps using kid celebrities like Selena Gomez or Dora the Explorer as mediums for communication.
Why and how fruits and vegetables are beneficial*

I fully agree with @number9 on the fact that we need to have better products and packaging for fruits and vegetables. There is no point to pack the processed vegetables or fruit into similar wrapping as say Doridos.
How to promote fresh vegetables and fruit in their original form while there are thousands of small independent producers? Producers (apple, bean, strawberries etc.) should work together in similar way as the carrot manufacturers to spread high quality marketing messages. Producers should help grocery stores bundle up boxes from local fresh products similarly as Farm Fresh to You and others small producers who deliver seasonal boxes to people's homes. Safeway has their pasta corner, why couldn't they also have a vegetable and fruit box that has selection of seasonal local products with recipes. I'd pay extra for this and would love getting it without plastic wrapping.
I'm of the opinion that we should ban advertising to kids.  Perhaps certain types of "positive message" commercials like this could be allowed to be shown to kids.  Intriguing.

The wisdom of using modern marketing techniques to promote healthy eating and healthy foods is obvious, but we need a better product.  As vegetables go, raw  carrots are actually fairly low in nutritive value, and since it's so tough, we burn almost as many calories digesting carrots as we get out of them.
More than that, though, baby carrots are actually shaved or compressed from carrots not deemed worthy for sale as full carrots.  Rejected carrots, processed in factories, packaged in plastic, and sold to our kids.  Just another attempt to feed us all processed foods.  I'd rather promote whole carrots.
The campaign is creative but not necessarily effective. Does it really make people eat more carrots or does it just make them laugh and forget about it very soon?
Hilarious! But I think it still lands too heavily on that fact that they're NOT the snack you know and love.

"Oh baby!.... Carrots"Pretty funny.:)Definitely the 'scattershot' approach to marketing.  Try every angle and something will be bound to work.  I think the 'Baby Carrots' name works the best with the sexy ad.  Maybe they could do sub-brand names for the other angles?  The 'Bunch of Carrot Farmers' name and logo is clever.  This is a similar thought process to my "Grow To Go' concept in that you would use 'Fast Food' or 'Junk Food' marketing vocabulary to try to resonate with kids in the same way that the unhealthy stuff does.  Thanks for the concept!
Excellent idea of comunication
I love the idea - the video's great.  Totally to the extreme.

promoting_health_food_like_junk_food_fun.title: Promoting Health Food Like Junk Food (funded by stakeholder coalition)

the_truth_campaign_for_food.description: The Truth anti-smoking campaign circa 2000.  How can we harness the rebellion of teenagers with a compelling presentation of nutritional data?
the_truth_campaign_for_food.creator: 93bfa00b2ea719b86a94413e06b1d56c

comments.text:
I think you make a good point about how ideas can be marketed in innovative ways to particular audiences by bringing attention to these shocking public service ads. Scare tactics, like the ones employed in this anti-smoking campaign are very striking and attention grabbing for sure. I feel that this ad is aimed at the teen, to young adult demographic and is most successful at appealing to the feelings and motivations of that group. 
However, I think healthy food education needs to begin much sooner than the teenage-to young adult years. Kids need to start learning and making healthy food decisions as soon as possible and there needs to be another way, (a more positive/fun/interactively focused way to get the message acrossi.e. campaign efforts to show all the benefits of choosing healthy foods versus focusing on the negative effects which seems to appeal to an older audience).

the_truth_campaign_for_food.title: The Truth Campaign for Food

kids_cooking_show.description: Do any kids cooking shows exist? If not, why not? As I can think of plenty of ways this could appeal to children.
kids_cooking_show.creator: 47e9b5043e3f7a92dc70efbde37d2857

aiming_at_their_pockets_planning_taxes_t.description: Enacting tax benefits to healthier fresher foods, and raising taxes for unhealthy processed foods, so people would prefer buying healthier fresher food just because it's cheaper.
aiming_at_their_pockets_planning_taxes_t.creator: 0abc9ca16994245ceda7f034f218401d

comments.text: I agree this in an option.  But taxes rarely solve anything.  Cigarettes are taxed at an extreme premium and while it may dissuade some from picking up the habit and provide for others that little bit of extra encouragement to quit, I would strong argue that the value taken by an artificial tax does not come close to the value added by the increased price.

aiming_at_their_pockets_planning_taxes_t.title: Aiming at their pockets - Planning taxes to benefit healthy eating

make_shopping_a_game.description:
"The solution to the problems of bad nutrition, obesity and poor health may be right in front of you the next time you go to the supermarket.

Researchers at New Mexico State University say a simple change in the design of shopping carts may help people make better decisions about the food they buy."
make_shopping_a_game.creator: 6f82c6af8130dc89c1d939f797c735ba

comments.text: Vincent, while I find the shopping cart divider quite cool, I personally hate those prison-like divided plates. They remind me very much of undefinable thick, green stuff that gets smashed on ones plate :-)
Wow, nice demonstration how a simple visual reminder/path can really guide behavior. This provides support for the various divided plate ideas that have been posted.

make_shopping_a_game.title: Make shopping a game

do_as_i_say_and_eat_identify_and_replica.description: Children learn from their parents. Studies have shown that parents with issues around eating and weight, too restrictive or too expansive are likely to raise children who take those attitudes and behaviors to the extreme. We know that there are some parents out there eating well. The project will identify different families that are leading a balanced life, we will distill their lessons and then work with them to bring their methods to their social networks and communities across the U.S.
do_as_i_say_and_eat_identify_and_replica.creator: 5de4e01017b6184d0f1302a3464719b4

comments.text:
I like this idea of creating links socially. This could easily be adapted small scale to. One could start in their own class room where the teacher invites parents to share recipes within class members so that parents and students can get involved.
By inviting different parents this makes it quite diverse and fun learning and eating experience.

do_as_i_say_and_eat_identify_and_replica.title: Do as I say and eat: Identify and replicate healthy living by healthy, diverse American families

pillpa_a_flying_orchard.description:
In the same way that we digest our food better if we are mindful of it, touch it and smell it before we eat it, for children, cultivating their food as part of playtime raises in them the awareness of the food that they eat and of their health.
In Pillpa we promote education through motivation and full participation.
pillpa_a_flying_orchard.creator: bd76c863a11e0094586ca9f50bd86a33

comments.text: In this our third year working with kids in social risk in Pillpa,  a small course on food handling was added. Kids learn to wash their hands prior to handling the vegetables, when to peel or not to peel, how to use a knife without hurting themselves, what to cook and for how long and what you can eat raw and why. We also teach them how to preserve fruit and vegetables for when they are not available. It sound obvious but not for this kids, some of them never have eaten anything but tomatos and lettuce, if.

I like the idea of different gardening sections designed for specific age groups.  And the concept of integrating hands-on learning about agriculture into children's education while also teaching them about healthy food, satisfaction from good work, cooperation, etc. Glad to hear that it has been successful so far!

In today's fast-paced world, where kids think veggies come from the produce section of their local supermarkets, no wonder they opt for fast food, which leads to a host of other issues, including obesity and diabetes, but also generation after generation of future adults, future stewards of the earth, who give little importance to the earth that bears our food. There is no appreciation for what we put in our mouths, and even less for what it takes to get that food to your plate. I think this idea is brilliant and portable. Let's make one in Toronto!!
Great using a visual image of a butterfly hold your concept and reinforce the natural beauty of home grown produce. Brava!!!

Congratulations!! It's a great idea, already started and proven and fun to do! Kids love it and it gives them awareness of where veggies come from, how to take care of them and how great they taste when they harvest! And in addition they can observe diversity making it's own magic with insects, birds, earthworms and all class of trees and plants. It's a magical place. Hope Pillpa flies all around the world!
And it is already working with great success! Thank you so much for commenting Ed and Patrick, I love to see the wheel go round and round and this butterfly flying high.
this is such a lovely idea, highly collaborative and inclusive.
Why re-invent the wheel, right? Thanks for sharing this proven idea!

pillpa_a_flying_orchard.title: Pillpa, a flying orchard

student_city_lot_farming_project.description: Take a cue from the food-truck craze and create ‘Moo-vable Barn' Trucks.  These barn trucks will not only service multi-lot urban farm projects for kids but will also draw attention and build interest in this fun program aimed at educating city kids about growing great vegetables and eating healthy food.
student_city_lot_farming_project.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Stephen, Thanks very much for your kind comment! Great idea to incorporate Farmer's Market farmers into the program. Not only could they stop by some of the urban plots that the kids are tending and give lessons and helpful pointers on cultivation, but day-long field trips could be scheduled to take the kids in the program out to the country to visit the farmers on their farms.  They could tour the operations and hear the farmers describe how they care for all of their produce.  As you mentioned, connecting the kids to actual farmers is very important.  When they see the care and effort that goes into cultivating their vegetables, I would bet that kids would better be able to see produce as valuable and treat it with more attention and respect.  This would also be a great way for kids to draw a conceptual line from the food on their plate back to its source. I think you are right in getting the kids to see and interact with young, hip farmers.  Showing them someone that they could identify with and relate to would probably help to make the job of growing food for people more real to them and, therefore, more interesting.  Thanks again for the comment!  I really appreciate it!

I love this idea.  I think putting kids in direct contact with food, farms, and farmers is critical to expanding how they thing about what they eat.  Check out the American Center for Sustainability.  In the Spring 2010 issue of Edible Portland, the cover story was about the Center's mobile seedling program.  They converted an old public transit bus into a mobile greenhouse to deliver seedlings to urban pea-patch farmers.  The bus itself is very cool - even the front bumper was turned into a garden space.  
I suggest adding options for Farmers Market participants to be volunteers in the program.  In addition to the food, connecting kids to the farmers is key.  Using farmers as educators in this model would be a powerful addition.  In the Pac NW, many of the farmers are young hip families themselves - something kids and families can easily relate to.
Thanks for the great idea here.  It's my favorite and, thus far, the only one that's inspired a comment.  Cheers! - Stephen

Thanks for the comments!  Eddie, I like the idea of using trucks to bring the farm to the kids.  I think there was an early inspiration about that... I'll have to go back and look... but that could definitely be an aspect of this concept.  Actually, maybe the trucks could not only be the 'barn' but also a 'greenhouse'.  Maybe the flat roof of the truck could be fitted with modular plexi-glass 'greenhouse' boxes.  The clear boxes could hold seedlings to be planted at various lots, herbs to bring to classes for cooking demonstrations, lettuces, etc.  The boxes could then be taken off of the roof and lowered to street level to give kids access to them.  In tight urban environments utilizing every sun-touched surface, even the truck roof, to grow vegetables and herbs, is vital!Also, as you mentioned, taking advantage of warehouses could work too.  Maybe big roof gardens could be constructed that groups of kids could be taken to.  These permanent 'farming centers' could also have things that vacant lot gardens couldn't, like chickens for eggs.  Great stuff!  Thanks again for the comments!

Haha!  This could be lots of fun!  You could event turn it on it's head and have trucks bring the farm to the kids - where you could have compact hydroponics boxes for the children to work on, and to water and tend to.   Thinking about it again, what about all those empty warehouses in cities?  What about converting some of those to community gardens that the Moo-vable barn could take them too.  You wouldn't necessarily need much space, and if they are unoccupied, the got to some good use.
Love this idea! Mobile + motivational and also enhances community resilience.

student_city_lot_farming_project.title: 'Moo-vable Barn' City Farming Summer Program

fruits_first_then_vegetables.description: Scientific research showed that 80% of children have bitter sensitive gene. Most vegetables are mildly bitter. So don't force vegetables on children.
fruits_first_then_vegetables.creator: 01f07c71f71429cbd5e429d7bf8a0d0f

comments.text: Very good point. We should not be dogmatic about these issues.

Goodness knows this applied to me as a kid.  It's only made worse by using fruit and veg that not quite ripe or has been treated in some way to hold it in suspended animation while it travels halfway around the world to get to the grocery store.  Sauces - even a good dollop of butter - that goes a long way to yumming it up.

Indeed pay attention to their response to vegetables, especially those with enzymes that may be more offensive. Remember that preparation helps significantly! For example, roasting Brussel Sprouts removes more of the enzyme that many find offensive. Use light home made sauces to mask flavors and gradually reduce/remove them...

fruits_first_then_vegetables.title: Fruits first, then vegetables

get_all_the_foodies_out_of_the_closet.description: Launch a campaign where healthy role models confess that they eat / cook / grow their own fresh food.
get_all_the_foodies_out_of_the_closet.creator: fce81d42a66b3440338f98e31e897347

comments.text: It a good idea.  Similar to my inspiration to have pop stars like Justin Beiber sing about good eating.  Endorsement from celebrities can go a long way.  Or even to connect good eating choices to pinnacles of pro-sports achievement.  Like the Daytona 500 winner drinking milk.  Maybe the winner of the U.S. Open has a photo-op chomping on a 'Big Apple'. Or the Tour de France winner eats a bunch of carrots (minus doping allegations).  Anything to get kids to think healthy food when they think of the sports stars they want to be like.  Another tone option would be "eat healthy food?  Of course!  Don't you?!  Healthy eating got me to where I am today!"Good one!

I think that this is a powerful influencer for all age ranges.  Let's get radical and say that all Olympic athletes have to openly endorse fruit and vegetables and healthy food ahead of other commercial sponsorship!  We need heros, not just for children, but for adults too!

get_all_the_foodies_out_of_the_closet.title: Get all the foodies out of the closet

k12_food_lab_and_open_tastenovation_plat.description:
k12 Food Lab would involve kids in further scientific research into the senses, how they influence food choices, and how they can be exploited to get kids to overcome their first reactions to some new tastes and to provide healthy options that subtly adjust the tastes of foods to cater to the palates of kids. The lab could be a food truck, a small restaurant, a few offices at a university, a building or its own campus.

The Open Tastenovation platform would involving kids in the hypothesis formation, research, prototyping, and evaluation processes, building their thinking skills as well as their understanding of their palates.
k12_food_lab_and_open_tastenovation_plat.creator: 8f8753f65ff6a98c5661cf0006f44620

comments.text: Another kind of food lab:http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/63519/title/FOR_KIDS_Tomatoes_that_trick_taste_buds

k12_food_lab_and_open_tastenovation_plat.title: k12 Food Lab and Open Tastenovation platform

inner_peas_from_tots_to_tweens_.description: We propose to teach health in an original way  within a traditional system: the schools

cookbook_cook_website_for_kids.description:
When I was a kid there was a kids cook cafe in Amsterdam. The cafe also had a cookbook with recipes to prepare real 3 course meals. Each meal / recipe was well explained and clear. It was also written in order of the steps to take. If it meant that it is better to start with desert, then it started with that. Also there was a ranking from easy to make to difficult. I remember making a lot of menus for my family!

Would it not be great to have such a book again? However in these modern times a website might be more appropriate, or both!
cookbook_cook_website_for_kids.creator: d03915870a2cad6fb92c645901e2ddc5

comments.text: I have also learned cooking through a children cookbook and a children magazine from school that contained a recipe on the last page of each magazine. I still make those recipes today! Why can't we make a very nice cookbook with 'fresh cooking' - even 'fresh and simple fast food.' Simple good and fresh cooking. And make it useful for adults too!The recipes can be easily catagorized by season (making a dish that uses fruit and vegetables that are mainly harvested in e.g. winter, or summer).Also creative cooking should be stimulated. By explaining in a book some cooking basics, explaining that, for example, carrots are sweet, and tomatoes are sour, and how certain products combine and complement.

My older sister had a very good cookbook she got when she was 8 yrs old and still uses today, with basic recipes and Disney characters. It got her cooking and especially baking from an early age. I think it was this onehttp://www.amazon.com/Disneys-Family-Cookbook-Irresistible-Recipes/dp/B002PJ4HBC/ref=pd_sim_b_8

cookbook_cook_website_for_kids.title: Cookbook / cook website for kids

understanding_where_the_food_comes_from_.description: With the new technology and way of life kids have become unaware of where their food comes from, and the emotional link and personal engagement with the origin of vegetables and meat is lost.
understanding_where_the_food_comes_from_.creator: 2c18df3a1fe8ae587232da21f7c216a8

comments.text: Maybe another important aspect, building on your comment, would be to encourage local fresh markets, and separate the fresh food from junkfood-filled supermarkets, so that kids (and parents, with their massive influence on them) are more aware of where the food comes from, even getting to a personal level, as it happens in small, local foodmarkets.

I agree with you that children dont know where the food comes from so they can not build a link with nature. since all the food comes from supermarkets where also all the junk food are sold, all the healtier food is put in te same category. 
I believe that the consiousness of healthy nutrition comes from family. to create awareness of the benefits of the fresh food for kids, the process must start from the households.
I remember that when I was little, I visited my grandparents home more often which has a huge garden around and full of vegetables, tomatoes, cucumbers, beans, kiwis, pears and berries. I have played with the leaves of beans which are very sticky and usefull tools for joking around :) I have cooked corns in the oven and eat tomatoes right from the garden, coloured my hands with the berries and surprised when I learned that there must be two roots (a male and a female root) for a kiwi to grow.
that way I created a linkage with the nature and then on it improved. and I think this is essential for the awareness for other children too.
Sorry, the pics and video did not load properly. All the info about windowfarms as a method for urban farming can be seen in their website http://www.windowfarms.org/

understanding_where_the_food_comes_from_.title: Understanding where the food comes from, personal engagement and awareness for better choices

la_machine.description: This funny interactive website shows you how depending on what you eat, you might suffer or not when you go to the loo.
la_machine.creator: c186d344b513f4950e063174b5b150f4

comments.text: Yes Demian, I must admit that it is a bit strange, probably not funny for everyone.  As you mention, what I like about it is how very simply explains the consequences of eating certain type of food and the combination of them.  After all, having a healthy diet it is not only about eating fresh food but in a balanced manner.

Wow.  Very strange.  A limited interface, Sort of loud. Could be a subtle advertisement for Nutella.  Features dancing poo with crazy eyes.  But I kind of like it!  Maybe the idea is about developing a video game for kids that centers on the entire body and how what goes into it and how it is treated affects its performance.

pronto_the_food_delivery_system.description: Parental involvement + Child incentive + convenience = a change in eating behaviours.
pronto_the_food_delivery_system.creator: 84dfdcb9d5ea5a538ca6c185070a798e

comments.text: nice idea. i appreciate the approach. lresearch indicates that for adults, keeping track of what you eat has a positive impact on long term behavior change and weight loss. not that the aim here is weightloss, but i wonder if something can be adopted from the journalling approach to get and keep kids and parents more intouch with making healthier choices. it could be fun & interactive. think of how many parent still reward kids with stars on a calendar for good behavior, good grades, potty training, etc. journaling could be creative and educational. weightwatchers has a pretty good online system.

Thanks for the posts! Damian, i really like the idea of an online system component for parents and/or children to log on, maybe print out coupons as well as meal recipes like you said! I have been researching a fun and engaging way to do that; using some sort of barcoding and/or picture recognition technology through the use of a hand held device for children. I believe taking the convenience factor into consideration; parents and children wont just log onto the internet unless they have some sort of incentive (coupons for parents)or it becomes more game like (for children)..hmm! Vincent! Thank you for your link. When conducting my research (user testing) I realized it was really difficult to create a functional lunch box divided solely on the basis of each food group (For example: what about combination foods like a sandwich?) That is why this system has three segments (dividing a meal into 3 components) with an accompanying packaging system all using an "Exchange system". Therefore combination foods could be accounted for and a more usable lunch box could be developed. Children get the same understanding of food groups and portion control but in a more realistic and normal experienced way. Great feedback and truly appreciated...this is fun!!

Brigid, Some good stuff here!  And thanks for the research!  Agreed there are definitely some similar ideas to Vincent's concept from a few days ago.  Maybe a hybrid collaboration could happen? :)  I like the idea of a flash card box with recipes and tips for each meal component.  Maybe there could be a way to translate that to an online iteration?  Meaning; when the parent buys the weekly kit either the purchase is noted by the Pronto system or the parent emails/texts Pronto to initiate the start of the week.  Then each evening Pronto emails both the parent and the kid with recipes and instructions for assembly of the next day's lunch components.  The emails could include fun facts, interesting science/health information about the next day's food, fun videos, whatever.  So the parent and kid then have instructions on hand, most probably displayed on their phone's email, to engage in the assembly of the next day's lunch components together.  Not only would Pronto be engaging the kid in an active interest in the food that they will be eating but also it would facilitate a time of learning and relationship building between the kid and parent.  The dividends of which would more than make up for the cost of the weekly kits!  Thanks Brigid!  Keep it up!

Hi Brigid,
I posted a similar concept earlier (http://bit.ly/9MoCSp), so I may be biased. Anyways, I really like where you are taking this with the pre-packaged components providing convenience for parents & personalization for kids. The attached supporting research is also great. *Applause*  *Applause*

pronto_the_food_delivery_system.title: Pronto, The Food Delivery System

become_a_maker_and_empower_kids_to_creat.description:
Developing a love of making food (real foods, things that can feed a family, not just snacks). We can build good eating habits for life if we can teach kids the beauty of making things.  
We have a duty to teach our children lessons in life that will help them live a better life, and eating right is one of them.
become_a_maker_and_empower_kids_to_creat.creator: 4a4c7fb62fdde566a5fe43bf1fc4d93d

comments.text: I think this idea starts to nail the issue on its head - personal responsibility to instill in your children the values that will contribute to them becoming healthy, happy, successful adults.  Its great to show children how exciting healthy food is at school, but if they come home to McDonald's every night, whats the endgame?

become_a_maker_and_empower_kids_to_creat.title: Become a maker, and empower kids to create with food

happy_saint_fiacre_s_day.description: On September 1st we celebrate the day of Saint Fiacre, patron saint of food growers. On this day, children of all ages come together to make a full dinner out of fresh food for the party of their choice: a group of friends, their (grand)parents, the homeless. The key element of this food fun day is celebrating good relations and fresh food together. Leading up to this day, kids send out Saint Fiacre’s Day messages, inviting people or telling them what they will make and for whom, and suggesting recipes at the same time.
happy_saint_fiacre_s_day.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d
happy_saint_fiacre_s_day.title: Happy Saint Fiacre's Day!

fao_toolkit_for_setting_up_and_running_a.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text:
David's suggestion is quite true.  I wonder about creative ways for making things grow indoors with little space/light/soil.  How about sponsorship from Hydroponics companies, and this could be even part of the science class as well.
http://www.growell.co.uk/f/hydroponics/What-Is-Hydroponics.html

I think this is a great idea. I worry about areas that don't have land (city schools) or are in arid climates. How about some indoor gardens as well? Part of the kids morning routine during announcements - water their plants, etc. There could even be awards for the best growers - teach kids the hardwork that is involved just to get one vegetable!

fast_garden_food.description: Imagine a restaurant that features a cool indoor playground a la McDonald's and meal packages with a positive reinforcement prize ( a la the "Happy Meal") but that serves healthy, locally grown vegetarian, or even vegan meals.
fast_garden_food.creator: 63d266506383ed9b4152479c1777cef9

comments.text:
Hi Tamara
I endorse and encourage your idea! I find myself in a position to visualise this, and with your permission, i will file the idea into my reference frame and perhaps explore it further through design when the opportunity presents itself... (i'm currently a lowly 2nd year Landscape arhitecture student, but i'm determined to help change the world). 
Your issue here would be the right client. It's said that good designers are those that find the right clients. With the capital, the drive and vision, and a holistic designer on board, this scheme will be brilliant in an urban context. One would provide a space that will function as an indoor (or transitory) semi-public dining area, perhaps continuous indoor and outdoor playground/dining spaces... Oh, the possibilities! can you imagine (especially for the limited space of an urban framework) a green roof above the restaurant proper - that recycles greywater and rainwater through biofilters of course - that is designed to be a highly productive, perhaps hydroponic/biocircle/keyhole garden, vegetable garden that supplies the restaurant with all its stock in terms of the vegetarian diet [although sustainability and vegetarianism should go hand in hand - no, should be bedmates for that matter]. The kitchen will recycle their scraps, surplus and wastes as compost on site for the garden; and all signage, materials, packaging (minimal!), utensils etc. should be part of a recycling program that returns the recycled material to be reused for these same items! In terms of structure, a sustainably constructed building would almost zero energy costs, the cost of the nascent sustainable tecnnologies would be offset in a matter of a few short years (thats why you need the right client and by implication, the right capital bracket), provide a pleasant microclimate (imagine if the garden were accessible to the customers!) while supplying endless offsetting in terms of the contribution to lessening the urban heat island effect, the wellbeing of the users, a healthy [and innocent] diet available to the fast-food indoctrinated city-dweller, and hopefully promote the influence of environmentally-friendly novelty and wholesomeness as a trend :) Aweh indeed!

highlight_the_short_term_benefits.description: People, kids included, tend to value more what we can see and feel now even when we know the long-term benefits may be greater. How can we combat that temporal discounting?
highlight_the_short_term_benefits.creator: 5985a2173f02d421f866c74433afbb2c

comments.text: I agree, Thao. I don't think either needs to be compromised, and I like your idea of rewarding long-term and short-term thinking. My point was that evidence shows people tend to see short-term benefits more easily than they do long-term benefits. That's why saving for retirement is a challenge, or sticking to a diet. I *know* eating fresh veggies is better for my long-term health, but I still eat the potato chips because they make me feel good right now.

I agree there's nothing like instant gratification, but I don't think you have to compromise short term gains, for long-term benefits, or vice versa. A system that rewards short-term achievements with small rewards, and long-term achievements with bigger rewards may foster long-term thinking. For example, my last inspiration was a piggy bank & tokens. Reach 5 tokens, and get 5x, reach 100 tokens and get 100000x.

highlight_the_short_term_benefits.title: Highlight the Short-term Benefits

fresh_foods_fresh_souls.description: I would love to see gardening in schools.  Growing fresh foods for their school and community while learning the importance of eating healthy.
fresh_foods_fresh_souls.creator: 9c4f8d6497375368d9fd417cc8b3c9b4

comments.text: This is a great idea. We live in Arizona and my childrens elementary school has a gardening program. Each class has a raised bed. The program is sponsored by the parents' group. The kids work the earth, plant from seed, tend the bed, and even bring things in from home for the compost piles. When everything is ready, they harvest their crops and cook/prepare what they have grown. Every child tries what they grew. My kids have eaten all kinds of things they would never try before. Each garden has a theme. One year they grew a salsa garden, another year a three sisters garden ( a traditional native American garden of corn, bean and squash), and many others. Good luck with your idea!

Continuing on the theme of concepts which could be implemented across many schools in parallel, I think this would be a powerful way to build awareness if combined with the earlier idea of enabling kids to cook for each other at school.  Imagine eating food grown by your friends and cooked by your friends!  Super idea.

This is a great idea. In the UK some schools do have vegetable patches, which is great, but that still isn't enough, as not much cooking is done with the vegetables the children grow, afterwards... So the kids don't get to see the full potential of what they could achieve with their produce, which, I think, is a shame! That is why I like your idea - it includes the next step of learning much more and preparing the food as well ... and it links very well with my own concept of After School Coooking Club!
This reminded me of school community gardens in parts of Australia, see for e.g.http://www.kitchengardenfoundation.org.au/

I really like the heart of your idea - parents seeing the pathetic state of their kid's school lunches and getting inspired to build a community movement around locally grown healthy food.  The one main issue that comes to mind, which Jamie experienced when he took his Food Revolution series to West Virginia, is that each state (even nationally) has laws and regulations that dictate the content of the food that is served in public schools.  And sometimes the laws are so draconian or lobbyist driven that they actually work against fostering healthy eating habits in kids.  So the main hurdle might be just getting past all of the government red tape to be able to supply the school kitchen with locally grown, community raised produce.  I am sure it is possible.  With enough will power and passion for the truth anything is possible.  But it will be a battle against the regulatory status quo.  Here's to the fight!  Thanks for your concept!

JUST DO IT! Chickens are fun, the kids love them and is a very good way for them to understand the compost process.  All weeds from the vegetable garden go to the chickens and the chickens bed goes in to your compost bin. And that is all you need to fortify your soil.And yes, it is a lot of work, but it is worth it!

Wow, great!Finally a non-diital solution to a natural problem. I can't understand the concepts based on digital and virtual ideas. It's the digital world that created this distance between us and nature!and no, chickens are not pushing. I think that more animals should help on the side.But what I like about this Idea is how it gets the children closer to nature (and food). I have a small garden and mostly I eat what I pick. If someone gets me a fruit, I don't feel like eating it (I can't explain why but I think that i's a feeling that grew along with the trees and the vegetables) I see this feeling growing trough this idea too.

fresh_foods_fresh_souls.title: Fresh foods = Fresh souls

Provide training for teenagers to teach cooking classes featuring fresh produce in elementary and middle schools.  All ages will benefit from this and it will teach the teenagers leadership skills as well.  The younger ones will listen because they naturally look up to the older kids.

Knowledge about cooking, recipes, ingredients, etc was often times passed down amongst family, neighbors, and community members...this was the case until the likes of KFC and McDonalds starting started providing us with with the convenience of fast foods. Improving our food IQ is going to take time and money. But we either pay now or pay later in the form of health care costs.

I think this is a fantastic idea but how feasible is it if people are simply looking at a bottom line.  Great Idea, maybe the schools themselves can grow some of the fruits?  It will take a whole lot of wrangling to get these schools to shift some of the funding from refrigerated Milk and easily obtainable frozen foods to something that perishes as quickly as fresh fruits do.

I remember it as great. It is aslo a good incentive for families to shop around for vegetables and fruit when the kids are "required" to have it in school.

forbidden_fruit.creator: 1299159a7417804f4ade6ab5e3651255

comments.text:
Ian, 
I really think that your inspiration is great food for thought and it helps us re-evaluate all those solutions that are based on a didactic, paternalistic or regulatory framework that would not work well with kids, in my opinion. I wish I could applaud this inspiration 7 times!

Hahahaha, this is fantastic, and so true! I cannot remember who said this (it might have been the inspiring educator A.S.Neill), but I am sure you will like it:
"There are three ways to do something:1. Do it2. Pay someone else to do it3. Tell your children not to do it"
This is hilarious because it might work, but i don't think it is the right way to do it though. =)

mr_and_little_miss_.....fill_in_the_vege.description: Can we create a series of books for fruit and veg using a similar format to the Mr men books:  - Little Miss Carrot, Terry Turnip,Sydney Sprout, Edna Eggplant etc Each story focuses on a single dominant attribute to convey a nutritional lesson. Maybe each book could have a series of challenges for the children to take up at the end (how to get peas for tea). Maybe the characters could interact together in the stories to communicate '5 a day' . The key would be keeping it simple, funny and colourful.
mr_and_little_miss_.....fill_in_the_vege.creator: 8d6e3fb8c9908f1cddb3234e9dd8e241

Wouldn't that be great to create healthy food characters that taught important health lessons and stayed relevant over multiple generations?  This could definitely spread the news and get kids excited about healthy, fun food!

the_incredible_edibles.description:
In pursuit of efficiency and convenience, we, as North American consumers, demand better accessibility of our daily needs. The food industry has responded to this change in need and supplies the market with mass produced and processed food.
Now, we buy corns and peas in frozen bags, beef in ground form, chicken in pieces and
fish in fillet form. This shift in lifestyle creates a shift in consciousness. We no longer see food as a fresh produce from the nature, but mass-produced products rolled out from the assembly line. Food, therefore, becomes just another consumer product on the shelf.

The goal is to attempt to raise the awareness about what food is. Food, being not just the thing that we eat, once has life and a story. Food, being one of the many essentials in our lives, can reveal our cultural history as well as relationships between people
from the different parts of the world through understanding the logistics of our food supply. The more we find out about the story of the food that we consume, the more we become conscious about things around us. Using children as a starting point, this project attempts to spread the consciousness of the need to understand our food, and the world.
the_incredible_edibles.creator: f3fec08331b211417c12aeffe9a12ff8

comments.text: Great concept! Using two things that come natural to children: playfulness and curiosity, should work wonders.

the_incredible_edibles.title: The Incredible Edibles

comments.text: I found this, and I think is very inspirational, and I think each school, kindergarten should have a contract with something similar. http://www.zephyrosfarmandgarden.com/slideshow/634

Matt, I am sure it is just a mather of having support from more sides, we have much ways to implement something today thats worth to. I think if each school will benefit by a small publicity on local TVs for example with the kids in their farms, and with the scheduled lessons, I am sure this will have a huge benefit, not to mention websites, videos, and many many ways to do it. Hand in hand we built to last.

Just like the White House garden has been a shining example for citizens of the US, school gardens/farms have the potential to have the exact same type of effect. They eventually turn into more than just farms and gardens-they turn into spaces for community gatherings and opportunities to learn about fresh foods. 
Here is a HUGE problem for most schools, though...there is an intense pressure for schools to put their students in a position to score well on standardized tests. In many states, teacher pay and jobs are even tied to this performance. While you and I may value the learning opportunities associated with school gardens, the reality is such that most people will not due to the pressure of our culture of testing. Given this, how can we convince people that this matters? How can we find the time for school children to get out to the garden and participate?

each_school_should_have_a_such_called_se.title: Each school should have a such called "Self made farm"

the_food_curriculum_part2.description:
Building on The food curriculum for national and international schools. 
connecting, school children with the real world and the real world with children, children with adults to adults with children and using different cultures/industries/ histories and societies to connect realise, and understand explore play



connecting existing platforms, knowledge/ information is the key, a complete 360 facilitating is needed for this to succeed.

NOVELTY is the WRONG WAY FORWARD!!

The methods used should be Food and accessibility of learning bias.The entree level must be obtainable by every person with every situation. So with this in mind, a concept for delivering a collaborative schooling curriculum across disciplines/industries/cultures/ages etc.. must mean using formats that are already popular but already exist and are scaleable / easily changeable. Something that promotes an action and discussion and documentation.

any apps and till based programs can be developed to facilitate a shopping visit augmenting the meaning of shopping for food.

All the content in the world needed for this already exists all the formats already exist its a matter of collating and creating relevance to that content. giving it connection and meaning.
i dont want to mention any current projects or ideas as this very much detracts from the core message im trying to put accross, we dont need anything else, its already in front of us we just need to structure the content and reemphasis what it can mean.

Food bias means the think with the food at its best in mind. This should have as little novelty and branding as possibly as "design" detracts from the communication. What we need is DESIGN, that is incognito that facilitates information, helps store, collect,collate,document,connects.

food is not fun, but it can be if you know what to do with it, that doesnt mean it should be treated like play doe, or make a freak show out of them (re food circus) ultimately this is what caused the lack of respect in the first place, making food into 'objects'. (re: round tomator vs heirloom tomato in the photos above) the behavior towards food need to be geared towards an appreciation of the natural state and the process of obtaining this food.

supermarkets in the UK im aware that they have specific SUPERFICIAL 'guidelines' to adhere to other wise theyre not 'fit' for UK supermarket consumption.. often species or types of natural fresh produce are picked not because of the quality but usually upon their aesthetic perceived 'qualitys'. If a tomato or an apple isnt round and unblemished even not solid in colour or texture, this is apparently not fit for consumption and rendered waste. THIS  is obviously disgraceful, and one of the reasons perception is SO important and RESPECT towards food is important.


 Everything is against us in this instance, which is why at ever level this project should communicate the relevance and respect towards nature and its effects on both us, as individuals but as societies and environments. This is where the connection happens.

data visualisation showing how much food is eaten in a week per person physically this can change ones life...

fundamentally it must be as hands on as possible, doing and experiencing all the time.
less of this elitist food rubbish about so called artisan/organic/bullshit. this is what segregates people.

you grow/rear/farm/plant food then use ingredients to make things, we then experience it through eating it and it has an effect on our body. this happens every single day to every person on the planet.

there are millions of ways of exploring this. so an individual example of a business would not do this project any
the_food_curriculum_part2.creator: 87071ee2050ad7bc38ed005d03434901
the_food_curriculum_part2.title: The Food Curriculum  - connecting what already exists / perception / awareness

make_the_kids_the_teachers.description: The best way to learn something is to teach it. Create a curriculum/hands-on experience where we speak candidly with kids about why the topic of healthy choices is important (obesity, diabetes, etc) -- let the kids articulate what's in it for them (more energy, grow big & strong, feel good) and who they are going to teach (younger kids in the school, their parents, etc.). Help them discover what tastes good to them and is also healthy, plus finding alternates in cases when they simply hate the taste of something. Let them present to parents, teachers, local officials on what they learned, including hands-on with food. Video it for parents that can't make it due to travel, work or illness. Make them rockstars and they will teach others.

chow_chew_chat_the_real_food_interventio.description:
A  three tier intervention programme  that encourages children aged 8-13 to recognise and ask for real and tasty food everyday. It will include in-school education, a user generated website and support packs for teachers and parents.

1.Tween Real Food Advocates - these will be the kids that lead the pack. They can develop new recipes, take charge of schoolyard crops, demonstrate knife skills in culinary class, imagineer online cooking games, organise a class cooking smackdown, investigate from where our food comes or just be the most adventurous taster in the class. Peer pressure can be a good thing!

2.Tween Cooking Think Tank-  is an online place where Inspiration, progress and problems can be shared. An edible schoolyard in Berkeley could influence the growing of a pot of potatoes in Edinburgh. A 'Cranberry and Pecan Soda Bread' recipe posted from Co.Cork, Ireland could make a tasty afternoon snack  in Chicago. There are so many people and organisations that love real food and simple cooking- we just need to hear each other.

3.Tween Cooking Support Packs for Adults-  sharing new cooking skills and interests with family will be helped by simple information available to download, parents cooking days and an online chef to answer all questions.
chow_chew_chat_the_real_food_interventio.creator: babc2860c134a097abd7b53f2a2a4193

comments.text: Sushi definitely has a visual appeal because of the presentation: small, colorful, playful...finger food. It hits all the senses: sight, taste, smell, touch, and the sound of my tummy be satisfied.  I'm a sushi lover, and I think we're on to something delicious.

Bento Boxes for kids are a massive winner at our place, if its shaped into a cute little chicken, or flower, or star or the latest cartoon caracter - It's gone. We invested in a few simple tools and utensils and now health food is cute food. When my daughter gets involved in creating it's craft time to her - not eat your vegies time!

I think it could also be the "raw fish"..To adults this has certain connotations and to kids it potentially has an entirely different meaning==>imagine a child running in his or her imagination with the idea of raw fish. I imagine we might get a lot of "oohs, that's gross" or "coooolll, that's awesome". Kids attraction to sushi could possibly be in how their imaginations run with the food!

liberal_paternalism_nudging_choice_archi.description:
Choice architecture describes the way in which decisions are influenced by how the choices are presented. It is in arranging the choice architecture in a certain way that individuals can be nudged in a certain way without taking away their freedom of choice. A simple example of a nudge would be placing healthy foods in a school cafeteria at eye level, while putting less healthy junk food in harder to reach places.

School lunches often use ID cards to track student lunch purchases. They could be tweaked to track student diets.
perhaps parents could see this data and be disgusted by the information, or reward them for impressive results. maybe other parents could see your kids scores.
perhaps then we could have a tangible history of what students ate, and how it might be affecting their lifestyle.
perhaps then that students buying lunches would have a weekly 'maximum balance' for carbohydrates and proteins.

comments.text: This would be great to turn into a game: - collect your daily fruits and vegetables- earn a daily badge when you get 100% of something in your daily diet- have awards for streaks, etc.

Great idea!And if anyone have doubts over personal integrity : a project like this do not have to be individually, the statistics could be made anonymously, and only show an average of the class.or of the whole schools statistics.it could also include the cost per portion in the school and so on.
another side track could be to make it possible for kids to voluntarily add info about the other food that they eat at home or out in restaurants ?
Better yet, get everything that isn't healthy out of the schools.  Then everything kids get will be something they and their parents can be proud of.
Sort of like a Mint.com for automatic healthy eating/nutrition tracking through purchase history.

you_are_what_you_eat.description:
An app centered on the life of a virtual character that needs to eat healthier, in order play better. Kids (and their parents) will help the character make the correct food choices, whilst learning to understand and engage with the benefits of fresh food.

The idea is to have the character living an ongoing life that involves selecting the fresh foods at meal time, preparing it, eating and playing games. The aim is to select the correct food, by developing an understanding of their nutritional benefits that will help the character compete better in playing the next round of games.
you_are_what_you_eat.creator: 1dbe400eebee1e550ac7884baeea8fa1

comments.text:
There is a seed of a great idea in this. 
Couple of points to keep in mind:- credibility is the key, the game needs to be for the kids, not for the parents and kids have to be able to share the fun with their friends (get the kids to educate their parents)- technology should be relevant and accessible for the target audience, i.e. online social media from club penguin to mobile phone apps- partnering with relevant brands makes all the difference- don't create just a game but a platform for teens to drive social change in a world where their eating behavior is dictated by parents, fast food joints and school lunches- as @zahoor mentioned below the crux is to make this available for rest of the world and people outside the converted. Mobile phone could be the tool for the people with no access to PC, read example of Nokia Life Tools that are targeting developing markets: http://europe.nokia.com/services-and-apps/nokia-life-tools/main
I'm not sure on this one - it seems nowadays that an 'app' is the answer to everything.

The idea is good. I think one of the most effective ways of getting kids to learn is by combining two key elements: (1) visual learning and (2) gaming. This is precisely what this idea proposes.
I don't believe the concept is truly original. However, originality does not matter to me as much because sometimes the best solutions are the simple, yet effective. This is definitely a simple, practical and effective idea. 
My only issue is w.r.t scalability across communities for a couple of reason:
1. Only 10% of the world's population has access to Internet. Kids in developed countries might be tech savvy, but in the developing world the story is very different. Access is the first hurdle, followed by knowledge and time. 
2. Different cuisines / cultures - For this application to succeed, it is absolutely essential that the game developer has a robust understanding of different cuisines, and creates localized modules for individual communities. In addition, cultural sensitivity will also be equally important. 
Nevertheless, its a good concept.

The idea is very good, at last there is some use in social gaming, but how to make kids interested in this particular topic? Most of them very likely  will prefer something more exciting.. For adults it can probably work better.

Love the idea of piggybacking on social gaming, it invites a change in behavior rather than critiquing existing behavior which I hope would help whole families to better understand the benefit of healthy eating
Nice. I like the idea that "morale" is also a factor for winning and that a burger may keep it up.

I think we could have several different interfaces overlaid on the same platform but targeting old kids or even one for the parents. The idea is to educate through play and understand the consequences of having a bad diet.

I like the fact that social gaming gets more and more supporters. This is a very nice concept. I like the various challenges. That is what keeps it interesting. Don't you think this could appeal (maybe in another game interface) to an older audience as well?

you_are_what_you_eat.title: You Are What You Eat

comments.text: My favorite food these days is Kale Chips!  You can do barbecue flavored ones too!  They are even raw, so that they have nearly all their vitamins and such intact.  You can do a search for "kale chips" and you'll get lots of recipes.  There are even a bunch of videos for making them.  It's really simple, as it's just making a simple marinade/dressing, tearing the kale into smaller pieces (and removing the stems), and then massaging the dressing into the kale.  Then dehydrate in the sun, in a dehydrator, or in an oven on very low heat (preferably with the door open so it doesn't bake the poor things.  They get deliciously crispy and salty and so yummy!  AANNNND... good for you!

universal_standards_for_agriculturehorti.description: The creation and cultivation of the baseball diamond, the football field, basketball court and track & field arena were all essential in the development and massive proliferation of their respective sports, industries, economies and cultures.  Today they are dominant in our public landscape both physically and culturally...By creating a similar standard paradigm for agriculture+ horticulture within public space and schools in America we address Jamie Oliver’s challenge by integrating children’s physical, intellectual, and nutritional education on this new “playing field”; by laying the grounds for a universal proliferation similar to mainstream sports; and most importantly –concurrently restoring the lost links between what goes into food, where it comes from, and the children we feed.
universal_standards_for_agriculturehorti.creator: 8e70965981c5bc5214e59b15cf618f67

comments.text: The notion of eating healthy, organic, and fresh has hit a big part of America of recent, but in general, is still geared towards a very small percentage of the general population. The western side of the world has recognized fast food as a normal part of every day life and the root is in the lack of knowledge and lack access to anything much better. In terms of knowledge, I think this concept of raising awareness to kids by exposing them at an early age is crucial. Environment has much to do with how we view what we eat. However, this healthier way to growing and cooking our own food may be challenging if it is far more expensive than the alternative. If both the recognition of the importance of healthy foods and the ability to make it financial feasible is available, then the initial hardships can be overcome. Wonderful concept that I hope to see implemented, even if on a smaller scale!

Very interesting idea!  I think the uniformity applied to sports arenas, etc. is there to 'level the playing field' to enable fair competition.  So I think you are right in seeking ways to make this modularity a platform for fun competition.  How this happens, though, to me is the tricky part.  Cultivation capabilities change with every location due to specific climate, soil, etc. as well as locally available foods.  Some things grow better in one place than another.  So I think these standard gardens would be affected by climate in ways that sports arenas are not.  That is not to say that this concept couldn't work!  Just that the idea of competition based on standard growing platforms will have to be developed to take this into account.  Good stuff!

@Bruce Seaton:  Thanks for comments, your school in New Mexico sounds like an interesting place and I wish you good luck with your school gardening efforts in particular.  You might want to take a look at the Gary Comer Youth Center Roof Garden for some ideas on how to integrate a roof garden into your particular curriculum.   http://www.gcychome.org/

@Elson Trinidad:  Thanks for sharing.  Element-based and dimension-based standards both seem crucial in developing a set of standards and/or rating criteria.  I really hope that various different experts in education/agriculture/urbanism would be very excited to participate in a dialogue/workshop focused on programing this proposed paradigm.  Perhaps they might even organize a more focused design competition on finding a suitable paradigm.  As you point out, one of the major points of discussion in this dialogue would be that of balancing the existing regional context/climate/heritage with the new universal spatial/programmatic/curriculum/nutritional requirements that children all over the country/world should learn regardless of their locale.  As human dietary requirements are more or less universal, I see them as having the single biggest influence on how this proposed paradigm should be programmed.  Please see the website for Ecology Action for further detail: http://www.growbiointensive.org/index.html   They have developed a wonderful universal 4x8 module for sustainable mini farming that is currently being implemented and monitored all over the world which would serve as a really great reference in this ongoing dialogue.

Very cool. I work at an urban charter school in New Mexico, where a large part of our student body comes from farming families (chiles, mostly--yum!). We've been trying get something like this going in our building's courtyards, on an obviously limited scale. Charter schools often don't have the requisite space of other public schools for serious agricultural projects, but a few of our teachers have been looking at green-scaping our building. New Mexico is perfect in some ways for roof gardens (all the buildings have flat roofs), but few plants can really handle full New Mexico sun (including, sadly, most grasses). 
Such projects, however, could be interlaced with virtually any core high school subject--the sciences obviously apply, but related paperwork, applications, and project evaluations could be completed in English classes, social/environmental impact of these projects could be analyzed by social science courses, and materials/needs/expenses/layout and so forth could be handled by algebra or geometry classes. The addition of a competitive element to this theme is a fantastic idea, particularly for this age group. What a great way to make sometimes boring course matter apply to real life! Great stuff, Dan!

Very interesting concept. I've seen community gardens in different cities and communities, some of them look quite attractive while others look like a disorganized mess. 
I wonder though if these standards will be more element-based or dimensions-based; may be a problem for the latter as public spaces obviously vary in size. Also, there should be some leeway for creativity to reflect community vision/aesthetics/values/culture(s). But otherwise a very novel concept.

@ Michael C:  Thanks for your comment.  Yes you are right, one of the great qualities of modularity is an ability to adapt to a given context as scale & shape permit.  However given this particular challenge, its sheer scale, massive audience (America's youth) and most importantly its URGENCY; "every instance [being] the same" has tremendous advantages.  Imagine James Naismith's layout and rules of a basketball court.  For the most part, they are universal all over the world and have achieved an far reaching iconic quality known.  This leads to them being universally learned, recognized and practiced by people all over the world despite their many differences.  Gardening & farming in schools, parks and any other available public spaces need to be distributed with a similar universal+iconic layout and set of rules+standards if they are to reach children in the same way.Moreover, there are far too many community gardens that simply make do with what urban infill spaces are available and many times these places are unsuitable for children.  Meanwhile, there is no shortage of dry turf or asphalt within the American public parks and schools where such a layout could be as easily & rapidly implemented in the manner in which basketball courts have been. I remember walking the "Not a Cornfield" Project in Lincoln Heights.  It's an amazing project and a continual transformation of the city.  I thought it was very experimental, radical and necessary.  I still do and I think it something that all Los Angelenos can be proud of.  However, in order to meet the scope of Jamie Oliver's challenge, it's now necessary for efforts to evolve from separate, experimental and radical to unified, synthesized and mainstream.  Cultivating children with gardening & farming the way we cultivate children with Sports is the perfect channel for such a transformation.

The notion of a modular farm/garden is a good idea because of how expansive it could be. I think one point that should be made is that just because it is modular, does not mean that every instance is the same. There could be multiple modules developed that serve as the building blocks to fit specific sites and needs. Additionally I would state that you could have multiple phases of these modules. For example, you could have a first wave of modules that seek to reclaim lost urban space (whether due to site damage or the expansion of park systems). The next phase of modules could then use the now improved site to yield crops. The entire process of growing and land reclamation would be a very useful tool for education. Not only do you teach them about where their food comes from, you can teach them about the impact society has upon nature.
Although not exactly the idea you posted, there is a project in Los Angeles called "Not A Cornfield" that merged art, landscape architecture, and land remediation into one singular project to improve the community. Your modular gardens could build upon ideas such as these.Not A Cornfield: http://notacornfield.com/

@ Liz Snyder:  Thanks for your comment.  Full Circle Farm www.fullcirclesunnyvale.org looks wonderful and the fact that it's between soccer and baseball fields makes it even more accessible and attractive to children.  What a great integration + addition to your community! 8 months!  Wow!  Think of everything that could have been grown in that time. You're absolutely right, an amendment to the building codes for urban/neighborhood farms such as yours would be a huge step toward seeing more and better farm programs.  I'd love to hear more about how you were able to overcome the 8 month long nightmare and I'm sure others who are trying to start similar farms would really appreciate the advice.

Agree 100% with this. Full Circle Farm (see Pam Fox Rollin's Inspiration) is such a space - built behind a middle school, it's an 11 acre farm between soccer fields, little league, and a suburban neighborhood. Because the city had never seen anything like this before, getting the permits approved was a 8-month-long nightmare. A code for spaces like this one would take that burden away and create a network of "neighborhood farms'".

universal_standards_for_agriculturehorti.title: Universal Standards for Agriculture+Horticulture in Public Spaces

smoking_and_junk.description: Straight to the point campaign linking the emotions felt towards smoking to eating unhealthy food.
smoking_and_junk.creator: d3d7eaed605c49b6d7fa0ffa4e4d642d

comments.text: First: These campaigns don't work. Believe me, I work in advertising. They create awareness and maybe public interest amplyfied by the media, but they don't change people's behaviour. Second: Such campaigns are often just a form of whitewashing governmental reluctancy to change the law in a way that really protects the people even if it means a loss of significant tax money, which makes them noncredible for a bunch of people.

Agree - just campaigning will be not driving change. However as ads do effect our decision making (it is just about to identify those 50 percent which work isn't it  ?) there is need for a campaign. So how to get out of this limbo ? The classical way would be "heros" or "vip" which represent themselves as advocats. However where to find celebrities or idols which really stand for green ?
I also think that the tone of voice of this idea could be explored much more thoroughly so that perhaps the message is delivered in a less patronizing fashion and a more informative.

I think this idea is all about provoking reaction and getting people to psychologically agree with the idea that poor eating choices are bad for your health, even if they don't act on it there and then. 
Thanks for the comments, it's always nice to hear honest opinions. @Franziska Luh and @emir shad, I'd be interested to see the proof that the provocative smoking campaign graphics (both bill board and on the packet) have not had a positive impact on the perception of smoking as a bad habit. I would challenge anyone to be able to prove that the small-dosed and frequent exposure to these graphics and images does not have a impact on the conscious and subconscious of the smoker so that in the long term they are more likely to make the right decision about whether to smoke or not. 
So whilst I do not believe that alone this idea would see the end of unhealthy food choices in kids, I do see it as part of a wider campaign that yes grabs attention in a way that resonates with people.

the british government are going to stop all public information campaigns because they just dont work.... its about education not making light or sillyness out of something, i dont think image play is clever in 2010, maybe in 1942 it may have held some significance but,. lets not be patronising
Don't stop with analogy to smoking. Your brain on drugs... your brain on junk food.

Thanks for the comments. I wasn't really thinking that it could be taken as far as banning junk food eating in public or insurance companies getting involved, I was more trying to frame the topic in an emotional context that people understood. But, perhaps this is the end point when we consider the strains that unhealthy eating is putting on the public services we are all entitled to. I talk from a UK stand point where we have the NHS and the impact obesity is having on this service is astounding!
http://www.24dash.com/news/health/2010-08-27-UKs-obesity-problem-placing-overwhelming-burden-on-NHS
At the very least, more effort needs to be made by governments and organisations in promoting a healthy and sustainable (in terms of health) lifestyle.

Interesting concept! (luv the photo of the kid. He will definitely appreciate that one being out there when he's older :) ) Your idea started me thinking how far the association between a practice such as smoking and the practice of eating junk food.  Could definitive studies be done that show a relationship between junk food consumption and heart disease, diabetes, obesity, shorter life expectancy, etc.?  If the claims cold be supported by peer reviewed data, would the next step be legislating that warning labels be put on all of the burger wrappers that are sold at fast food restaurants?  Or push it further to the point of cities and states making it illegal to eat fast food in public, just as it is illegal to smoke inside a restaurant or office.  Could it get this far?  Maybe, instead of laws being the driving force behind this sort of change, it would be insurance companies that would be on the forefront of this change in public habit.  Maybe insurance companies could mandate that, to receive the lowest premium coverage, you could not be a fast food eater (much as you can't smoke to be considered 'low risk')I am not sure that this would be the best way to go.  But it is definitely a conceivable route that could be taken as the affect of fast food on our collective health is further understood.  Thanks for the concept!

I love that junk would be the early 21th centuries smokes! Moviestars forbidden to eat burgers, labels on snacks and lawsuits all over the place. It would be really cool to check out the old anti-smoking campaigns and just remake them into anti-junk campaigns. Looking at the numbers we obviously dig quite good...

sponsor_a_virtual_child.description: Ask the children to offer food to the starving child to help them grow strong and healthy. Ask the child to guess which food the starving child would offer them to help them grow. Talk about what they actually ate today. (Display everyday 'good' and 'bad' options.)
sponsor_a_virtual_child.creator: 37bb1586d1a76b03d4ba37f98cb98710

comments.text:
I think there's a gem of a great idea in this concept. Kids love nurturing virtual pets and places, Nintendo DS etc have already demonstrated this. The idea that the children could feed their virtual child and perhaps make better food choices than they would for their real self is quite an interesting idea. It may help tie up their engagement with their diet and the implications it has on their bodies.
It needs to be carefully constructed (in consultation with psychologists who specialise in children's eating habits) or I think this concept presents certain risks. I don't think we should be encouraging children to label food options as "good" or "bad" but rather encouraging them to create a moderate balance to which our bodies are best suited. My friends who have the most healthy relationship with food can sit down and enjoy a slice of cake without thinking of it as sinful. It is those for whom the slice of cake is steeped in guilt that are more likely to be trapped in unhealthy relationships with food. 
I don't think the idea of tackling the issue of third world poverty and poor nutritional choices is the right way to sensitively encourage and enable children to make healthy food choices. The idea of starting the "game" with a starving child could be harmful and offensive. It is teaching extremes, when we should be teaching moderation. 
Eating will always be an emotional experience, our bodies are designed to receive information about what we are putting into our mouths in this way. We need to build knowledge and understanding in young children so that their food choices can be informed with facts and not just feelings. This concept could be a great tool if constructed carefully to better synthesise the drivers behind a child's food choices.

Interesting concept. The better the food given, the better the child does, I presume. For instance: feeding the child with a balanced meal from fresh foods helps the child more than feeding it pizza or processed food.It resembles the old Tamgotchi principle and the popular Moshi Monster site. I think you could be on to something!

sponsor_a_virtual_child.title: Sponsor a virtual child

mcdonald_s_rooftop_gardens.description: What if the fast food industry took a lead role in talking about healthy, seasonal, locally grown food?
mcdonald_s_rooftop_gardens.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Yes, it'd be great if some fast food chains got on board. And never say never. Walmart, although far from perfect, has come a long way on the sustainability route vs. what many thought was possible. Regardless, trying to get the big fast food chains involved, even with small changes, would be a step forward. And, if they don't change, that just means there's more room for upstarts to come in and make a difference.

I definitely think there are opportunities for fast food chains to incorporate fresh, healthy and naturally raised ingredients in their foods. Chipolte is already doing this-they source locally when possibly and try to only source meat from farms that raise animals naturally and humanely. Chipolte certainly isn't the size of McDonald's, but it serves as a proof of concept. My wife and I were talking a while back that it won't be long now before McDonald's starts offering burgers made from grass fed cows as an option. I do question, however, whether a restaurant chain that is the sheer size and scale of McDonald's can make such a change.

mcdonald_s_rooftop_gardens.title: McDonald's Rooftop Gardens!

comments.text: yea ... like lazy town in Islandia ... they could made that the kids made much more exercise and eat more vegetables ...

I completely agree. Like Popeye made kids kinda want to eat canned spinach back in the day, if Sponge Bob today went crazy for a spinach salad kids would most likely want a spinach salad too.  The only issue holding these cartoon characters back is the money.  In today's celebrity cartoon world, there are bills to pay.  Sponge Bob probably has a whole entourage that he has to keep kitted out in stylish square pants.  The square guy needs to get paid!  So it is more likely that he will endorse a sugary processed cereal instead of a salad since the cereal company probably has way more money to pay him than the Spinach Growers Association does.  The key, I think, is to figure out how to incentivize celebrities and characters popular with kids to endorse healthier eating habits.

comments.text:
I think that people are already aware of the health issues with junk food. Also, I'm not sure if getting the government involved would be of any help, or make sense.
It seems like a lot of the reasons people always resort to junk food is for two main reasons: price and time saver.
Price isn't as valid of an excuse as time. Many kinds of produce, rice, noodles and other foods can just as easily be turned into a meal for cheaper than fast food.
Time on the other hand, seems to be a valid complaint.
I don't think raising the cost via taxes will help. Remember, there's a difference between educating someone about their choices, and forcing them into a different choice.

The premise is a farm in your backyard, and getting your local community/neighborhood to get involved. He keeps a blog about his work: http://downtownfarm.wordpress.com/

food_gardens_as_part_of_the_larger_outdo.description: Food gardens in schoolyards are often marginalized as a "supplemental" educational resource and teachers can't respond to "add-ons" because their plates are already too full. It's time we integrated Outdoor Classrooms into the culture of K12 education by designing green schoolyards that lend themselves to academic instruction across disciplines. Then healthy food activities can be taught as science, social studies, language arts, math, etc.
food_gardens_as_part_of_the_larger_outdo.creator: 51496f6682240d101fb62e9139ae295c

comments.text: Has the same thought. A lot of times teachers feel that they have "another thing they have to teach." This initiative should be taken up at the school-wide, school district and/or state level so that curriculum is designed for implementation. Each grade level at the school can be and should be involved in this project. The youngest students can start seed banks - sprouts - while the older students take care of maintaining and improving the system. The family community can be involved too.

food_gardens_as_part_of_the_larger_outdo.title: Food Gardens as part of the larger Outdoor Classroom

As Akio Morita, the ex CEO of Sony said wisely once: We dont ask consumers what they want. They dont know. Instead we apply our brain power to what they need, and will want, and make sure were there, ready. On the same way children, probably put in the frustrating act of choosing, would probably don't get the whole benefit behind.
Growing programmes sound cool, but compulsory?
