trace_your_produce_back_to_where_it_was_.description:
This idea would require participating growers/distributors to include a serial number on their produce that allows kids+parents to track where it came from. Picking a fruit or vegetable turns into an adventure that takes them on a journey around the world, helps them learn about where food comes from, how it's grown, and realize the simple beauty and humanity behind fresh food. 
Most people have forgotten about the natural appeal of fruits and vegetables. Kids are growing up not knowing what an apple tree looks like or that potatoes grow underneath the earth.  The purpose of this idea is to change that by getting them engaged and interested in the origins of their food in a fun and dynamic way.
trace_your_produce_back_to_where_it_was_.creator: 35bfb12f8a900b4804e9a4118f17823c

comments.text:
In an attempt to go green, corporations like Wal-Mart are labeling where their products come from. 
Take a look at this article, Wal-Mart to label products with eco ratings: http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10288186-54.html  
To change how they make and sell products, Wal-Mart ...ask its suppliers to provide environmental information on all products carried in its stores. Wal-Mart Stores will use that information to label each item with an eco rating, designed to measure its environmental friendliness.
This was in 2009, and I don't know the status of their mission, but I think it's applicable to the kids' challenge. Has anyone seen this being implemented at Wal-Mart stores?
A good point to bring up is how much it might raise costs, or the price for consumers. It would require Wal-Mart to do extra work (working with universities to collect data), and to redesign it's packaging to accommodate the new labels.
This might be worth it for kids if it promotes a fresh-foods-eating lifestyle, which I think is likely. The more you know about something, the more you are open to making lifestyle changes. If kids grew up with this tracking system to help them know where their foods come from, they'll utilize the knowledge where ever they go.
Harvest Mark is a system that would allow for this - in addition to being educational, it also adds transparency to our food system, allowing tracking of food safety much more feasible!

This is a good idea. In Europe, eggs are already stamped with a number code, which translates into type of chicken farming, country of origin, company, stable. If this can be implemented on eggs, it can be on other foods as well. See http://www.lioneggfarms.co.uk/information/egg-codes/ for an example.
And for the badges: you could also have a badge to applaud using local foods (not further than 100 miles from home).

trace_your_produce_back_to_where_it_was_.title: Trace your produce back to where it was grown (and learn a thing or two in the process)

wheels_of_wellness_health_awareness_van.description: In this concept, a van drives from town to town, educating children and their families about their gastronomic health.  Able to be rented for schools or communities, the "Wheels of Wellness" van provides an unique hands-on experience that allows anyone from toddlers to the elderly to see both the devastation caused by poor food habits, and the advantages of healthiness.  Including anatomical samples, a projected time-lapse of a child, and full-size dummy demonstrating the harms of eating fatty foods, Wheels of Wellness would be the perfect educating solution for families on healthy eating.
wheels_of_wellness_health_awareness_van.creator: f3e99a84f85bc13f7a57c8047dc25608
wheels_of_wellness_health_awareness_van.title: Wheels of Wellness - Health Awareness Van

re_educate_parents_to_educate_kids.creator: 2920899f8af779533dbdadfa38f3b85a

comments.text: thanks for the feedback. I'm not sure of the effectiveness of these labels on cigarettes, I've never been a smoker so all i can say is it reaffirms my stance on the issue, something i will definitely look up though. the way i see it the fast food giants are effectively doing the same as the cigarette companies were, marketing a deadly product anyway they can to make money, even marketing to young people who do not understand the full implications. Yet they are still allowed to market anyway they want when obesity is the biggest health issue in western society. something i feel definitely needs to change.

A very poignant moment in Jamie Oliver's US version of the 'Food Revolution' show came when the mother of one of the main families started considering the thought that maybe it was her buying decisions that led her son to be on the brink of diabetes.  A harrowing thought for any parent.New York city has recently implemented a rule that restaurants (only fast food places maybe?) have to list calorie counts next to items on their menus.  I am not sure if this is having any affect on people's selection choices.  What is the health difference between a burger that is 580 calories and one that is 690 calories?  May be too abstract a metric for the typical consumer.  Do people have a sense of what it would take to burn off the extra 110 calories?  Also, does the typical consumer have an idea of how many calories per day are considered healthy for their age / body type / gender / activity level / etc.?  Probably not.Warning stickers on food just like warning stickers on cigarettes is an interesting idea. 'Saturated Fats Lead to Obesity and Heart Disease'.  Or 'A Sugary Drink This Size Every Day Can Lead to Diabetes'.  If the data is there why not use it?  But I guess a critique question would be to ask how effective the warning labels on cigarettes have been.  Is there evidence of people changing their behavior because of these warnings to support this method?Either way I think warning labels on food are a provocative idea and something to think about.
I had a photo of the labelling idea, not sure why it didn't upload

re_educate_parents_to_educate_kids.title: Re-Educate Parents to Educate Kids

comments.text: wow...from imagination to execution: "creative Betsy". I like it, because it's holistic thinking, collaborate between knowledge and experience.

When I was a kid I remember how much I loved reading again and again the comic strip on the back of the corn flakes package that described how corn flakes were made. There was a step-by-step illustration of the manufacturing process that I found very interesting! Kids are inherently curious to know where things come from.
I like it! It could also create a link between the food and the well known books which main characters are animals... as the 3 pigs and the wolf and so on :)
I like it! It could also create a link between the food and the well known books which main characters are animals... as the 3 pigs and the wolf and so on :)

I like this too. Not just for kids, adults too. 
In Australia, we have labelling for livestock (http://www.mla.com.au/meat-safety-and-traceability/livestock-identification). I think it's RFID technology; it's for quality and safety.

I like this!  Sort-of a 'character development' concept applied to food.  Interesting idea if an egg company started to publish children's books about a cast of chickens.  And then the eggs that they sold could be labelled with the chicken character's names along with some other detail that might carry the book story lines further.  Would definitely get kids interested in egg selection and eating.  Great idea with a lot of potential!

comments.text: This ides could be build up so that the scanner not only decides the info about the food, but scan the total meal.  This is, if the meal is healthy and fresh, the possibility is high that the meal is colorful.  On the other hand, the food at fastfood is colorless (except their artificial colored packages). The healthy scanners could not only give you information about the food, but to keep track of what you are putting in your basket to buy; showing you what other items you could then buy to complement your diet in a healthy and balanced manner.  Going even further, what if based on your purchase it send you recipes and suggestions of what to do with this healthy food selection.
It could be combined with shopping carts as well - check out the concept posted on same lines called healthy food guide scanner.

go_digital..description: Using digital information, we can add up the amount calories you have been consuming. When calorie information is added up and recorded, it becomes very different in it's impact to a small box on the packaging that nobody wants to look at, besides the health obsessed. Make calorie counting digital, useful, easier and fun.
go_digital..creator: d1aacd22b4aa8bdc73b7b0053eb8a201

comments.text:
Building on this, what I'd like from this is a very simple graphical application on smartphones.  Many kids already have phones and parents have them too.  We come up with a simple bar-code that can be scanned by the camera - loads of software to do this already.  This includes all the breakdown - calories, fat, protein, vitamins, etc - even include allergy information on nuts, etc.  When you scan the food before eating it, it updates a simple graphical pie chart on your phone display and shows how you're doing - too much/too little of different nutrients.  If we make a simple online system, restaurants can also enter their ingredients & weights for meals and the system will produce a simple bar code for their meals that can be included on menus.  We can build in other features such as games, leaderboards, competitions, training towards your soccer practice, warnings of overeating, etc.
We could do a fast prototype with a couple of local restaurants & small grocery stores and get some feedback from parents/kids on how it helps/motivates them.  
Hopefully this would raise awareness for everyone.

@Rosemary: Not too sure how barcodes work, i guess the barcode could be like a bit link.(http://bit.ly/axcPZi) as opposed to information directly and that would direct to web information on the product and alot more of it, photos, similar products, nutrional information etc.
@Anthony: I agree that more than just calories is needed, I find it hard to work everything out, but i guess after one week of food digitally recorded, suggestions could be made to one's deficiencies. Maybe some new scoring technique is required, many have tried such as weight watcher points. I still remember being 15 and a girl telling me that she couldn't have tikki masala as that was too many ww points, more than a whole day, so she would have to starve herself all day and miss breakfast the next day just to allow it. Interesting how aware she was of an intense meal.
Hmm...can the nutritional information be embedded in the product bar codes? Then you can get the info when you scan your groceries in the store while shopping or figure out a way to phone app it.

I like where you're going with this -- I have similar thoughts with labeling and bringing nutritional information to the forefront.  However, my issues with this idea are that kids don't understand these labels and it's not all about calorie intake.  I've proposed an idea on a food ranking system taking into account calories, vitamins, minerals, proteins, carbs, etc., resulting in a 0-100 score.  We can apply this concept to your games, balance sheet, point-scoring concept to come up with a truly powerful method of getting kids to not only be able to easily appraise food choices with a 0-100 score that factors in more than calories, but to have fun with it and develop a game or an application that kids want to play with.

go_digital..title: Go Digital.

fresh_idea_to_be_fruit_smart..description: Adjust the functions of vending machine might help in changing kid's behavior of snacking, and it might even enrich kid's vocabulary/knowledge for fresh food and challenge their financial thinking.
fresh_idea_to_be_fruit_smart..creator: 29514707bbcb62361d562fe8679f2990

comments.text: coool ... a fruit spender machine ? clever ! it could really work in schools and oficinas !

The pragmatic reality is that vending machines earn money for the school that they are in.  So schools are loathe to get rid of them.  I think vending machines and the products they offer either have to be banned from schools via legislation or they have to be countered with something else that is healthier yet just as enticing.  And a similar price point.  Maybe subsidies would be helpful to make healthier snacks more affordable?

I think that there should be severe restrictions on vending machines within schools.    They really can promote snacking between meals, so if they're full of caffeine, preservatives, fatty food, etc, then that's not good.  Anything which promotes them to sell healthier alternatives, or encourage healthier habits and raise awareness, and learn, all the better.  I wonder if schools have experimented with removing machines altogether and monitoring average pupil weight!

fresh_idea_to_be_fruit_smart..title: Fresh Idea:  To be fruit-smart.
